Employees of all kinds, even management would stand around talking in the middle of a rush.

Better pay

The work atmosphere was nice and for the most part I usually enjoyed going in to work because I knew what to expect and if I ever had a problem, the management would always try to help resolve them.
Cons: Since it is the restaurant industry, there was sometimes unnecessary and unwanted drama due to the coworkers lifestyles and the relationships that stem from working in such an environment.
Advice to Management: Don't allow dramatic or sensitive conversations to take place at work or during working hours.

Title: "Assistant Manager"

Title: "Server"

Title: "Server"

It's really stressful when you're on a wait, as the servers aren't very apt to pre-bussing their tables. There is no tip share and the servers won't tip you out, no matter how many of their tables you end up bussing.
The host positions are hellishly understaffed. There's typically only one host per shift, unless it's a Friday night or Sunday morning.

Title: "Hostess"

Title: "General Manager"
Pros: Some of the people that work for the company really try to adhere to the Business Model of ERJ Dining or Chili's
Cons: There are too many to list them all but the majority of upper management are hypocritical and will say one thing to your face and then when their boss is touring with them, they will act as if they agree with all directives. Upper management can often let their tempers get the best of them and the company uses religion to cover up the many character flaws or its people which include blaming those down the management team structure, a lack of knowledge on what it means to run a restaurant leading to ridiculous expectations that are used subjectively at every store depending on how much upper management gets along with that Management Team or how much money they make for those above them. There is a lack of respect for tenure and it actually tends to harm a lot of middle management because they will find a reason to replace you if you are making too much money. The company has a lack of understanding of the communities it serves and holds all restaurants to the same goals in turnover regardless of the workforce available to the area. Retaliation often occurs in this company keeping its employees to present their true problems and feelings. Assistant managers are in and out of the stores almost as much as the hourly employees because the training program is not holding everyone to the same level of accountability causing the stores to be short staffed so much so that everyone is expected to travel to guest manage at stores that are up to 80 miles from their home.
Advice to Management: Follow your Inverted Pyramid, Don't be naive to think that your Regional Managers are all doing their jobs with the morals and ethics that The person who started this once great company expects of his employees. Stop sweeping problems under the rug by moving managers from one store where they create an issue to another store thinking that the person will change. Take harassment, both sexual and verbal, seriously and understand that it occurs in the restaurants today as I type by a number of managers including your training stores.

Title: "Chili's Bar & Grill Company Review"
Pros: The company that owns Chili's (Brinker Nation) is a well run, and organized company. The continue to lead the casual dining category. The have the best food out of all the companies in this category by far.
Cons: The company places unrealistic criteria on the serving staff. Requiring a certain percentage of people to answer a survey at the end of the meal. The use a 5 point scale for these survey questions. If any customer answers anything but a 5 on any of the questions, it is then perceived negatively on the servers and management.
Advice to Management: Place a higher importance on hiring quality staff.

Title: "Open, Close, or MID to relieve managers"

Cons: Too much responsibility for 13/hr
Advice to Management: Make sure a progressive track for promotion is in place within 9-12 months

Title: "Server Review"

Title: "Great team spirit"

Cons: Long, and late hours. Sometimes getting off work at 12am and having to be back to work at 10:30am sucks--especially if you have class the next day. My sleep cycles have not been consistent as a direct result of working at a restaurant that closes at 10 and 11 on Friday and Saturday. It's hard to complain though when you see the nicest management team all working 80+ hours a week.
Advice to Management: Keep up your hard work! The team would suffer if it weren't for your guidance and support. Keep asking for pay raises--cause they certainty deserve it.

Title: "Server"
Pros: Great atmosphere and fun.place to work with understanding management that lead by example.
Cons: Relying on tips and cheap people for your lively hood. Slow lunches and other nearby restaurants cause some months to be slower than others.

Title: "Everything is variable"

Cons: You work your butt off every shift. You are not guaranteed to make money. There have been many shifts that I made less than minimum wage. It is a very high stress job. Many customers don't tip at all. Many more customers tip very little. Your schedule is different from day to day and week to week. You may not know your schedule more than a few days ahead. Just because you are scheduled for a specific section for the night does not always mean that is what will happen, beware of last minute changes, without your knowledge.
Advice to Management: Having more than a 2 day notice for my schedule would be great, especially for those who have other obligations and/or children to consider. Gratuity for large parties should be mandatory. I've had too many groups who run you ragged, and leave you nothing for your time.

Title: "Server"

Title: "Chilis"

Title: "Line cook"

Title: "Ups and Downs"
Pros: Great place to be. Fun atmosphere . Moving up the ladder is easy. Co-workers become family. Easy money. Cash in hand every night including tip share for bartenders. Great starting point for first time servers. Always hiring.
Cons: No bussers. No food runners. Very little Q/As because the pay isn't worth it. When your location isn't fully staffed, you end up doing multiple jobs outside of your own. Big concern on survey responses without proper support.
Advice to Management: Chilies has lost it way with the focus to make a profit. Go back to the basics. Make your Q/As more valued and bring back bussers and food runners if your intent is to have a great guest return rate. Servers are the least paid and do the most work. We make our living by the service we provide which is also how your intent to return rate, sales, and bonuses improve. Without Servers, there is no service.

Title: "A self destructive company"
Pros: I work with some amazing people. Throughout my tenure with Chilis, I've learned that most of the best managers are strong individuals that defy corporate culture and truly make the work place meaningful.
Cons:
Massive wage theft.

As I write this, a coworker is currently setting the restaurant up for business. This employee is not clocked in. They have been doing this for five or six days a week for going on four years. This person has even received several ATL (above the line) comments from former GMs and ADs.

Very tight run company. Employees are often asked to pick up product from other locations because we run out. They usually on their way to work and not on the clock while this happens.

Not salary competitive. Most employees, hosts especially, can receive better pay and less work from other companies.
Advice to Management: Chilis looks great on paper. Stop being disengaged with your guests and employees. Actually try performing the tasks you ask your hourly and salaried employees to do.

Title: "Server"
Pros: I like my coworkers. I like my bosses. The perks of discounted or free food is always appreciated and i recieve highly valued services and special treatements from other businesses because they consider me an "insider". The money I earn can be considered easy and fast.
Cons: The work is hard. The hours are long. The conditions can be terrible. There is no such thing as a lunch break in the restaurant industry (even if I am scheduled all day) and the pay is under mininum wage. I joke about this constently. The stress level can be through the roof. Sometimes the customer can be stressors, sometimes coworkers can be stressors, and sometimes my managers can be stressors. The entire work shift can be considered slow, boring, and a waste of my time or overwhelming and not properly backed up by my team or supplies. Every day is something different. The hardest part fo the job title for me is to be able to take care of yourself in times where you may feel obligated to help others, Sometimes when working as a group or in a team everyone must do their best to focus on their job because one weak link can slow the entire group down. Nobody can afford to help someone swim so you have to let them drown or learn to tred on their own. I learned this the hard way, by helping others I took away from my own guests and their attentative needs, This resulted in poor survey results which dictated my scheduling. So even though I was helping all my coworkers and taking one for the team, when it came to my pockets for the shift, I was then hurt again by the lack of hours scheduled to me because of my poor customer intention to return survey results.
Advice to Management: Use discretion

Title: "OK."

Title: "Server surveys are very unfair"
Pros: Working with a great team. Team service is usually great. Managers help on the floor and in the kitchen. And usuall no silverwear rolling!
Cons: ITR! Survey guest take after paying on ziosk or online are your job and main problem. Spending hours trying to get a 5 on one question is terriable. Once something goes wrong (cold food, weak drink, long door wait) it will probably lower your itr score. It dont matter if it is ther servers fult or not. If your score goes under a 67% you only have a couple weeks to redeem yourself before you get fired.
Advice to Management: It wouldnt be so bad if we went constantly reminded that we may lose our job if we dont get surveys .. A 5 at that.. No 4s .. Only 5s.. Its a rolling score. We have good and bad days .. We are human and its impossible to keep every single person happy. I can say the most of our staff takes pride in our work and make a strong effort to make every guest feel welcome and special. Its a shame to see a company lose so many great servers over this. Maybe management could have a meeting to talk to corporate.

When I got my first paycheck it was wrong so I went to him and he said it was more bonus based than anything.

Also at the store management seemed to talk about other managers behind their back this was the area directors doing. That area director would take credit for a great numbers but anything that went wrong was behind on the management team. I worked there for 16 years, started as a dishwasher and walked my way to the general manager. Our new area director mind you store just closed because of bad numbers all of a sudden becomes our new director. Came in and fired the team managers that work there 16+ years and hired a whole new manager instead even though the numbers were the best they've ever been. Basically boils down to if he didn't like you or you didn't kiss his butt you were gone.

Title: "Great - most of the time"
Pros: Chili's is great if you are in college or high school and do not have many bills to pay. There is great opportunity for good tips, but I'm sure that varies by location. They have always been good to me and they are typically pretty flexible when it comes to scheduling.
Cons: They do not always hire the best employees. Sometimes it seems as if they would hire anyone who walked through the door. Chili's has a TON of promotions and sales that decrease the overall price of a customer's meal, and it also decreases the tip amount if the customer is paying the standard 20%. It would be a terrible place to work if you actually had a lot of bills to pay. There is no overtime.

Title: "Chili's is very confused"
Pros: Met some of the best people I know while working at Chili's.
Cons: The brand is very confused. It is not sure what is wants to be to it's consumers. Working in operations, and then to upper management, there was a stark contrast in reality as to what was expected from the operators. The parameters that are given vs what is expected is just not realistic. Managers would be crying daily because the stress that would be placed on their shoulders was too high. The menu is ridiculously large and impossible to execute properly.
Advice to Management: Figure out what kind of restaurant you want to be. Listen to your operators honest feedback. Labor parameters are just too tight to operate a menu with 120 items. The fact that the menu cannot be executed properly and timely is why you are losing guests. And guess what....Bussers help keep your restaurants clean at very minimal cost. Big mistake to eliminate them.

Cons: Very repetitive work every table, every day.

Title: "Company going downhill."
Pros: Met amazing people and made decent money.
Cons: The corporation is taking that company in the wrong direction. The ziosks were and still are a horrible idea and make it not fun to work there. They make the job unfair and the focus of the company is deterring away from customer service.

Title: "Server"
Pros: Flexible schedule & quick cash. Cool environment as well, A lot of out of work activities.
Cons: Menu items are so cheap so running up a tab is hard when everyone gets 2 for $20's.
Advice to Management: None

Title: "Average Serving Job"
Pros: Easy and laid back environment that does not require much effort or concentration
Cons: Cheap food means cheaper bills, which means fewer tips. Management is unorganized and does not know what they're doing or talking about half the time

Title: "I absolutely love this restaurant. Great food!"
Pros: You would make good tips, and there would never be a dull moment.
Cons: It is constantly busy, so it can be a bit crazy.
Advice to Management: More wait staff is needed.

Title: "Server"
Pros: Flexible schedule allows for attending classes, raising a family or a second job. Performance-based scheduling for sections and shifs.
Cons: Corporate environment which is good for stability and benefits, but does not allow for a whole lot of individuality.
Advice to Management: Keep up the good work. The only advice that I would have is a general statement to all people think before you speak.

Title: "server"
Pros: take as many tables as you can handle
Cons: You have to do everything yourself. No food runners, no bussers, tips are decent

Title: "Waiter"
Pros: Coworkers seemed to be very respectful. Restaurant was clean and training was good. Kitchen did a very good job.
Cons: Management allowed one complaint by a customer (who complained in the past in order to get free food) to be used in my termination. The customer was sat in a section that was not mine, I was not aware that this customer was to be waited on by me until she had been there almost 20 minutes. I did everything in my power to make her happy but she emailed the corporate office and got me fired!
Advice to Management: I understand that the hospitality business is all about pleasing the customer. With this being said, I do not believe that I should have lost my job due to one complaint that was from someone just trying to get a free meal.

Title: "Brinker International is great!"
Pros: Working for Brinker was a positive experience. This is a company that is focused on helping people reach their full potential.
Cons: Some Franchise locations are definitely not equal to Brinker's standards

Title: "Hostess"
Pros: Works with schedule, Usually have great co-workers
Cons: Too many managers, Managers are not held accountable

Title: "Typical Corporate"
Pros: Good Hours, ok managers, food is always changing, they tried incentive on the job stuff, but was just ok
Cons: managers never stayed for more than a year. There was too much pressure to make numbers.
Advice to Management: Stay at one store for longer than 6 months please!

Title: "Fun atmosphere"
Pros: Fun people, flexible schedule.
Cons: Late nights, working weekends.

Title: "Managing Partner"
Pros: Fun atmosphere, great menu innovation, technology advancements
Cons: Culture is not complete from top to bottom. Great mission but it gets lost in along the expectation chain
Advice to Management: Lot's of hard work but plenty of reward if you can make it happen

Title: "Chili's makes it happen!"
Pros: Make great money, enjoy the people
Cons: Long hours lots of holidays
Advice to Management: Be careful underscheduling employees

Title: "Bartender"
Pros: Scheduling and hours were Nice. Ability to transfer easily.
Cons: Constantly new management. Managers tend to show insane levels of favoritism
Advice to Management: Worry more about quality employees and less about friendships

Title: "Little Support from Upper Management"
Pros: Somewhat flexible schedule, free food on shift, health coverage, 401k.
Cons: Upper management doesn't support management at the store level, hours are long, unpredictable, and shifts are short-staffed to keep costs down.
Advice to Management: Treat your managers better and they'll stay longer.

Title: "Server"
Pros: Great training program. Good learning experience for life and work ethic. Very corporate as you would expect but the benefit is that teaches you the standard for serving if you are inexperienced.
Cons: Be prepared to move fast and like most restaurants you get some sucky guests. Can be demanding on your schedule when co workers want to drop shifts.
Advice to Management: My management team was supportive and awesome! I'm sure that varies but they were very professional and semi strict but also jokey and fun.

Title: "Server/Waitress"
Pros: You make good money for the most part.. On a really really good night you can make anywhere from 150-200. You get six table sections. I absolutely loved 2 of my managers, they were wonderful. There was another manager who was new, he was previously a server but he was another one that I loved, those 3 really really cared about me and I loved them too.
Cons:
Where do I start....
It depends on who's working in the kitchen to how your food comes out, if we had the wrong staff in the kitchen, my food would come out all messed up then I would look bad because 2 out of the 3 people sitting at my table's food came out incorrectly.
Too much running sidework, it wouldn't be such a big deal if we didn't have so many lazy people working because we don't schedule people based on the amount of side work they do, we schedule them based on their scores so the people with the highest scores get to stand around on their phone and not worry about side work or running food so it's always the same 3 people doing side work and running food and they never get called out for not doing anything because their ziosk scores are high, it's really ridiculous. And the people who are doing everything don't get noticed for it because their scores aren't high enough and their scores won't go up because their too busy doing all the side work for the people who's scores are high so it's just a ridiculous pattern.
And the hosts, not to mention the hosts... They don't check on the servers because they don't care if we're weeded, we have 6 table sections so if you get 6 tables at once, it's almost impossible to greet and make drinks for 6 tables at once so you pretty much just break down. And the managers don't say anything about the hosts doing this to us because as long as there's not a wait at the door, that's all that matters, it doesn't matter if they get horrible service or if their food takes 30-45 minutes to come out, as long as they're not standing at the door waiting, that's all that matters. Most of the time, the managers are helping the hosts sit us 6 times in a row then wonder why we're drowning.
We're a team based restaurant so we have a partner in the floor which is sometimes good but most of the time bad because if you have a partner like me who works hard, it gives you as my partner an excuse to go stare at the kitchen for your food and ask me to do a bunch of stuff for your tables or for you to go to the bathroom or smoke while I watch your tables.
We close an hour later than any other restaurant so the last hour, we get crapped on.
We also do a bunch of cheap cheap deals so we get all the bad tips. The average check is 20$ so 15% of 20$ does not add up to much at the end of the night, you wind up doing more work for less money so a 6 table section doesn't really make a difference.
The 3 managers that I talked about in the pros were awesome but there was one who constantly yelled at us and talked disrespectful to the people he didn't wanna screw or didn't hang out with. He was also the one that made the schedule so only his favorites got a good schedule, like this one girl who wasn't even a very good server and I constantly had to cover her butt because she couldn't handle more than 2 tables but because he wanted to screw her she got the schedule she wanted. I heard him constantly talk about screwing her
There was one time every body could hear this particular manager yelling all the way at the front of the restaurant at an employee, it was really unprofessional and he doesn't deserve to be a manager.
Advice to Management: Pay better attention to your servers who are doing all the side work, stop only paying attention to a score that doesn't make any difference. The score has nothing to do with your server, it's not based on attentivness, it's based on whether or not they wanna return to a restaurant that may or may not have been dirty or a restaurant that their food might have taken 40 minutes or maybe their food was sent out with something their server 86'd but because I didn't run their food, I didnt see that it had something it wasn't suppose to on it or they had a kid in the next booth screaming in their ears or base it on the fact that they couldn't get sat in a booth instead of a table or that the bartender took a year and a day to make their drinks or maybe the host just sat me with 5 other tables and I really just couldn't control the service I have them.. Not everything is based off of a score that doesn't mean anything about my serving ability. Pay more attention to who actually cares and who actually is a good server but is just stuck covering everybody else's butts and doing the work for them. Pay better attention to what is really going on and not just what YOU wanna think is going on because 9 times out of 10, you're wrong.

Title: "Decent job"
Pros: Good management and nice environment to work in.
Cons: Benefits aren't great and would like a better pay scale.

Title: "Server"
Pros: When you are on shift, you get 50% off food! Good training program and nice managers. Good sections as well.
Cons: Business tended to be kind of slow. And the business there was, most of the customers did not tip well.
Advice to Management: Cut servers when it gets closer to closing time, so that the closers can at least make more money.

Title: "Waitress"
Pros: Hours, money, location, food, people
Cons: waiting tables, working at night

Title: "Good"
Pros: Good learning experience, Solid training program and will teach you the fundamentals to succeed in the industry. overall good experience
Cons: Keep proven staff in the store they know. Bouncing around staff may seem like it gives the overall company better consistency but in turn focus on consistency in each store
Advice to Management: Continued education for management would help prevent managers from getting to comfortable and getting into bad habits. This also would help in keeping them motivated and drive sales

Title: "Become IRobot"
Pros: Leaving the job. Never eating their bagged poison again.
Cons: Starting the job and seeing how gross the food is...

Title: "Chili's"
Pros:
- Meals discounted during work hours
- Consistency in directions from the top down
- Location was excellent given my situation at the time
Cons:
- Not much leeway for individuality/innovation
- Employee suggestions did not seem to be taken seriously
- Quality of food was sometimes unnerving
Advice to Management: Be more open minded to suggestions from service staff. They are actually on the floor, interacting with customers and have a better idea of what customers want then they are given credit for.

Title: "Nice Home"
Pros: very nice quality of life the systems are easy to follow. It is very relaxed and has a family feel,
Cons: Even with very reasonable work hours you need to stay on the move to keep up and leave on time. Oh wait that is a good thing.

Title: "Area Director"
Pros: Strong Leadership, very technology driven, great culture
Cons: Unrealistic labor expectations. Too many initiatives

Title: "Flexible but somewhat uncaring"
Pros: The company is willing to work with whatever schedule you give them and will change your availability with a simple request. It is very easy to transfer to any location in the country give you great flexibility.
Cons: Employees are treating as completely replaceable. Upper management almost has a disdain for the hourly employees. No benefits to speak of.
Advice to Management: Recognize good employees. Make an attempt to keep these employees. Even lower management is treated as replaceable.

Title: "Hostess"
Pros: Fun, close-knit atmosphere, fast-paced, pretty standard restaurant job
Cons: Hostesses get leftover of servers' jobs and not treated very well

Title: "Meh"
Pros: Flexible schedules, above average wages, team Service oriented, feels like every employee is part of the family.
Cons: Tips suck. I worked at 2 different locations and each one had it's own draw backs. One was busy but the kitchen staff was not up to par so every shift there was a disaster. Which in turn depletes tips. The other was slow with an awesome bog. But no guests no tips.
Advice to Management: Quit relying on those surveys so much. People are always negative and never satisfied. You put to much emphasis on those scores rather than being involved and seeing what servers are actually doing

Title: "OVER-STAFFED!"
Pros: Great benefits (if they work you full-time for at least a year,) friendly co-workers, discounted employee meals (an hour before shift,) great pay, and uses a helpful tool called HotSchedules for scheduling, which allows you to check you schedule, talk with other workers to pick up or drop schedules.
Cons: They're so overstaffed that there are about 12 people in the host position, and at least ten managers. Since they were so overstaffed in the host position, they only scheduled me for, on average, 5 hours a day, and maybe two or three times a week if lucky. There are so many managers that none of them are on the same page. They had said they were going to fire me, but never had, though they thought they did. When I called to ask about scheduling it took them 40 minutes to finally get a manager on the phone, and even then they refused to talk to me. I had to call back in a few days, and waited about 30 minutes for them to not answer my question, and tell me I was supposedly fired. It took me 3 weeks to get a paycheck that one manager said should've been given to me about a week prior, that another manager said hadn't even came in yet.
Advice to Management: You might want to start answering phone calls, and get all of the managers on the same page.

Title: "Chili's made me great. But they let me go."
Pros: Leadership team really is invested in growth of restaurants and team members. Lots of unique training to help you create a better professional and personal career.
Cons: Leadership preaches all the time about great quality of life for the restaurant managers but there is zero follow up with it happening. Great quality of life doesn't really start until promotion beyond General Manager.

Title: "Lounge Server"
Pros: Working with a group of people that become like family. It is a great way to make extra cash when in the right location.
Cons: Horrible atmosphere when you have a GM that is only interested in numbers and stats. The balance and smoothness all depends on who's in charge at that location. Corporate has a lot of "quotas" to meet that are ridiculous for employees. For example, if you do not get a specific amount of customers to take the survey on their receipt, you get threatened of being demoted to "to go" or "hosting." Ridiculous that Corporate would hurt an employee based on what a paying customer decides to do once they leave the restaurant. Corporate is all about the numbers. Stick with a Chili's that has been franchised. Less greed.
Advice to Management: Corporate Chili's - stop basing your promotions on who sells the most margaritas and gets the most surveys because it is not fair when someone works 2 days vs someone who works 5. Common sense, less shifts, less margaritas. I should know, I was that person who worked 5.

Title: "Awesome place to work"
Pros: Fast paced, paid the day you work, relaxed management, free food
Cons: Long hours, customers always complain

Title: "Sever/bartender"
Pros: Flexible hours and easy money
Cons: Bad management and bad staff
Advice to Management: Don't beat your staff up over numbers

Title: "General Manager"
Pros: Some great people to work with.
Cons: Unrealistic labor goal expectations. Too may initiatives/changes multiple times/year.
Advice to Management: Support your staff. Hopefully they were put into the position because they are capable. If not, then replace.

Title: "It is okay if you are studying"
Pros: Very flexible schedule good tips
Cons: Managers are really mean and disrespectful

Title: "Hard, but get paid"
Pros: Busy. Money to be made.
Cons: Lots of ongoing sidework. Sometimes managers are rude.

Title: "Awesome company"
Pros: Team oriented, fun, great discount, awesome opportunity.
Cons: There really are none that I can think of.

Title: "Food server"
Pros: Take home money every night
Cons: No future in industry, dealing with bad clientele

Title: "Decent Place"
Pros: Flexible work schedules, fun atmosphere, quick cash.
Cons: Upper management looks at you as a number and stat and nothing more. May not be a fun atmosphere depending on your managers or other staff.
Advice to Management: Look at people more as people and not as much of a number or a stat based on some random secret data.

Title: "Hostess"
Pros: The management was very friendly and helpful
Cons: No busboys meant the restaurant was hectic/dirtier than average

Title: "Line Cook"
Pros: It a okay job that is very easy
Cons: Need better management and health benefits

Title: "Review"
Pros: Decent money, easy to adapt to
Cons: conflicts with staffing, long hours at times

Title: "Fun Place To Work"
Pros: Fun & Exciting Environment. You Get To Enjoy & Have A Good Time With The Customer's.
Cons: A Lot of Customer's Know How To Get Free Items And The Manager's Allow It, Even Though They Know The Customer Is Lying About Something On Their Order Being Incorrect Or Saying Their Food/Drinks Took Too Long. Also, The Manager's Aren't Always Kind/Thankful To The Staff.
Advice to Management: Listen To Your Employee's, They Are The One's Out On The Floor And Even The Back of The House Employee's As Well. Take Constructive Criticism From All The Employee's To Make The Work Environment Fun & Exciting So The Staff Wants To Go To Work Every Shift.

Title: "Fine tune your basic service skills into crafting a more personalized dinning experience for your guests."
Pros: The training is top notch! Various "modules" are geared towards supplying you with the tools you will need to make MORE money and create an all around better dinning experience for your guests! Good work ethic is NOT overlooked here at Chilis... Work your butt off every day and you will see doors open and better opportunities arise.
Cons: Chilis hires at an entry level for service positions. Sometimes it becomes a bit of a pain to sort through the hacks that just don't cut it out on the floor.
Advice to Management: Utilize the awesome training better! Help the trainers identify the true gems hidden in the extremely large and extremely intimidating Training Binder.

Title: "n/a"
Pros: awesome team to work with.
Cons: really nothing bad about it, just do your job and you will be good.

Title: "Dish washer"
Pros: Free food, good workers, and a positive attitude.
Cons: No breaks, 63 hours week, working every night, no time to eat the free meal.
Advice to Management: No comments

Title: "Pays the bills"
Pros: Great place to make friends, and to learn the do's and don't's of customer service. If you can take a lot of tables, the pay is also decent.
Cons: Management doesn't care, and that attitude is also reflected upon the other employees. You must work late nights and weekends in order to make great money. The employees are also scored daily by customers with questions that have nothing to do with the servers service. These scores can determine how many tables a server is permitted to have. For example, one question the survey asks customers to rate the quality of food.
Advice to Management: Listen to the suggestions of employees. Make them feel valued, and at the very least attempt to make it look like you actually care. If you don't, then neither will anyone else....

Title: "Great place of employment"
Pros: Enjoy everyone that works there
Cons: Restaurant stress but nothing else
Advice to Management: Keep up the good work

Title: "Good Job for students"
Pros:
50% discount on food; made it easy to grab lunch on a shift and treat friends to a nice dinner.
Tips!!
Cons:
Local management was horrible... It's pretty much a peeing contest. Got old pretty quick.
Location & culture of this restaurant meant hard customers from Mexicali that wouldn't tip at all or leave $2 tip, no matter the party size.
Advice to Management: Grow up, be professional and take care of your employees. Most of them are young adults trying to put themselves through college, don't make it so difficult to accommodate school schedule every quarter.

Title: "Other Places Do The Same Thing Better"
Pros:
Flexible Schedule
Lots of opportunity to advance
Cons:
Unreliable Hours
No Quality Benefits
Too much sidework
Unhappy Environment
Terrible Management
Managers Pick Favorites
High Turnover Rate
Too Many Doubles
NO TEAMWORK
Horribly disorganized
Advice to Management: Everything about the way you run your business is a joke. Give incentives for people to stay employeed at your company long term. Increasing your bottom line will actually increase your top line way more then you think. Having more servers on a night will allow those servers to give BETTER service bringing more business. Instead of 1 person doing a job for 3 people, have 3 people do the job of 1 person so that the 3 people can do the job better. It's impossible to give service that will make people want to come back for more if the server has 8 tables at once and has to cut corners because the kitchen is taking 45 minutes on appetizers. If you want more advice you can email me. Always happy to help.

Title: "Great High School Job"
Pros: Chiliheads are like family and the discount is great
Cons: Low pay, rude customers can be frustrating

Title: "Host/Silverware Roller"
Pros: All of my co-workers were super friendly and welcoming. They also do a lot of work with St. Jude's Children's Hospital!
Cons: I would be scheduled for Host shifts and end up spending my whole sorting dirty silverware instead.

Title: "Chili's ToGo/Host/QA"
Pros: The discounted food is pretty great, and depending on which store you're at you may make friends for life. People tend to be like family there.
Cons: I had this job in college and could never afford to pay all bills on my own even though I was working full time.
Advice to Management: Be aware of each employee's individual situation. If you're not giving them the hours they need to support themselves or their families, then you're basically a terrible person.

Title: "manager"
Pros: great customers, great employees, would of loved to stay but relocated to a different area. It was a fun loving place, especially all of the local customers.
Cons: No cons what so ever! I would love to own my own Chilis because when management is not paying attention, things start to get out of hand.

Title: "So- so"
Pros: Nothing good to say at all.
Cons:
The management team sucks (only one good manager there)
Server staff suck at teamwork and are selfish
Advice to Management:
Stop cutting servers so early
Be professional and stop having favorites
Schedules need to come out a month in advance (stop waiting the last minute)

Title: "Everything"
Pros: Team members who are bought in to the old chilihead way create a great atmosphere. the schedule can be flexible to fit your needs.
Cons: Freeze on wages for all hourly employees for over 3 years. No reviews or raises in 4 years. Do not count on years on the job, performance or willingness to work making a difference in your schedule. What you make on your hire date will probably be the same wage you make in 4 years no matter what you do.
Advice to Management: Please take care of the people who take care of you. Just because someone is willing to do whatever it takes does not mean they deserve to get less.

Title: "Decent Place Start Working"
Pros: Good use of technology like Hot Schedules to pick up and give away shifts. Easy to work with schedule wise. Never had a problem with Managers working with me to help cover a shift.
Cons: WAY TOO MUCH SIDE WORK. Side work averages 30 - 45 minutes to complete. Other restaurants might have 5 minutes of side work. Shifts are way too long as well. If you're in a closing section you'll be there for 7-8 hours versus other restaurants being 4-6 . Clientele is average too 6- 8 buck tips are as good as it gets.

Title: "F"
Pros: Great place to work at
Cons: Need more hours on schedule
Advice to Management: Give more hours to employees

Title: "Review"
Pros: Great place to work, friendly staff
Cons: Management and dishwashing equipment in Utah needed help

Title: "benefits"
Pros: There are benefits available. Like anything else in life there is red tape to go through but if you consistently pursue it it's worth it. 401k is the best benefit offered.
Cons: The health insurance benefits that are made available to you are not worth the money you pay for them. What is covered and the dollar amount are not worth it if you sit down and do the math and research
Advice to Management: Communicate within management and employees. Get everyone on the same page and be consistent on rules expectations and consequences.

Title: "Horrible"
Pros: It's actually pretty great despite my title and everyone should try and apply there because the food is just amazing
Cons: I'm totally kidding about the food being amazing because honestly it's not that great and I would never work there again
Advice to Management: Hey you guys need to stop acting like you're so much better than everyone else that works there because we're practically on the same level and I will not be treated as a lesser

Title: "Hostess"
Pros: excellent management and meal discounts
Cons: not enough hours for me

Title: "Great Company"
Pros: Had great atmosphere and many opportunities for income growth! Benefits were great and leadership was very understanding.
Cons: You have to be very disciplined and driven to take the opportunities and something from nothing. Have to be willing to dedicate a lot of hours upfront so having a family is challenging.
Advice to Management: Important to focus on the people aspect CONSISTENTLY to continue to excel forward. Culture and outlook is great but size can be a limiting factor to growth opportunities.

Title: "Line Cook"
Pros: The best part of working at Chillis is having future benefits like earning a scholarship.
Cons: The only thing that i wont enjoy is wearing jeans in the kitchen because the material is thick.
Advice to Management: Are we allowed to wear black dickies? That would be a good idea i think.

Title: "Horrible"
Pros: Convenient location, well-known company, easy to get hired
Cons: Long hours and manager is basically a line cook to save on labor costs. Avoid.

Title: "Many interior management problems with gm"
Pros:
When the
Money is good it's wonderful
Cons: A gm who doesn't care for his job who by default became a gm because another manager got fired.Puts the workload on the other management is seen doing little or no work almost always will disappear into the office at busy times and not answer the door, doesn't care how employees feel violated the personal rights of employees doesn't care about people's needs as workers says they need to work for it even when there's evidence that they have done their job, unfair favoritism
Advice to Management: Get a new gm who likes his job does it and generally wants to care for chili heads also

Title: "A good first job"
Pros: Easy money for the work you are doing. Flexible scheduling
Cons: The pay is okay but only if you are on the top and closing a lot. It can fluctuate with the season also as summer months are not as busy.
Advice to Management: I know every restaurant is different and the employees are also. But being open to ideas from everyone would benefit

Title: "Great place to work"
Pros: Great team, excellent leadership and integrity. Solid training provided with plenty of room for growth. Adequate resources to get the expected results. There are high expectations but the goals are reasonable and achievable
Cons: Like most restaurant jobs there can be long hours and closing shifts can keep you till 1 or 2 in the morning.
Advice to Management: I feel the leadership team has not only the interest of the business and profitability in mind but also genuinely care about the welfare of their managers and the chiliheads. Keep that philosophy as happy employees make for profitable restaurants

Title: "Server"
Pros: Great Co workers. On some nights you make really great money. Flexible. Real team effort by everybody. Plenty of opportunity to work your way up.
Cons: Sometimes its slow and our General Manager has driven several employees out of working due to her poor attitude and constant negativity. Then, when she is told this, the positivity comes out so forced that everybody knows she is only saying whats needed to be said if anything were to threaten her job.
Advice to Management: Get a new GM and make everyone happy. Otherwise it is a great working environment.

Title: "Kitchen Manager"
Pros: Good benefits, 3%match dollar by dollar, 50 cents on a dollar from 4 to 5%, great bonus program,
Cons: Too many rollouts, revised menu, Chili's is not the same anymore, different target market,
Advice to Management: Pay more attention to your staff. ADs spend more time at your restaurants instead of sitting on your butt at home.

Title: "Unfair"
Pros: Free meal for all cooks
Cons: Management need to be focus on they employees, many of them show up to get a check ,but they don't work for it
Advice to Management: is ridiculous that newly hired people come and know they earn the same or more than you, you already have several years in the company

Title: "great company"
Pros: excellent pay, fun fast paced environment, lots of hours
Cons: hard to get time off, rude customers

Title: "Salary"
Pros: The salary and benefits are good.
Cons: Labor expectations are extremely difficult to reach. Managers are constantly helping in hourly functions to get to labor expectations.
Advice to Management: Listen to your leaders in your restaurants.

Title: "Best place I ever worked all around"
Pros: Great understanding competent managers pleasant team mates who believe in the brand
Cons: Alot of side work and stressful busy money filled days!!
Advice to Management: Keep it up

Title: "College Student"
Pros: Tuition help, flexible schedule, and the willingness to help with whatever comes up. During finals, I get the time off to study and during summer I work more than usual.
Cons: Late hours, not always but sometimes they are very late. Also there is a lot of physical labor that can be demanding.
Advice to Management: Help as much as possible, try to get engaged with the servers and staff not just sit in the office or appear during problems.

Title: "A Great Experience"
Pros: Friendly staff, fast pace , a lot of hours
Cons: everything just seems right on the money
Advice to Management: keep up the good work

Title: "Have not received a raise in 2 years"
Pros: Great benefits, but only if your restaurant allows you to keep your hours above 32 a pay period. In some places this isn't possible. For servers not trying to support a family it's a great place to work. For everyone else it's not.
Cons: The food quality is horrible, the restaurants are all dirty once you make it to the kitchen, there isn't any cohesion between management (after all I have seen three entire management staffing changes in the 3 years I've been there), and after learning every position in the back of the house I still haven't received the raise I was promised. This may have to do with the 56.5 million dollar class action lawsuit that the company was hit with, that they decided to shove the loss down our throats.
Advice to Management: Don't promise someone something you cant deliver on, and if you make a mistake in corporate decision making, don't dock us positions and wage increases because of your mistake.

Title: "Meh"
Pros: Meet good friends, some management is ok
Cons: Focus too much on ziosk scores and not enough on actual server ability and skill. Punishes by cutting much needed hours and shifts down to next to nothing. "Promotes" unfairly to not so deserving employees while casting aside those who do deserve. Favoritism very much a factor.
Advice to Management: Focus more on server ability and work ethic. Look at scores as a whole, and recognize the issues and understand that more often than not its a food quality, or restaurant itself issue and not the server themselves.

Title: "fast pace. a lot of work"
Pros: fun atmosphere. laid back. set your own pay
Cons: wait on people. favoritism. seniority. no room for growth

Title: "A great place to work"
Pros: Chili's is has a fast paced and rewarding environment. Working for Chili's is a great way to grow alongside friendly people and responsible management.
Cons: The pace can be somewhat overwhelming. Some days feel as if they will never end and the competitive environment can sometimes amplify those feelings.
Advice to Management: In my experience, management has always been very helpful. I would recommend running courses on social skills for wait staff.

Title: "blah"
Pros: good hours. stable employment. good mid level management.
Cons: no cross training boh to foh

Title: "Manager"
Pros: Active job, lots of people interaction, flexible schedule, opportunity for advancement w/ in restaurant
Cons: Late nights, long hours, inconsistent/ unreliable co-workers, hard to move from operations to corporate, drama
Advice to Management: Hold everyone to the same standard from day 1.

Title: "Chili's Grill and Bar"
Pros: I enjoyed the family atmosphere of working with my colleagues. I enjoyed meeting all the different people. Managers were very helpful and encouraging.
Cons: Tips sometimes suck, especially on Sundays.
Advice to Management: They managers could grow up a little bit, and handle situation with other Chili heads better.

Title: "Chilis"
Pros: Competitive pay with the area
Cons: Un organized at the top

Title: "chilis hates servers"
Pros: I don't really have anything positive to say about the company I work for. Mangers won't talk to tables when problems come. They tend to hide in the office area and play Pok√©mon go.
Cons: Mangers don't care about employees, they care about the labor hours.
Advice to Management: Get another job, or take some classes on what management does.

Title: "Managers"
Pros: Senior management mostly easy to deal with. The type that if you're doing your job, doing it well, and striving to improve always, will have your back.
Cons: Hours are very high, stress very high - like any restaurant. Salary is not the greatest; one has to be able to put pressure on senior management to get decent performance based increases.

Title: "Hostess"
Pros: We had decent hours for high school students and management was flexible. Ability to trade shifts was a plus.
Cons: Tend to go on long waits with no support from other staff
Advice to Management: None

Title: "Forever a Chilihead"
Pros: Competitive pay, great team building, support and opportunity for advancement
Cons: employee expectations set extremely high, not always the best support from management
Advice to Management: Remember to reach out to team members occasionally for more feedback instead of during the yearly MEE surveys.

Title: "Fun at times, stressful the rest of the time"
Pros: get to eat for free while working. Some people are cool to work with
Cons: high turnover rate. pay is inadequate for the stress
Advice to Management: help out your subordinates when you can. Give raises to employees who are loyal and do well when they ask for them, not six months down the road or when they try to leave for a better job, by then it is too late.

Title: "Server"
Pros: Great teamwork and helpful management
Cons: Needs to be more staff

Title: "It's very stressing at times"
Pros: You get a free burger at end of shift and the pay isn't bad at all. Time fly real fast wich is a good thing
Cons: It gets very buisy. And the managers expect the job too get done with 3 cooks on a Friday and some times Saturday's
Advice to Management: You should try too respect the cooks that been there for a long time. It seemed it was always bout the money but f the cooks. That isn't right.

Title: "It was average work, but it does get stressful."
Pros: Understanding staff/management. They were always eager to help with any problems you had going on at work or at home.
Cons: Not flexible, sometimes they're really hard on you about things. Have to hit a certain goal each week. some staff members were disrespectful

Title: "Great people, great benefits"
Pros: Great people, great benefits, great staff
Cons: None that i can think of at the momement
Advice to Management: Keep doing what your doing!

Title: "Do yourself a favor and don't work here"
Pros: Easy to get days off you need
Cons: coworkers who have been there longer will automatically boss you around and dishes are always dirty
Advice to Management: Stop letting co workers boss other co workers around its not right!

Title: "Great Benefits!"
Pros: Chili's has a lot of perks and discounts such as 50% off meals up to 4 people at Chili's or Maggiano's, discounts on hotels, car rentals, and cell phone plans.
Cons: Management could've been better, my store particularly. The company itsself will take great care of you.

Title: "Not so great..."
Pros:
- 50% off food
- Most of the time you work with great people
- Make decent money
Cons:
- Some management is not so good
- ITR (Intent To Return question on surveys) is the most important thing that will knock out good servers if it's not at the level the management wants
- Dealing with ridiculous complaints and difficult guests a lot of the time
Advice to Management: Get rid of ITR or stop making it so important, because you're losing good servers over a stupid question.

Title: "Fun place to work"
Pros: Flexible hours, benefits for part-time employees, fun atmosphere
Cons: Managers were not all on the same page. Some would help on shifts when we would get backed up, others would hide in the office and do nothing.
Advice to Management: Be a part of the team. We are all in this together.

Title: "Server"
Pros: Great money and very flexible.
Cons: Gets overwhelming if you cant handle the volume.
Advice to Management: N/a

Title: "Stress full jobs"
Pros: great staff made good friends
Cons: weak salary pay for commented time.
Advice to Management: be there more then you staff is.

Title: "Why ive stuck with Chili's"
Pros: Working at Chili's Grill & Bar it's fun and it is a pretty relaxed environment to work in. It is a casual dining restaurant so it is not overly stressful.
Cons: THEY ARE VERY FOCUSED ON THE SCORES THEY RECEIVE FROM CUSTOMER WHO FILL OUT SURVEYS ON THE ZIOSK AND THEY HAVE FOOD SELLING COMPETITIONS YOU MUST COMPETE IN.
Advice to Management: Be more friendly to your staff we will be more motivated to work hard when you are nice, fun, and cool with us; compared to if you yell at us to do something that'll just make us not want to do it. Treat us as your equals and we will work hard and be grateful.

Title: "Line cook"
Pros: The people I work with and the granted hours. Being able to enjoy working almost everyday
Cons: Under staffed, some stuff are super lazy and you are expected to pick up the work. But we get through and make the best of it
Advice to Management: Keep up the good work

Title: "Server"
Pros: Very flexible, if you work hard you can make upwards of 500-1000 a month.
Cons: Pay isn't reliable. You're depending on people's tips .

Title: "Kitchen Manager"
Pros: Steady Pace,Easily Promoted, Nice environment
Cons: 70 hour work week, high turnover
Advice to Management: Keep promoting from within

Title: "Bartender / Server"
Pros: Amazing working staff that felt like a family. Opportunity to build relationships, make impressions daily & have freedom.
Cons: There wasn't growth in the company for me.

Title: "Sr GM"
Pros: Great compensation, great peers, fun environment
Cons: labor constraints, manager shortages, work life balance

Title: "Great Opportunity to make money same day"
Pros:
Make money same day
Team Work style
Cons:
Standing all day
¬†Nothing else comes to mind
Advice to Management: None

Title: "Waiter"
Pros: Relaxed environment and dress code isn't bad
Cons: Becoming less about the employees and more about saving money and profits

Title: "Like any other chain"
Pros: The people were fun to work with. The night goes fast. The tips
Cons: Management sucks, constantly pushing servers to up sell every dumb promos, kitchen crashes and burns every rush
Advice to Management: Stop being so useless

Title: "Very Coorporate"
Pros: Systems are put together incredibly well
Cons: Management is a work in progress, Kitchen set up needs to be a work in progress but unfortunately things are not being changed.
Advice to Management: be leaders not micromanagers. In the food service industry there is nothing less helpful than a manager with empty hands saying "full hands out of dish" especially knowing not a single thing about what we are doing in the moment. If you do not want to participate in the servers job title anymore than do not manage in food service. You should still feel the need to take on the same duties as servers as a manager if the servers need help. STOP THE MICROMANAGEMENT!!

Title: "Pretty good college job"
Pros:
Good money
Good people
Short hours
50 percent employee discount
Cons:
Too much sidework
Stressful job
Tip dependant
Advice to Management: Lessen sidework

Title: "Great Place"
Pros: Management is awesome and very accommodating
Cons: Have to work nights, weekends, and holidays

Title: "Former ToGo Specialist"

Title: "Fun job but hard work"

Fast paced work environment
Lots of room to grow
Fun place to work
Multitasking and problem solving is an everyday thing

Restaurant work is hard
Time consuming, long hours, work weekends and holidays

Title: "Addison Chili's"
Pros: The servers that have been there make it worth working there and make you want to come back. They are the ones who support you through your shifts. Great bartenders and cook staff as well. You can get good hours and full benefits.
Cons: The GM doesn't have the employees backs. Many employees don't show up or come in late with no repercussions. Diners don't tip well regardless of how well you serve, and on a weekend night, you're lucky to make a bill. You're often stuck rolling silverware and doing work for the closers while only making the $2.13 an hour while not on the floor. There is a high turnover rate at this location.

Title: "horrible."
Pros: managers were very helpful and did all they could do in helping workers with their complaints also provided great customer service.
Cons: some workers didn't provide positive work environment and didn't treat other workers with respect. also managers didn't help hostess with their complaints.
Advice to Management: listen more to workers.

Title: "Okay, if you want to work for your money"
Pros: Chili's had great people to work with, you were able to become great friends with all other people that worked their. They also had pretty flexible schedules as long as you told them ahead of time.
Cons: People can get pretty angry when working in this setting especially when it's really busy. i did cry a couple of times from really rude customers. But, the managers usually understand and people help out.
Advice to Management: Be nicer. Your employees are trying their best.

Title: "Server"
Pros: Flexible hours, relaxed environment, and relaxed dress code.
Cons: Alot of favoritism, difficult and cheap guest, not worth the money.
Advice to Management: Be more organized and take care of guest.

Title: "Poor management at quarry location"
Pros: Plenty of business, good tips

Poor and unprofessional management
Lots of kitchen mistakes

Title: "Great place"
Pros: Great place to work for flexibility, quick money, and a fun happy environment. Co workers are helpful and teamwork is a priority and you work in teams for a section. You make great money. Great food and drinks.
Cons: Work long hours. Low priced menu items and lots of promotions that lowers the tip amount from customers. Large parties are not required to tip, so it is common to make no tip on larger parties. Sections can sometimes be overwhelming, therefore being weeded is common.
Advice to Management: I believe management needs to be more cohesive when deciding on new policies. Overall, management is great. Even cooperate managers have a major presence within our local chilies

Title: "Linecook"
Pros: 401k is very good
Cons: Cut hours as they feel like
Advice to Management: Value workers regardless of culture

Title: "Great location"
Pros: Always busy, Good teamwork, and Great tips. Not much competition and in a very heavily trafficked area. Plenty of hours.
Cons: Just normal being tired at end of long shift. Busy is stressful but rewarding at the end of the shift.

Title: "Server , Trainer"
Pros: Fast cash, dealing with loads of customers, flexible hours
Cons: Managment doesn't care about you, you're basically a servant.

Title: "A great place to start off. Former Server"
Pros: The employees and the managers are very kind and understanding. You really feel like you're part of a big family. The pay varies, but you can make a decent amount of money here if you're young and just starting out. The customers usually tip well, and have a positive attitude for the most part.
Cons: The pay isn't consistent. There are very dry days, sometimes dry weeks. So a second job may be mandatory. The customers can be cruel depending on location, and management doesn't really do much to assist you in those situations. Co workers can do some pretty unsavory things to get more money than you, since it is a competitive job. Hours aren't consistent, and the high turnover rate does affect the work load.

Title: "Erj Dining Worst job ever!!"
Pros: Great pay and benefits. But you pay the price with integrity
Cons: Company does not follow its own rules and policies. Poor leadership and inconsistant management create work environment. Constant turnover of employees because of poor treatment.
Advice to Management: Start running the operation with integrity. Dont have rules and policies on the books that you have no intention of following or enforcing. Be open to new ideas and change.

Title: "Good place"
Pros: Great place to work, fun and good food
Cons: No bad words I enjoyed every bit of it
Advice to Management: Keep up the good work

Title: "Server"
Pros:
The other members of the staff that stick around for longer than a couple months are really a joy to work with.
Not much else...
Cons:
60-70% turnover rate for FOH Staff, constantly hires alcoholics and drug addicts
Management team does not seem to care about anyone, very unprofessional with employees
Office politics are strong at this place, favorites exist and get all the best shifts
Cooks seem to be immune to being let go / fired
Food quality is extremely inconsistent
Advice to Management: Get a grip, focus on consistency, reward long time staff members

Title: "Work Work"
Pros: Once you go through a few moths and move your way out of the "big top" area you can actually start to make more money.
Cons: Unfriendly guests, entitled people, staff really just doesnt care, management really doesnt care about staff.

Title: "asst mgr"
Pros: good company - good people
Cons: long hours - be ready for the bar "seen"
Advice to Management: keep up the good work - don't let technology stop you from touching tables

Title: "General Manager"
Pros: Upper level management are very friendly and very professional.
Cons: None that I see so far.
Advice to Management: Keep up the great work

Title: "Chilis firewheel"

Advice to Management: Get it together!

Title: "Line cook"
Pros: Great people good food free food soo busy didnt see time flying

Title: "Server"
Pros: Very flexible with your schedule, fun staff, half discount for employees with employee card, and great for people who can't stay still. The company is friendly when it comes to transfers around the world and encourages growth with in the company.

Depending on the location, an employee can make a good amount of tips but that amount will be coming from flipping your tables. Employees need a pay raise. If you are looking to move up into corporate, you better be ready to move to Texas.
Advice to Management: Better communication from management needs to be implemented and individual goal setting needs to be established in the restaurant.

Title: "It sucks"
Pros: Well the pay isn't terrible and the chips are banging.
Cons: Upper management cares not a bit about the guest experience...only profit. Herd them in, herd them out and brand them with a chili pepper on the way out.
Advice to Management: Your greatest asset is your people. Norman Brinker believed in this....it's time Wyman and Kelly did too.

Title: "Dish washing the good the bad and the ugly"

Cons: No actual breaks you have to eat as you work and work environment can be heavy at peak days and peak hours.
Advice to Management: Train your dishwashers properly and have at least two to help reduce turn over rates.

Title: "Bartender"
Pros: Good tips at the aeroport
Cons: Management sucks and H.R sucked big time

Title: "Indifferent"
Pros: The pay can be great at times, love my coworkers, not too strict
Cons: The pay can be terrible at times, the guests treat you like a slave

Title: "Server"

Flexible work schedule
Quick money
Can make your own schedule

Management is not very consistent and lacks communication
Depending on location clientele is not great at tippinf

Title: "General manager"

Title: "it is okay"

Advice to Management: do not act like you are a god and teach your teammates corporate rules better

Title: "Worst Place I've Ever Worked At"
Pros: Leaving at the end of my shift is the one and only highlight of the day. The only other pros are my days off. Sign up for the 401k so that you have money for when you quit. You'll be glad you did.
Cons: Low pay. Idiotic and extremely lazy coworkers. Extremely lazy management. NO paid vacation for full time hourly employees. Instead of a paid vacation you get a lousy $250 yearly bonus which is about $160 after taxes.
Advice to Management: Employees are human beings. Treat them as such. Everyone knows the reason people go into management is so they can make more money and do less work but at least try not to make it so obvious. Lead by example.

Title: "Restaurant Manager"
Pros: Great benefits and good money
Cons: The hours are long, extreme workload unbalanced work/home life
Advice to Management: Focus more on the well being of your team members and they will take care of you

Title: "Server"
Pros: good tips, good management, and good work life
Cons: bad hours and the manager doesn't know what they're doing
Advice to Management: more experience

Title: "Server/ Trainer"
Pros:
- Best communication between staff and management I've found at any serving job.
- Supportive of whatever your personal goals are and try best to accommodate.
- Schedule is decently flexible with requesting off as long as you give enough notice
- Servers are very willing to assist those with questions
Cons:

-high turn over rate due to job itself

Title: "Servers have too many responsibilities. you'll make tons of money. It's not worth the stress sometimes."

-Free soda
-Meeting new people

-No scheduled breaks
-Hardly any hours

-Servers whine and complain on how you seat them
-Bussing tables all day every day cause some servers get lazy
-Go home smelling like a burnt toast
-Unsanitary conditions

Title: "good atmosphere"

generally well tipped
other waiters and staff were friendly
constantly meeting new people (customers)
sometimes received free food or discounts
Cons:
management was sloppy
last minute schedule changes occurred frequently
generally disorganized behind the scenes environment
always had to be in a great mood which can be very tiring

Title: "Cook/key holder"
Pros: Good place to work
Cons: Do more for kitchen employees

Title: "Server/Bartender"

Title: "Server at chilis"

Good atmosphere
Great friends
Managers were really nice and understanding
Cons:
Long hours
Low tips at times
Stressful
Advice to Management: Management was great. Very few things to gripe about, only problem was being forced to work some shifts that were really difficult for my schedule.

Pros: The managers always treated the employees well and luckily I was in a restaurant with a relatively polite and respectful customer base.
Cons: Its a corporate restaurant so everything is extremely regulated and there is no room for interpretation. Also if a customer gets irritated they have unlimited resources to vent which has cost people their jobs before over nothing.
Advice to Management: Be more personable with the employees and stop acting like every small problem is the end of the world.

Title: "Waitress"
Pros: Very good money in short time
Cons: Must have patience with guests

Title: "Prep Cook/Trainer"
Pros: They are more than willing to help work around a schedule. The rest of the team members can be very friendly and helpful. There was also supposed to be a regular review schedule, I had 1 in over 5 years of service. What a joke!
Cons: The company took away paid vacation time from the full-time employee base. They did this when times were tough and never gave it back. They will often try to put things as though they are helping you when they are really hurting.
Advice to Management: Give back more to those that are at the base of this company. Bring back paid vacation time for Full-TIme workers and institute mandatory reviews by managers every 6 months.

Title: "Average"
Pros: Easy system to learn as a server
Cons: Make very little in hourly wages

Title: "I loved working here."
Pros: They work with your schedule, they are very understanding about circumstances that arise. It was a fun and fast paced environment.
Cons: The kitchen was very small, so you were always running into people. Other than that I don't really think it had any cons.

Title: "Server"
Pros: friendly environment, fun, good pay
Cons: long hours, lots of lifting

Title: "Chili's Fry Cook"
Pros: Get to make delicious food and also get free food as long as it is accounted for.
Cons: Potential to get burned since you are working with a fryer. Cleaning and detailing the fryer can also be dangerous and is not very fun to do, but overall it was an alright job.
Advice to Management: Some of the managers here make inappropriate remarks to the employees that are way out of line. The management will give you a lot of chances to do the job right but I personally did not like the way they handled certain aspects of the business and how they talked to their employees. From experience though this tends to be true in many restaurants, not just Chili's.

Title: "Good Culture with lack of true purpose (at least no-one knows it)"
Pros: A great culture with a true family feel. There is a hazing period for you to make it so get ready. You have to do your time and impress.
Cons: Leadership is seemingly engaged but doesn't listen and is disconnected with the most important people in the business- the Team Members.
Advice to Management: Listen to your team members in an honest way and put egos aside. Slow down and focus on the basics of the casual dining business.

Title: "Chili's"
Pros: Working at Chilis teaches you how to work with different personalities and to think on your toes. Every person should work in the service industry
Cons: The hours at Chilis are not as consistent and can be very unpredictable. Depending on your position, you wear many hats.
Advice to Management: My advice for management would be to apply a more hands on approach in correcting the issues presented in running the restaurants.

Title: "Bartender"
Pros: Great atmosphere. The clientele is always very kind. Great flexibility and great money. It's always fun going in to work .
Cons: They make you say do certain things that do not add to the guests experience in my opinion. They are not too bad though

Title: "Bartending for corporate"
Pros: Flexible schedule for students, management (mine atleast) treat me very well.
Cons: Chilis in general experiments stupid ways to run the restaurant. Won't include gratuities in big parties and where I am (ghetto area), people do not tip. The way they want thing done makes no sense, food choices just cause further delays meals getting out, it is very frustrating when you work your butt off. Best part, you only get paid $2 an hour. If people don't tip, you work for free.

Title: "Burgers and beer"
Pros: Easy cash, simple drinks, great regulars, flexible scheduling
Cons: Awful upper management, as far as area directors go and some in store managers. Corporate puts too much weight on the ziosk surveys and have unrealistic expectations for the team as a whole.
Advice to Management: Get a back bone and stand up to your bosses so you can be more effective with your team members

Title: "Server Trainer"
Pros: Awesome environment to work in and great money!
Cons: The kitchen staff is moody and tempermental at times. Very hard to work with when they are like this. My current location has been through 4 GMs in a short-time of a year.
Advice to Management: Managers don't stay for too long. If you want a job in management you better buddy up to the area director.

Title: "Erj dining looks like a good company to work for. Looks..."
Pros: Pay, insurance. Quality of hours worked. After hours events held for management staff. Close to home for most. HR Department works with you nice.
Cons: Upper management is too stuck on themselves and always trying to change things that work. Always trying to make the job harder with nonsense projects, ect. Never know what's going on in the restaurants but always want to tell you how to do things without being there.
Advice to Management: Get with the game or your restaurants will fail!

Title: "Good over all"
Pros: Great way to start earning money
Cons: They should think more on their employees.
Advice to Management: Need more leaders and not managers.

Title: "Bartender"
Pros: Great part-time work while in school.
Cons: Corporate requires certain pitches to be said at every table. Can feel kind of fake and forced.

Title: "Worked as a Server"
Pros: Chili's was a great place to be a server, because it is well known and there were always customers. Management seemed bitter, but that is common in most restaurants.
Cons: Because of the price range, some of the clientele did not tip well. There is a clear line between FOH and BOH staff and oftentimes that makes it difficult for servers to work.
Advice to Management: Let servers do what they do best. They are the face of the company and should be kept happy.

Title: "Me"
Pros: It's a great atmosphere here.
Cons: The customers can be difficult at time.
Advice to Management: Your doing a good job good luck.

Title: "Dishwasher and night cleaner"
Pros: I get to listen to my own music as long as I can hear everyone else and enjoy the other cooks attitudes
Cons: Some of the servers don't care about my organized table and will out plates anywhere they want to
Advice to Management: Let the servers know that the dishwashers like to keep their table organized

Title: "Casual Dining at it's finest"
Pros: Casual Dining at it's finest, it's pretty easy to get the hang of it and start making some money. Fast-paced environment where time flies by during the busier hours. After 6 months, you get a 50% discount card available for all Brinker positions. It's often easy to get a shift covered or pick up an extra one.
Cons: In a place so socially connected, drama is quick to sprout up at any moment. It is a high-stress position and requires someone who can keep their cool during the rush.
Advice to Management: Set up contests or fun activities that joins Front of House/Heart of House. The disconnect between the two can become hostile, so it's important to keep up the morale of both sides of the QA line. I suggest a game with the following: Pairing up each FoH member with a HoH member, and setting up individual goals for them to reach to gain points that fits their job discription. Ex. Have a FoH member sell a particular item on the menu that the HoH is in charge of making and if it is made to the QA's specifications, that team gets a point. Give chili's gear as prizes, or go to a dollar store and bring in some candy, something to motivate your workforce. Activities like this breaks up the monotony, strengthens the bond between FoH/HoH, and lowers the hostility that can occur during the stress hours.

Title: "Line Cook"
Pros: Awesome coworkers, fast paced, easy dishes to prepare
Cons: Can get overwhelmed with orders during a rush. If you fall behind during this, it is very hard to work yourself out. Some cooks were very rude.
Advice to Management: Try to eliminate cooks with poor attitudes and servers that mess up consistently.

Title: "no life, professional apologizer"
Pros: Great team members to work with. benefits and insurance decent.
Cons: no work life balance, change menu every couple weeks, labor restrictions make it impossible to deliver good results to guests,
Advice to Management: get rid of BRG, actually embrace your core values like, feedback is priceless. develop a work life balance for managers. stop changing menu every quarter.

Title: "Not worth the money"
Pros: I made good money and the other people working there were pleasant and helpful for the most part. Some of the managers were also helpful.
Cons: Always understaffed and ill equipped to handle the volume of guests. Upper management continued to set goals that were completely off basis to how the restaurant was run. For example servers could get fired or demoted based off the survey's that were on the ziosks. Even though it was a small amount of people who took the survey and a small amount of people who payed through the ziosk. This is completely whack according to the scientific method.
Advice to Management: Actually be in tune to what is happening on the company. Also don't always put the blame on the servers. sERVING AT CHILIS IS THE WORST BECAUSE YOU HAVE NO RUNNERS OR BUSSERS YOU DO IT ALL ON YOUR OWN.There is no one refilling ice in the back, there's no one make desserts or soup, there's no one wiping your tables.

Title: "Eh."
Pros: Easy job, decent pay, can get really busy so it makes time go by quickly.
Cons: Deal with cranky people and it gets exhausting, too many whiny servers.
Advice to Management: Be more involved.

Title: "Okay"
Pros: Good staff, decent money, not bad serving job
Cons: very unorganized, need more positive reinforcement

Title: "Bartender"
Pros: Busy store, fun environment ,can make good money if building regulars. It may take time, but worth it. Chili's offers anniversary gift bonus and full time health insurance at 30hrs.
Cons: Menu changes every 3months. The % of tip out for the service well could be higher, high turn over for managers. There is a feeling of just being a number.
Advice to Management: Just have a human element toward your subbordnits. Say hi, ask feedback. If you make an deposit of trust in your employees you will be able to cashout when u need them

Title: "Good FOH Money - Bad Company"
Pros: The customers that we received at Chili's were always friendly, kind and knew how to properly tip their service staff. The food was offered at a 50% discount to employees, which was much necessary to survive there.
Cons: There was a lack of accountability amongst the staff and those felt as though they could get away with a lot of terrible behavior.

Title: "Great place to work for extra cash"
Pros: I worked at Chillis for about a year and had no complaints. Easy job.
Cons: I cannot think of any particular cons from this job.
Advice to Management: My advice to management is to remember to never pick favorites.

Title: "Being a host"
Pros: Easy job and easy money
Cons: Have to deal with rude servers who try to bully you, stand your ground
Advice to Management: Great management

Title: "Manager"

Title: "line cook"

Title: "An okay job"

Title: "Meh"

Title: "Great atmosphere"

Feels like a family
Great opportunity to move up
Great benefits
Great cash flow as a server/ bartender
Great starting pay as a manager

Can be long hours
You have to eat awesome food
Sometimes the customers can be hard on the employees
