Cons: Many of the customers can be very rude and messy and since chills is family orientated so young children are constantly present, often times the managers can have very negative and degrading attitudes towards employees, and when business is slow the pay is awful
Advice to Management: Treat servers fairly and maintain a positive attitude

Title: "It is what it is"
Pros: Management works towards a positive culture, 50% discount to Brinker restaurants is good.
Cons: It is still a casual dining restaurant, automation has overtaken any sort of culinary skill in the BOH
Advice to Management: Keep weeding out the negative employees and boosting the positive ones

Title: "Bar Tender"
Pros: Money, tons of girls on staff that are typically pretty easy, lots of food to eat (just don't get caught)
Cons: Management isn't good, customers are typically low class **** who don't tip, shifts blow, once your there they consider you their slave
Advice to Management: Close the businesss

Title: "Workplace"
Pros: Hours, Tips, Co-Workers, Shifts, Management
Cons: Selfish Teamwork, Non Busy Days
Advice to Management: Understand when your employee is sick just send them home no need to keep them at work

Title: "Former Dishwasher"
Pros: The people i worked with always had my back
Cons: Long hours, bad scheduling
Advice to Management: Get your schedule together

Title: "General Manager"
Pros: It's a large company with plenty of assets. Sales were good and bonuses were usually just as good.
Cons: Bonus structure would change a couple of times a year. Big turnover in management. Fourteen out of fifteen GM's were fired or quit in 2011. The Directors usually lasted about 6 months.
Advice to Management: Be prepared for a backup plan, because they are not afraid it let you go without a justifiable cause.

Title: "Awesome career"
Pros: Endless opportunities if you work hard
Cons: You have to work very hard to be successful here. Not for the lazy or inept

Title: "Server"
Pros: Friendly customers and discounted food.
Cons: Roaches, racist staff and managers who took it lightly. Too many servers on at one time so you make less in tips.

Title: "Abusive employer"
Pros: Suppose it is better than being physically tortured.
Cons: Fired the father of a special needs child for objecting to the offensive language used by the staff. That staff apparently still works there a month later. Shame! Anyone who spends money here is supporting this abhorrent behavior.
Advice to Management: A boycott is underway. These types of problems need to be resolved immediately. Shame on you!

Title: "Chili's Host/Hostess"
Pros: a very quick-paced, hands on job. Everyone is personable and it's like working with a big family. The most hours a host will work a day is up to six hours, but if you need more hours there is always someone releasing shifts that you can pick up.
Cons: Some servers are lazy and often times the hosts will have to buss their tables although it's not in our job description to do so.

Title: "Chili's"
Pros: Good pay for their managers.
Cons: Zero support staff during all shifts. Managers have to pick up all the slack while still managing a busy restaurant.

Title: "Great"
Pros: Pay well and room for advancement along with tons of recognition
Cons: Late nights along with upper management who sometimes don't seem to care about you if your not a GM
Advice to Management: Continue to add great big rocks that make life easier

Title: "how"
Pros: I love chilis it's very exciting
Cons: Nothing, I love chilis and it's a great job

Title: "Fine Place to Work -- Not great customers"
Pros: The people I worked with were fun & acted like a big family.
Cons:
Customers -- The customers at the store I worked in were some of the worst customers I've ever dealt with.
Management -- At the store I worked in, the GM was very un-confrontational. He would not deal with issues head on, and would avoid problems all together.

Title: "Chili's Bar And Grill"
Pros: One of the pros to working here was that the environment is great. The managment really worked with my schedule.
Cons: I really do not have any cons. Working here was great. The management was great. The atmosphere was wonderful.
Advice to Management: My advice to management is to never change.

Title: "Good money, a lot of stress at busy locations"
Pros: Great place to make good money. Very stressful work environment if you were it wouldn't look at these locations. Management turnover is high at my location. Consistency is usually an issue.
Cons: No consistency, high stress, dealing with hungry people.
Advice to Management: Management is usually overwhelmed but tries very hard.

Title: "Really good money for just working Togo"
Pros: I get the hours I want and the shifts I want. I also have lots of regulars.
Cons: The cooks can be very difficult to work with, probably because they just don't care anymore. They don't read the tickets and make the food correct most of the time and when you ask them to put tickets on the boxes like they are supposed to or make the food correctly you get yelled at because it's your fault and never theirs. They need to have more printers on the line so when the food gets bumped the cooks can have a chit to put on the box that is easy access for them.

Title: "Line Cook"
Pros: I enjoyed the teamwork and overall family-like connection I had with my coworkers. I actually enjoyed coming in to work.
Cons: The work can be very demanding for very little pay.. I've had to bite the bullet on this fact for a few years.
Advice to Management: Just be sure that you treat you're employees with respect and don't take advantage of your authority - at the end of the day, we're all human, no one is above anyone else.

Title: "Server"
Pros: Working at Chili's is like working for any other chain restaurant. Menu is always changing as well as procedures. A lot of the restaurants are getting a new remodel which looks much better than the previous.
Cons: Disconnect between Corporate and the actual restaurants and depending which store you work at, customers can make or break your night.
Advice to Management: I never had an issue with management at the stores I worked at. There were always at least 3 managers in the restaurant and all were usually very different.

Title: "Server"
Pros: Great flexibility, Great co-workers, Fun enviornment
Cons: Have to work late nights, weekends, and holidays

Title: "Overall great place to work"
Pros: Pay was above average, managment was friendly, managment worked with your schedules
Cons: Working long hours, not many breaks if any

Title: "Line cook"
Pros: Good pay, plenty of hours, decent paycheck
Cons: nearly everyone is on drugs and calls in
Advice to Management: Start drug testing actually hire good people

Title: "Server"
Pros: Good flexible job if in school or for extra cash on the weekends. Can earn around $27/hour average if at a good-tipping location.
Cons: More and more duties delegated to less and less workforce. They're cutting labor, due to rising minimum wage. Cash can be very inconsistent.
Advice to Management: Focus on healthier fare, one of the fastest growing markets. Use less waste in food prep, such as stop cooking food in plastic bags.

Title: "Culinary Manager"
Pros: ERJ Dining is an employee focused company.
Cons: Not enough to make a list.

Title: "Great money for hard workers"
Pros: Flexible schedules, good opportunity to create regulars, great pay for the right person, fun atmosphere and highly recognizable name
Cons: Understaffing, favoritism, gossip, unconventional working hours, sometimes bad tippers, poor attitude of coworkers and ineptitude
Advice to Management: Listen to your key employees. Don't let a few loud people skew the voice of the entire staff. Do not hand over your power.

Title: "Chilis Manager"
Pros: The pay is the best in the industry. Great benefits, free meals for you and your family. Good menu, smart marketing. Lots of potential to build a strong customer base at your location. If you enjoy a challenge, you will be challenged.
Cons:
50-60 hours a week minimum. You will never get to stop and eat, breaks are non existent. I've yet to meet a manager with a normal family life. The place is a pressure cooker. You are constantly pressured to send your servers, hosts, and cooks home to save on labor, then hope that you don't get a rush because YOU will have to fill all those roles. It's a schizophrenic management strategy that is impossible to win with. You are encouraged to "call workers off" - basically tell them not to come in to work if you feel it's going to be a slow day. Schedule them to work... Then tell them you don't need them! (Then wonder why people don't follow their schedule - ppl are always late, not showing up for shifts). It's Crazy.
The company is so obsessed with saving on labor that none of the hourly workers ever aspire to become managers because they see how abused the managers are. Since they are salaried, the managers are viewed by the company as mules... They are always pressured to send the hourly workers home (get them off the clock) and the managers end up having to take tables, bag to go orders, answer phones, seat guests, finish the prep work, etc. They work like dogs. Guests often stand at the door without being properly greeted because their is no host on the clock and everyone else is spread too thin around the restaurant. The company has a nice veneer, but its a corporation... No soul. It's all greed and profit-based once you get down to it. You feel suckered after working there a short while.
Advice to Management: Mandate a thirty minute meal break for managers. Have GMs limit the hours their managers work and stop using them as prep cooks, hosts and servers to save labor. My daily tasks include doing prep work that most other restaurants would have a cook do. Give managers leeway with labor. Most of my shifts have a10-15% labor margin! That's incredibly good, why are you still obsessed with cutting labor? Cut ME a break once and a while!

Title: "Good restaurant job, some inconsistencies and changes though"
Employee Title: Server, to Go Specialist, FOH Expo/Quality Assurance
Pros:
- Flexible scheduling
- Easy to cross-train in different areas
Cons:
- Not many incentives for long-term employees, difficult to receive anniversary bonus
- Lots of menu changes

Title: "Depends On the Restaurant You Work At"
Pros:
-Some amazing co-workers and one good manager out of the three
-Customers where amazing and I got tipped as a hostess from regulars since Servers are not required to tip hostesses out
-Good Food
Cons:
-Moving up is difficult and I was promised only three months of being a hostess and then my manager six months later after me being a hostess told me he never had any intention of moving me up.
-Servers are not required to tip hostesses out, but hostesses where bullied into bussing servers tables since Chili's did away with busboys.
-Minimum wage pay, they don't always follow labor laws, worked several twelve hour shifts without a break.
-Short notice on meetings. Supposed to have monthly meetings and then we didn't- if we had a meeting we where not told until three or four days before and still required to show even if we had other obligations.
-High turn over rate.. I stayed for seven months and at the end of the seven months we had 4 hostesses that where hired and had already quit. The only same people that where there was the head chef, managers, a bartender, a server, and myself. They didn't train me until a month into me working on the floor, which made no sense.
-Time off is so hard to get- I am a college student who handed in my Christmas break and Spring Break days in when I was hired in August and told them I had to have those days off- the dorms would close so I had to go back home- told it would not be a problem and then I had to fight to get Christmas break off and I ended up quitting a week before Spring Break because after they said for the last two months it would not be a problem, they then scheduled me and when I told them I couldn't work they said oh well. I quit after that.
-They don't hire enough people. We had three hostesses including myself. Two could only work lunches and not weekends. I ended up working every single night and doubles/triples on Saturday and Sunday. I am full-time college and said I could not work more than 25 hours a week and they said that was fine when they hired me. After the first month my hours where 35 to 45 a week- when I said I needed them backed down to what we agreed on, they said no and that they couldn't since they didn't have enough people to work and couldn't hire anyone else.
-Got told I would have to drive to the other Chili's thirty minutes away during my break (when I got one) to pick up extra food but couldn't do it on the clock (in case I got into an accident-they didn't want it on their time) and never compensated for gas. Told it was part of my "job responsibilities."

Chili's itself is an amazing company. I never got to see benefits and getting my shift meals where always hard. Older workers would bully the younger and newer ones. I had a girl pour a drink on me on purpose (a worker) and the manager didn't do anything about it so I smelled of alcohol the rest of my shift and then got in trouble for it. I have friends who worked at other Chili's and they love it and haven't had a problem. It depends on the MANAGEMENT. I ended up waiting 3 days in a row for over a hour and a half each day for an interview with each manager- that should've been my red flag.

Also, Chili's does not drug test. That was a huge problem.
Advice to Management: Don't lie to your employees, treat them like they are valued. If there is a problem, don't tell them to just tell another crew member where to go and how to get there, help them solve it. Work with your employees. I had several regulars who loved me and got mad when I told them I was leaving, I was valued by customers but not by the staff and that was why I had to leave. I stayed so long because of the amazing customers. Be considerate, employees are people also.

Title: "Poorly run. Disorganized"
Pros: Decent pay. Poor tip percentage but high volume so averages out to be ok but far from lucrative pay
Cons: Bad management. Bad customers. Food takes forever. No foodrunners. No busses. Complete chaos
Advice to Management: Hire foodrunners

Title: "Good place to work"
Pros: Free meals to cooks and managers take care of you when you come to dine in like a VIP
Cons: Sometimes managers don't help at all , they shut the office door to check Facebook lol
Advice to Management: Stay focus on what you are hired for and leave your smartphone on second place

Title: "Hard to remember the menu, but they are willing to work with you. Very nice staff."
Pros: Great benefits, fun to work with, and of course, great food!
Cons: No cons, really.
Advice to Management: Train more for closing and opening procedures.

Title: "Bartender, Server, Take out"
Pros:
Fantastic management
Clear expectations
Excellent training program
Opportunity for advancement
Cons:
Training was stressful but rewarding
Tipouts weren't as much as they should be
Good workers should be rewarded more often

Title: "Prepping"
Pros: Met some cool people, and I enjoy prepping food, so that side of it was somewhat ok.
Cons: So many things. They have such unrealistic expectations for their prep cooks. I would be handed a list of over 100 things at 8 AM, and then sent off on my own, which isn't the big deal. Its the fact of how much had to be prepped and how little help I got. And I was expected to be done by 2:30 every day. Which never happened. Works lots of 10-16 hour shifts, no breaks.
Advice to Management: Communicate with each other before talking to employees, help prep out, try to reduce amount of items on prep list

Title: "chilis"
Pros: great atmosphere, love the food, and sports.
Cons: poor location, bad service, sometimes workers dont care.
Advice to Management: nothing

Title: "Highs are highs, lows are lows."
Pros: I enjoyed working at Chili's for the first year. I started when I was 20, so it was the first job I was ever making about 30 grand a year, with few bills it allowed me a lot more freedom than I was used to. Chili's employees are also very close, which kept morale high enough for a while. If money and going out drinking after with your coworkers is literally all that matters to you, then you'll love it for about a year. Then things change...
Cons: Then you get good at your job, you move up in the ranks and they schedule you a few closing shifts. They see you're good at those and your 4 nights a week, getting out at 9 pm becomes 6 nights a week, 9 hour shifts with no breaks. Because they will only train a few people for these shifts, no one can ever work them for you. Next, the days off you request are unavailable, and you have to work you boyfriend's 21st birthday, and close Christmas Eve, and New Years Eve...then New Years Day, then Valentines Day...and then suddenly you're a "disgruntled employee" because they never listen. Eventually your grades start to slip since you're so exhausted, you ask for time off that you never get. Then when your car breaks down (and you still make it to work!!) they call you a liar. Then, after busting your butt for a year and a half, they fire you on the spot for having prescription medication in your purse and you realize you hated working there all along...
Advice to Management: They take their employees for granted. Management bullies you into working shifts and then gets personally offended when you have trouble meeting demands. They don't listen, they kill the morale of their employees and wonder why no one wants to work there. My advice to Brinker International? Do a little looking internally.

Title: "Manager"
Pros: Great discount on food until you get tired of it. Pretty decent salary and okay quarterly bonuses if you hit your numbers.
Cons: Poor quality of life. Inconsistent scheduling and inconsistent scheduler. Upper management plays favorites and has no regard for the people below them. Major focus on productivity so constantly understaffed and managers get stuck working in a position instead of managing. Unhappy guests and team members make for a consistent negative work environment. Constant rollout a and never ending menu.
Advice to Management: Get rid of BRG focus and allow your managers to manage. Recognize their is a serious problem when you lose four Area Directors from the same region in a 6month time span.

Title: "worst job i had"
Pros: nothing seem the way it sound they tell you what you want to hear then they got you.they treat you with no respect what so ever and work you to death.
Cons: stay away from this company if you want piece of mind it will be nerve racking
Advice to Management: get your act together

Title: "It's ehh"
Pros: Most of my managers are really great! They work very hard to make customers, and they have no problem busting their butt to help the servers when we get in the weeds. I think that's pretty cool, because you don't see that everywhere. Chili's uses a team service method, which is also convenient ( two people basically take care of a larger amount of tables rather than just having your own set tables). Because of team service, the sections are larger because they assume two people are going to be stopping by and helping each table. if you're partnered with a weak server, team service falls through, because all of a sudden you're taking care of your own tables in addition to all of theirs. This happens to me all the time. Cool method, but it doesn't always work.
Cons: Understand coming in to Chili's, we do not have table bussers, food runners, etc. servers do this themselves. Which is cool because the tipout is only to bartender, but it can also keep you very busy doing these things on top of waiting on your tables. The main reason I'm leaving Chili's is because of the crowd it attracts. The Ziosk that sit on the table is basically a flashing light to parents to bring all 10 of their kids to Chili's and I'm running around like crazy for a bill that is barely $50, and I may only get a 10% tip. Cheap people. It's so bad, and please don't be offended if you go to Chili's to eat and you're reading this, because obviously not everyone that comes in is cheap. However, the crowd that came in on Mother's Day was just ridiculous. I made 10% tips ALL DAY. Chili's is a great first job; however, if you want to make real money, I highly recommend you try other places.
Advice to Management: Stop worrying so much about GEM. I swear that's ALL my managers care about. If a customer gets pissed off, they say, "don't let them checkout on the Ziosk." In case you don't know what GEM is, it's basically a short survey guests fill out at the end of paying their bill on the Ziosk. The surveys are printed off at the end of each night and managers see all comments/complaints. Corporate sees them as well.

Title: "server"
Pros: fast money! meet friends and you learn a lot far as learning how to multi-task.
Cons: not worth the time, I feel as though servers should get paid more hourly.

Title: "Terrible management."
Pros: Popular restaurant, tips are good.
Cons: The management is very unqualified.

Title: "Waitress"
Pros: 50% off food. Flexible hours for students. Can make decent money if the store you work at is high volume.
Cons:
The amount of side work that is done on $3.10 an hour is ridiculous, also the case with opening shifts. At that time no tips are being made so pay should be minimum wage. It is not fair to make employees do extra work while getting paid next to nothing (sometimes takes more than an hour or two). Like any serving job dealing with the public is hard and you must be a people person. In addition, I feel like pushing the customers to use the Ziosks should not be such a big deal. Yes, it can be convenient if the customer is in a rush and makes the customers feel safe as their card never has to leave the table, however, a lot of people simply want to enjoy their experience out and do not want to cash themselves out. This should not reflect on the server. I once had a table tip me 50% because I did not make them cash out on the ziosk. They told me to tell management that it takes away from the experience. The surveys at the end are also ridiculous because people will not tell you that they had a problem and then say it in the survey. How is that solving anything? Especially if the problem was with the food. I cannot fix the problem if I do not know about it until the next day.

There is also a lot of favoritism and not enough professionalism. If you work hard you and do well you should get recognized/rewarded. I also felt there was no opportunity to grow in this company as they were always hiring from outside rather than from within. The menu is constantly changing and is pretty large also. Customers get mad when something leaves (cinnamon apples and Caesar salads). There are long hours and no breaks. Sometimes I would get there at 9am and not leave til 10 with no break on doubles. Overall, this is not a job I would recommend for a long period of time.
Advice to Management:
Listen to customers and employees wants/needs
Stop favoritism and cattiness
Stop being cheap and pay your employees for their work
Promote from within the company

Title: "waitress"
Pros: great atmosphere, flexible scheduling, heading in a great direction with this brand
Cons: GWAP (guest with a problem) is unfair. It is based on a survey that guests take on the ziosk after payment and it asks if there was a problem... A LOT of problems have to do with food correctness and how long the food took which is a problem with the kitchen not the servers and yet we still get the slack from our percentage of guests with a problem while the kitchen hears nothing of it....
Advice to Management: Don't have blatantly obvious favorites and hold the kitchen accountable for the GWAPs that they cause

Title: "Server"
Pros: People, staff, good food, no-brainer
Cons: Bad server once in while (debbie downers), but when staff is good it's great
Advice to Management: Don't be so campy/basic. Be cool w/the staff and they'll respect u infinitely more

Title: "great environment"
Pros: Fred food, nice people, flexible hours, opportunity.
Cons: Standing all day, freezer limited
Advice to Management: Better break area

Title: "good"
Pros: Nice group of people to work with.
Cons: Very late nights when assigned to be closer.

Title: "Would not want to work here again"
Pros: The menu is easy to remember if you are serving, and it allows you to transfer easily to many different locations
Cons: you are in a restaurant that does not attract the best tippers, no matter how nice you are they will be unlikely to tip.
Advice to Management: Help people to move up

Title: "Assistant Manager"
Pros: Flexible schedule, good benefits, Promote from with in, always expanding and looking for new innovative ideas to grow company.
Cons: Expected to work long hours. Job is not conducive for a family person. Expected to work on days off if need to. Expected to work every hourly position if need to.
Advice to Management: Its a good company but be prepared to work long hard hours. As a manager you will work hourly positions and you will work well over 55 hours a week. Many of the hours will not be spent in the building.

Title: "Host/Togo/Food Expo"
Pros: Meet great people and decent discount.
Cons: Terrible hours and favoriteism is HUGE in the company. Terrible pay especially as the food expo.
Advice to Management: Learn how to clean a restaurant. Mice in the store should not be a problem.

Title: "Just like any other restaurant in that there are good days and bad ones."
Pros:
-Coming here from a minimum wage gig was great. So long as you get a decent amount of hours, the money is good (*I'm speaking from the standpoint of a college kid)
-Free meals on shifts you work
-Good kitchen experience
-Easy, repetitive, mindnumbing work. If you don't get bored easily, or do and don't mind it, you'll be all set
Cons:
-Managers play favorites. People who have poor work ethics or attitudes still get good/better hours than others... highly annoying
-Prep (everyone who works in the kitchen, really) doesn't get treated fairly. New promotions come along, which equals more things to prep/cook, yet we're hardly ever given a bigger time frame to complete all of our tasks and are instead reprimanded if not finished by a certain time. Your hours can get cut in a moment's notice in order to help labor, yet management generally makes no strides of their own to see what can be done to help you recover some of that lost time.
-Managers can be very lax in disciplining wrongdoings by other team members. They also set goals that are never seen or heard of again
-Early starting time. If you're not a morning person and can't get over it, probably not the best gig for you
Advice to Management: LISTEN. TO. YOUR. EMPLOYEES. Realize that not all changes you make are always good ones. Recognize that not everyone can do a truckload of work in less than 8 hours. Dole out punishments to EVERYONE who does something wrong, not just a select few people you don't care for as much. Crack down on EVERYONE when you talk about tightening up, not just a handful of people you don't like. Don't be an a-hole to your workers when they approach you with nothing but respect.

Title: "Very bipolar place to work, because one day you will love it, but the next day you will hate it."
Pros: Flexible scheduling, steady flow of people to serve, decent money if you are good at your job. Meeting many awesome people that come in for service or work along side you.
Cons: Lack of care for the well being of employees from management expressed through both action and words. Unsafe working environment. This restaurant also attracts some people that are very difficult to work with and serve.
Advice to Management: Care about people more then selling your product including guests and employees. Priorities are unethical from my perspective. People are more important then money. Without people you will not generate any revenue.

Title: "I work as a server."
Pros: Fellow employees become family and always make the atmosphere more fun.
Cons: A major downfall is the long hours, and uncertainty of the actual hours that you will be there because it depends on the volume in the restaurant.

Title: "High turn over rate for a reason"
Pros: You get a 50% discount on food when working. They work with your school schedule if you are a student.
Cons: They do not care about the employee. If you are sick and even if you are throwing up unless you can get someone to work for you and have management to approve it. You will get fired. I have seen employees go to the restroom several times to throw up and come back to continue working. Even when you let management know the employee has been throwing up they tell them to continue to work. Also I have had to go to management because I could not find employees because they are outside taking a long smoke break. And their customers need them. If you are a non smoker you are not allowed to have a non scheduled break. All in all my experience was not pleasant. Most employees do not stay long and do not feel like part of a team.
Advice to Management: When you have employees that do work hard and have a proven work record and has a bad couple of weeks due to sickness or emergency. You should be forgiven and they will be loyal to you. And if you have a high turn over rate you should go to employees and figure out why. Value your employees!!!

Title: "You better like working with people"
Pros: Relatively easy work that's good for people who like to move around and usually stay busy
Cons: Getting cross trained can be like pulling teeth and hungry people are difficult
Advice to Management: Keep to your commitments and work on making fair schedules

Title: "fun pace with the right management"
Pros: Good co workers, and the discount.
Cons: Management was not fuctional. Higher levels new management was bad but didn't change anything
Advice to Management: If you know there is a problem with a gm and several complaints from employees and customers come in, as well as falling gem scores. Something should be done.

Title: "Overall positive experience with company."
Pros: Good pay for a temporary job. Management is flexible on scheduling. Good job to have if you are a student.
Cons: You lose your weekends and often evenings to work. There is no break in a typical shift. Money is not guaranteed as you rely on tips from customers.
Advice to Management: Hire more intelligent people.

Title: "Excellent company to work for, as they care about their people, and are a leader in the industry with menu innovation"
Pros: Quality of life and benefits
Cons: Changing casual dining industry, and sometimes slow to innovate with things other than menu
Advice to Management: Forward thinking

Title: "Mixed bag, people were diverse and interesting, younger immature management team."
Pros: Great food discount that can be used nationwide, availability of benefits. With the right "zone partner" and kitchen crew there is plenty of money to be made.
Cons: Childish inexperienced managers who were ineffective leaders. Staff walked on and took advantage of them. Descriminatory remarks made by another server about guests were overlooked when I approached managers and I ended up without a job.
Advice to Management: Grow a set and lead. Getting rid of someone who is offended by inappropriate remarks of others isn't right. This is 2015 NOT 1955 where remarks regarding a person's skin tone or the genders of the guests is not cool.

Title: "If it wasn't for the management and theft I would've stayed."
Pros: Money can be very good so long as you have the right shifts and sections
Cons: Your forced to pool general manager enforces this by telling you that he can't force you to pool but if you don't the door is right there. So if your stuck working with a lazy or untrustworthy person your screwed. And theft is HUGE problem in this place. Sidework is hell takes about an hr and that's if your not closing also they make you do extra cleaning once a month they call it "BUG NIGHT" and you don't get any extra pay for this or compensation even though your there for hours longer than you would've been. There are no food runners or bussers and you get a 13-15 table section with your partner. Your also getting only a couple $ from each table mostly 10% because of the quality of customers and prices on the menu so your running around like a madman you dont even make the money you should've made for your sales. And if you get stiffed on a bill? Management will actually defend the guests and tell you that they are not required to tip you.Your customers are almost always rude, entitled, and cheap. Oh and don't even bother trying to request days off. Half the time no matter how important you won't get that day off. The turnover rate is very high.
Advice to Management: Hire more than just pretty girls and stop sexually harassing them by asking them personal questions about their sex life and even playing "games" such as who would you have sex with its disgusting and most of the staff is 18-25, be proffessional. Don't blame the staff when the kitchen crashes maybe if you helped expo or run food instead of sitting in the office on your phone the weekend shifts wouldn't go so badly. Schedule people fairly not based on favorites. If someone claims they believed they've been robbed don't dismiss this and do something, I'm not saying fire people based on rumors but that's a serious accusation and you should at least look into it. Your very hard on your staff and expect way to much it's a job for most of us not a career so don't pressure us to miss class to go work for you. Even with requests for days off you require us to tell you at least 2 weeks in advance fine but then you deny that request even when it's for something important and we gave you 2 weeks to find a cover for that shift. When an employee quits you make their last 2 weeks hell to the point where most people just stop showing up. Quit being spiteful don't take it to heart everyone needs to move on at some point. Management needs to set an example for their staff.

Title: "Love the people, not always the job."
Pros:
Working at Chili's is never boring.

The 401k is great. They offer a 5% match on 6% invested. That's one of the best 401ks around.

The culture is great.

The brand is growing and doing very well.
Cons:
Work/life balance is something that seems impossible in the restaurant industry. While they have tested some ideas in certain markets like investing in a larger management staff to accommodate more time off they have failed to roll this forward. Turnover for managers seems to remain fairly high.

Most areas do not ever become "fully staffed" and when there is a shortage the rest of the area is called on to help cover. This means you will be away from your home for a couple of nights each month until things get back to normal.

Career opportunities are lacking. Becoming a restaurant manager is very attainable. A general manager position is attainable if you are willing to move. Anything past that the company is stagnant. From the area director level up there is not a lot of moving pieces. That results in general managers that have been in their role for 10+ years everywhere. It's hard for these people to remain passionate about what they do when they have not been challenged in years.
Advice to Management: Find a way to fix work/life balance.

Title: "server"
Pros: flexible hours great open door policy
Cons: unsteady income and bad communication

Title: "Terrible!!"
Pros: I don't think there are any pros.
Cons: Everything. Management and staff are not organized
Advice to Management: Hire better people.

Title: "Used to be a great company to work for"
Pros: Bonus program can be lucrative if you can hit the performance indexes.
Cons: Specs and standards seem to be fluid at this point in their maturation
Advice to Management: Figure out what you want to be when you grow up

Title: "I found the company Chili's to not be overly caring about their employees, but many of my coworkers were so great."
Pros:
- You make a fair amount of tips
- You are usually not too bored, at least at nights
- If you are going to school, it works well because you can just work nights and weekends
Cons:
- They would rather fire you than pay overtime
- The restaurant business is not always the most rewarding
- You only get your schedule 3 to 4 days before you start working that week
Advice to Management: Please, please, please when we ask something off, honor it! One of the most stressful things about working here was not knowing until 3 days beforehand if the special day you requested off 2 months ago was actually going to work out.

Title: "Dishwasher"
Pros: I had a reasonable schedule that I could live with
Cons: The nature of the job was too much to take

Title: "Not a bad place to work"
Pros: Put the guest first and solved problems with genuine intentions
Cons: Not always organized and would change things but not everyone would know.

Title: "Love being a chili-head"
Pros: Friendly coworkers, lots of teamwork, very flexible with scheduling.
Cons: Customers are sometimes a challenge.
Advice to Management: N/A

Title: "Ups and downs"
Pros: Great place to meet life long friends
Cons: Hectic work environment. Very long hours with little sleep.
Advice to Management: Takes awhile. They dangle a carrot in front of you so you keep doing a great job for them.

Title: "Server"
Pros: Flexible Schedule, Friendly Staff, Short hours
Cons: customer service as you are always dealing with people, working holidays, late nights
Advice to Management: Continue being awesome

Title: "Part time serving"
Pros: Flexible scheduling. Training for inexperienced servers.
Cons: Managers do not respect employees. Menu constantly changing and adding more work for servers with no extra pay.

Title: "Good for PT work"
Pros: Food discounts and great food
Cons: Atmosphere contains a lot of drugs and drinking

Title: "Great place to work"
Pros: The management was very easy to deal with and worked around my college schedule.
Cons: Working weekends is always a downside, but that is part of the business.

Title: "Ridiculous work for no money"
Pros: Co workers. Management pretty cool and easy to get along with.
Cons: Customers are so cheap at this location. Tips as a server can always be bald at times but this location is never good. Great servers walk with less than $50 on weekend night.
Advice to Management: Stop with the promotions, it bring in the worst of the worst.

Title: "Dependent on revenue it could be stressful"
Pros: Many benefits ranging from dental to health care
Cons: None at this moment
Advice to Management: None

Title: "Great starting point"
Pros: Chili's is very thorough with their training and flexible on scheduling. I started working there when I was a student and continued after graduation while deciding what my next step would be. It was a fun work environment, but maintained structure to keep things moving.
Cons: I agree with a previous reviewer that too much emphasis was placed on the customer surveys. Before the ziosks, it took an extra effort for surveys to be completed, so only customers who had a very strong opinion either way would be compelled to do so. The restaurant/servers also only got credit for 5s (scale 1-5) even though 4s still represented above average scores.
Advice to Management: Overall, management did a very good job. I recall there being problems with promotions/ shifts being promised to multiple employees where there was only room for one, which caused more disappointments than was necessary.

Title: "Flexible"
Pros: Flexible hours, great concept - dining room always full! Plenty of regulars at this place.
Cons: Hard to take some of the "experience" from here and apply it to corporate jobs, as corporate HR sometimes has a hard time believing that server experiences translate to the professional world.
Advice to Management: Make sure that you continue seeking your employees feedback as they are the boots on the ground, especially when rolling out new items.

Title: "Very hard work environment."
Pros: Coworkers are great although over worked also.
Cons: Corporate expects managers to cook and do hourly functions all day to save money. All they care about is the bottom line. No concern for the staff. Bonuses are almost impossible to obtain, no sick days, no holiday pay etc.
Advice to Management: Corporate needs to show appreciation for the people working in the field. Start caring about the people making your money.

Title: "Company is fine, just had a bad manager"
Pros: The opportunity to get tips and get more than minimum wage. Met a lot of interesting people. Some would invite me to sit with them while I took their order or share a desert with them. Co-workers were also nice.
Cons: Our manager didn't know how to schedule people. We either had too few cooks or too many servers on the floor. One Friday night I only had two tables for the entire night. On a Friday! I asked the manager if I could get more hours and she said "It's not how many hours you work, it's how you work the tables." You can't really work much money out of two tables.
Advice to Management: I'm not sure if the same managers are still working there. Just make sure that one of them knows how to schedule people so they can get enough tables.

Title: "waitress"
Pros: Great Money, easy, quick, fun,
Cons: Management, guest, side work, tsa
Advice to Management: Better training

Title: "Serving is stressful, lots of side work."
Pros: We have a lot of regulars and I love my co workers and managers. Money is best on the week days when the grill can handle the crowd and the clientele are a bit more high class than on the weekends.
Cons: SO MUCH SIDE WORK. Many hours cleaning and rolling silverware, all at 2.13 an hour. Plates and trays are very heavy, so I ache. All the time.
Advice to Management: Fire the people who are incapable of doing their jobs. This is not a charity. It's very frustrating when my tips go down because the grill can't get food out. Servers get dogged out more for customer dissatisfaction than the grill does-even though it's the grills fault.

Title: "Great people"
Pros: Great people to work with
Cons: Management is very political with workers

Title: "Pays the bills"
Pros: Flexible hrs. Good pay. Nice;)
Cons: Tips. Sometimes good sometimes bad.
Advice to Management: Listen.

Title: "Well structured company, they care about training you to do your best, do what they can to make it fun"
Pros:
- They make sure you are well trained and feel comfortable with your responsibilities
- They are constantly growing and reaching out
Cons:
As you would expect working in any restaurant, you sometimes have to deal with unhappy customers for one reason or another.
It's sometimes competitive to get holidays off when everybody is trying to ask off at the same time.
Advice to Management: Keep doing what you're doing!

Title: "Serving Logan Wonderful, Awesome, and Fresh food from the menu like no place else!"
Pros: The corporate culture is great, and we all really care about each other and our guests!
Cons: Sometimes I mess up an order, but if I own up to it then it's better for everyone.
Advice to Management: Rely on your instincts more than the quantitative data from the guest surveys. You guys rock!

Title: "Will Depend On Location"
Pros: Flexible scheduling, delicious but inexpensive food, popular restaurant. Easy to advance if interested and hours are plentiful.
Cons: (Shelton, CT location) Employees and managers do not act professionally. Rude comments and occasional outbursts can be heard from the kitchen. Workspace is often disorganized. Lack of respect among teams.
Advice to Management: Be less tolerable of disrespect among team members and set a positive example yourselves.

Title: "Decent place to work"
Pros: Opened the store as grill cook, not too difficult, busy at times. They pay you
Cons: Other staff members can be pretty rough at times
Advice to Management: Good Luck

Title: "Work environment"
Pros: Make great friends and the harder you work the more you make
Cons: The economy has made tips go down
Advice to Management: NA

Title: "Non-existent, skimpy benefits and low pay"
Pros: Some of the co-workers and management are ok. Food discount.
Cons: Low pay. Need to be on welfare or have second job to survive. No vacation, holidays or sick days, very basic medical benefits.
Advice to Management: You're making big bucks but you can't keep help because you pay slave wages and the work is hard.

Title: "grear opportunity if you are willing to work hard and work smart."
Pros:
People can be generous with their tips
It's normal to make $150 a day on weekends
Coworkers are fun
If you work hard, you can be promoted to higher positions
Cons:
You never see a paycheck due to taxes
Food industry requires long, arduous hours
Customers can treat you badly
Stressful environment
Advice to Management: Positive reinforcement goes a long way, especially when employees have to spend so much time receiving with the potential negativity of guests.

Title: "Loved it!!"
Pros:
Flexible scheduling

Advancement from within the store

Food discount
Cons:
You never know what type of guest you will be waiting on

Very slow during slow season

Title: "Great Restaurant and environment"
Pros: Chili's takes you in like a family. Though there are new rollouts of food almost every month, the company helps notify servers and managers in a timely manner to get their staff ready for new items. Managers, for the most part, are great with helping your shift go smoothly and dealing with stressful situations. I have been an employee for almost 5 years while going to school and Chili's has always been flexible with my schedule. Chili's is like a new family and I highly recommend working here if you enjoy the service industry.
Cons: Only con I can think of is the menu changes a lot, but that is about it.

Title: "Manager"
Pros: you get a comp card
Cons: hours, pay, servers make more than you, customers
Advice to Management: recruit people from staff who think managing is a career

Title: "Pretty standard, as far as chain restaurants go, but a good place to make quick money."
Pros: Out of all the chain restaurants, Chili's is one of the easiest to make quick money at. The sections are set up so that most good servers are able to get A LOT of tables at once, (sometimes almost overwhelmingly so). Tip out is also minimal compared to other restaurants so that you keep most of the money you are making.
Cons: This is sort of common for the industry but management rotation is frequent and communication between managers is often very poor.
Advice to Management: Communicate better with servers about the extent of their expectations.

Title: "Nice place for a first job."
Pros: Flexible schedule and overall a fun place to work
Cons: Not a whole lot of room for professional growth. Very high turn over in staff.

Title: "Loyalty is not one of their numerous "culture""
Pros: Can make money if you hustle, but you really have to hustle. managers are told they work 10hr days, but it's more like 15.
Cons:
-long work hours for minimal recognition
-corporate loves you one day and then hates you the next
-too bottom line and making numbers focused
-servers are children, have to hold their hands to get anything accomplished
-managers end up doing everything; bussing for the staff, running food, hosting, taking orders, and bartending all while trying to place their own orders, office work, and cooking all at the same time.
Advice to Management: You won't like working there

Title: "A great company to work for!"
Pros: This company was great to work for, the money for the work was great, I learned a lot really fast, they hired me without previous experience
Cons: It is a customer service oriented job and every customer service job has to deal with bad customers at times.

Title: "Chili's Grille & Bar"
Pros: Tips $$$, Flexible scheduling, fun
Cons: Management is rocky, Franchise is frugal,

Title: "Fun while it lasted."
Pros: They want you to make $20/hr
Cons: Management can be sloppy or inattentive.
Advice to Management: Listen to employees. If there's a problem be proactive and find a way to fix it!

Title: "No life sucky management"
Pros: co-workers and that's about it
Cons: Management pay people no life the hours suck if you're part time just know you are really full time
Advice to Management: Maybe choose mangers that speak to their team respectfully, who actually care & will help by any means. Give your chilis heads a life!!! The hours suck & you never know when you'll be off. Terrible pay for what we go through.

Title: "It's alright for a waiting job."
Pros: Chilis was the easiest restaurant that I have worked at. The food is good. It is easy to flip tables quickly.
Cons: The main challenge is working with incompetent co-workers. Also, there is no gratuity available for large parties.
Advice to Management: Give employees more incentives.

Title: "It's a good start!"
Pros: Great co-workers (I've worked at two stores)! Some flexibility. Can make a lot of money. 50% discount (1-4 guests) when you're off and eat at Chili's (any).
Cons: Not a guaranteed job. Not a for sure you'll walk away with consistent money. Can get really stressful. Smell like food after work. Late nights.
Advice to Management: Keep promoting people!!! This helps people stay motivated! Give bonuses, stop being stingy.

Title: "GREAT management, stressful work environment, WONDERFUL PEPPER PALS/MANAGERS that work as a team! Good food:)"
Pros: Never got denied a raise, worked around my student schedule, and genuinely cared about the employees. Good FOOD and good "team-bonding" outings!
Cons: Stressful workplace, not enough people on busy nights, and sometimes strict on rules on when you can have food discounts.
Advice to Management: Make your regional/uppermost management work there on a busy Fri/Sat/Sun few times a year and personally employees what they need!

Title: "ERJ Dining is a decent employer to work for."
Pros: Opportunities for advancement, benefits, everyday is different, paid vacation, tuition reimbursement, good co-workers, salaried, opportunity for raises yearly, six paid sick days
Cons: Very long hours, at least 10 hour shifts, required to work 50-55 hours weekly, always changing policies, no overtime pay when working more than required hours
Advice to Management: Needs more structured advancement program, management and employee training programs are very unorganized. When rolling out new food items the kinks should be better worked out before going to store level. Some policies not clear, too much leeway and guesswork when disciplining employees. Back office computers very old and slow, hindering completing your responsibilities.

Title: "fast pace,hard working person that loved working in a team spirited company."
Pros: very happy place with very friendly people....always loved going to work.it was always positive and i am very passionate about cooking.
Cons: i was very comfortable in every aspect of working for my company.
Advice to Management: i would love a job with benefits but some times it comes with hard work and time which i am willing to accomplish. i welcome a entry level position to proudly work my way up the the ladder.I have always landed leadership roles due to my hard work and determination. I don't consider time off policy.

Title: "Server"
Pros: tips, cash, easy money, flexibility in schedule
Cons: working for public, side work, hourly pay

Title: "Laid back atmosphere but not worth it at times."
Pros:
-good pay (when busy)
-fun people to work with
-flexible schedule and easy to ask off
-good discount on food for employees
Cons:
-Intense promotion of GEM surveys that could lead to you not being scheduled if you don't get enough
-St. Jude fundraiser in September is great but customers are absolutely bombarded. I wouldn't donate either.
-Management plays favorites
-Shifts can be very long
Advice to Management: Stop being so money hungry. I had a manager tell me they don't give discounts to soldiers in uniform because they don't have a gun. And guns can protect us if we get robbed. That's why police officers on duty get a discount.

Title: "Like any other serving job, but with more side work"
Pros: Can have a good schedule, good pay if you get good clientele, people are fun to work with, food is awesome
Cons: Scheduling issues (but this is specific to the store I work at), restaurant is open late, a lot of side work - often takes an hour and a half to two hours to leave the store after you're cut - asked to perform non-server tasks when closing (i.e. scrubbing the floors), often get bad clientele, but that's to be expected when you work in corporate/franchise
Advice to Management: Look at your staff's availability, and schedule them within it. If you make changes to the schedule, let us know ahead of time, don't try to appease everybody because that negatively affects someone else. Get better cooks so that servers don't have to be held accountable for kitchen errors. Pay attention to labor and actually cut servers when it's slow. More consistency overall

Title: "Value?"
Pros:
Awesome food
Friendly management staff
Decent hours
Cons:
No room for advancement
High turn over rate
Lack of teamwork in both FOH & BOH
Advice to Management:
Pay people what they are worth, and they will be loyal.
Pay them what you agreed at hire, and you may find their worth.
Overwork and underpay them, and then you find yourself starting from scratch...again.

Title: "Restaurant Manager"
Pros: Quality of life. Annual Raises. Bonuses. Upper management's level of engagement. Innovation.
Cons: Managers work too many positions and are way to hands on. Just as much time catering to team members as the guest. Too much change in menu, initiatives and procedures and recipes.
Advice to Management: Stop catering to team members and focus more on guest. Managers should supervise and be less hands on. Quit changing everything so often.

Title: "was a great learning experience"
Pros: meeting new people everyday and providing excellent customer service to them.
Cons: not much room for advancement
Advice to Management: benefits could be a lot better. pay for servers could be better

Title: "Simple Serving Job"
Pros: easy cash in hand, ability to transfer locations with ease
Cons: management puts a huge emphasis on "ziosks" which not only confuse customers, but make an extremely simple job much harder

Title: "Loving it so far!"
Pros: As a server you get a good amount of tables. Around 4-8 tables at a time. Which leads to more money, the management is wonderful, in my opinion, because they're laid back, but will be stern if needed.
Cons: The only con I could see is if a server wasn't able to keep up. And that's not the company's fault, but their own.

Title: "work"
Pros: I like some of the employees that I worked with and the customers
Cons: The ever changing schedule and short shifts
Advice to Management: none

Title: "I am new but love it"
Pros: Benefits, friendly staff, helpful managers
Cons: There are No bussers
Advice to Management: Keep on helping your team members succeed like you have been so far!

Title: "Good job, Good Experience"
Pros: Gain experience in customer service and learn how to work with many different people.
Cons: Hours. They aren't horrible, especially if you are working during the day but all the money and tips are in the night shift.
Advice to Management: Training should be improved. Management should make sure that employees are good trainers before allowing them to train your staff.

Title: "worst place ever"
Pros:
free food if you worked a double shift
50% off all chili's and maggiano's restaurants
certain discounts on products such as consoles, cars, etc.
Cons: I had 4 managers that never seemed to communicate with each other and each wanted different things from us. i was a host, so I was the first to deal with customers and had direct communication with the managers via headset. One manager never had hers on so I always had to run to the back to find her, leaving the door unattended thus getting yelled at by impatient guests. No tip out system although the hosts were also bussers. They got rid of bussers so it's up to the servers to clean their stations but most of the time they didn't. We were a very high volume store, yet we were severly understaffed. I worked 6 day weeks usually 9 hours a day. One manager yelled at me for staying overtime even though the other manager didn't give me a break and asked me to stay later. Goes to show how well everyone communicated. Just overall an awful experience, and I left crying many nights. Also, on a busy Friday night I had an awful server who couldn't handle more than 3 tables at a time and cursed me out in front of all our guests yet the manager that night did not do anything to handle the situation because they were in a sexual relationship. Worst place I've ever worked at and would not recommend to anyone.
Advice to Management: You all preach communication yet when it comes down to it, no one cares and seems to do things their own way. Train your staff better, and don't keep a high volume store so understaffed that you overwork the workers you do have, and then yell at them for working too much.

Title: "Great company to work for."
Pros: Flexible hours, great $$$, and awesome discounts.
Cons: Management (at times), ups and downs of business (as with most restaurants)

Title: "Torture for those in Management"
Pros: Fun staff. Fast pace. High energy. Front of house shifts were decent most of the time.
Cons: Spend most of your time cooking. Everything was microwaved due to no time to prep and cook properly. Managers always having to work in kitchen. Constant issues in the kitchen lead to having to comp a lot of things, then you get in trouble for comping things. Constant high stress level. Women and single employees are treated better than those married with kids and men.. Absolutely no concern for quality of life. Too many menu changes. Even the full time kitchen employees don't know the ingredients. But hey, they just throw them in the microwave anyway. Chili's does not care about employees or customers, only the bottom line. I worked for multiple Chili's in multiple states. I thought it was bad in my original area, but is worse in other areas.
Advice to Management: Stop trying to think of grand new ideas and start caring even one ounce about your employees and customers. Stop caring so much about shareholders, they will be happy if your customers are happy. Fire the board, president, and everyone at the top and hire someone with a brain. Maybe someone from Chic-fil-A. Probably the lowest paid person at Chic-fil-A or In-N-Out could run this company better.

Title: "average company"
Pros:
working with the staff - good people for the most part
easy to schedule days off
Cons:
Long hours
Bonuses are not very large unless you work at a very busy store
missed lots of weddings and family functions due to other managers being off.
Advice to Management:
Regional Director comes in and what he sees is how he thinks you run your shifts all the time.
Constantly changing the menu upsets guests.
too many coupons for free stuff and why have expired coupons if you want us to take any coupon they bring in.

Title: "Very great to work at, but every restaurant is different due to management."
Pros: Great environment to work in.
Cons: Schedule not very consistent. You some times get the feel that the brand is trying way too hard.

Title: "Ups and downs like everywhere"
Pros: Good pay compared to competition, Pretty decent hours depending on location, Good culture, Great tools to get the numbers you need and see what you need to do to improve.
Cons: Hard labor plan, you will definitely spend a very decent amount of time in position, a lot of the time it is dishwashing, hopping on the line and cooking, or out front bussing tables and running food. High turnover rate.
Advice to Management: Worry a little less about maxing out your bonus, and a little more about keeping your current guests and employees happy.

Title: "Foh expeditor"
Pros: Friendly and fun work environment woth plenty of opportunity to advance in your career fun contests half off meals
Cons: Customers can be very ride at time and coworkers aren't always the nicest management isn't always very professional and doesn't know what they're doing half the time will work you as much as they possibly can
Advice to Management: Make sure managers know what they are doing

Title: "Fun fast paced work place."
Pros: Great managment and fun upbeat atmosphere.
Cons: Can get hectic during rush.

Title: "Corporate doesn't know how to run the business."
Pros: Tips could be good sometimes
Cons:
-Terrible Ideas from corporate office
-not proud of the food being served
-no set schedule policy
Advice to Management: Have people work from the restaurant level hired onto corporate.

Title: "Aggravating"
Pros: Nice place to eat at half of the people are ok
Cons: Zero team work lots of lazy people and constant attitude from server's who are among the laziest and management is so horrible they don't care at all and are super fast to cut out and go home leaving all the unfinished work to someone else
Advice to Management: Be better at understanding or at least listen to workers and try and evenly spread the employees so No one is behind or frustrated especially in the dish pit one person constantly and constantly walks into a million dishes and no help

Title: "Good environment"
Pros: good boss and people. Customers are fun. Takes almost no time to learn the menu and the tips are decent
Cons: menu changes quite often. Stays open later than most restaurants. Hard to upsell. Sometimes have to work without busser, food runner, and host

Title: "Learn all you can!"
Pros: + $0.50 for every new station you learn, but you have to perfect it.
Cons: It's a kitchen job. If you don't have the personality for it, don't do it.

Title: "Good job to have in college, but not long term"
Pros: Flexible hours, easy to set your schedule, easy to request days off
Cons: Managers come and go so quickly each has a different way to manage it's hard to have a consistent work environment, managers often belittle the staff
Advice to Management: Encourage your staff don't belittle them, have more team building exercises so it doesn't turn into a high school popularity contest where there is less team work yet more drama , have the management all on one page by being consistent to what is of top priority and what is secondary and so on and so forth

Title: "Overall good, although a TON of change at above restaurant level leadership"
Pros: Just a great company to work for. I have had a great 10+ year job that has allowed me to meet a ton of people. The pay is good, the company has a good work life ratio on paper (more on that in the cons) and for the most part, upper leadership are top notch PEOPLE, not just bosses.
Cons: Occasional disconnect at AD level. That is the biggest issue I have had. Work life separation is non existent to some of them. Phone calls on days off when your restaurant is running great numbers. I would ALMOST understand the harassment if you were under performing, but some of them can't leave their GMP team be. Almost like they are looking to try to push you out.
Advice to Management: Better vetting of AD level position. Yes, results matter, but not at the expense of the company culture.

Title: "server"
Pros: fun and profitable job that still allowed me to go to class and study and be successful; very fast paced and upbeat environment
Cons: rude customers and long hours
Advice to Management: n/a

Title: "It's a job. An insecure one, but a job."
Pros: You make money based on how well your customer service skills are, as is with any hospitality job. There are small incentive programs that make work more fun, and the service staff is comprised of very awesome people. I would recommend this job to someone that has previous hospitality experience.
Cons: Poor training. New hires with minimal to no hospitality experience never made it longer than two months. The training program appears to have been designed thoughtfully with a fun and humorous tone to help new hires, but becomes complex and confusing, making it difficult for new hires to grasp, especially when it is administered by unconcerned servers/ bartenders that want to rush through the steps and get back to their jobs. Also, the menu is constantly changing, constantly making the older menus and training guides outdated. This makes it confusing for a new hire who is learning about old sandwiches that are not on the menu anymore, instead of learning about the new ones that are. Management seems to be more involved with checking on tables for negativity to throw at the employees, than spending time with them engaging, encouraging, teaching, training, and developing. Also, management is quick to let employees go without necessary documentation (i.e. counseling, written notices, suspension, etc.) which may hurt one day when you find an employee intelligent and determined enough to seek legal advice about being improperly terminated after one year of employment without any prior counseling.
Advice to Management: Become more involved with your staff and ensure that training is completely understood by new hires, and everyone is in sync with current menu items and promotions, without being too critical if they don't know everything on the second day. Remember, you're going to be questionable and stressed out jumping out of a plane, if you're not completely sure of how to use the parachute.
