Title: "Worst job I've ever had...and I've shoveled goat manure for a living."
Pros: Those who worked in the front of the house seemed slightly happier with their jobs than those of us at the back. Though I couldn't tell you for sure. They did make more money. It's not a bad place to eat, I never saw food being handled unsafely or bad product being used. Health insurance was available, which is why I stayed as long as I did.
Cons: Hired as prep cook, when I started there were three people making/portioning a list of well over 100 items during a shift, in addition to prepping things on the fly for the cooks. Absolutely no breaks. When I started there and asked about breaks they looked at me like I was insane. I was told I could take one if asked but was pressured never to take even a five minute breather. Work was expected to be finished in 8 hours but it usually took 9-10, and that is with three people. One of them was training me so that she could move to another store, so then it was down to two of us. Then our workdays were divided so that only one prep person was working on any given day. All items were expected to be finished in the same amount of time anyway, and I was lectured and written up for taking 12-14 hours to complete what took three people 8-10 hours to finish. They could not understand why I couldn't do it. I worked as hard as I could...I was hungry and tired all day, treated like a servant, frequently ignored when I asked for help lifting a 100lb bag of potatoes or finishing up dishes at the end of the night when I was ready to drop.
Advice to Management: Make breaks a requirement where employees have to punch in and out for them so that management has no choice but to schedule employees for at least a meal break or a fifteen minute break. Adjust expectations of how much a single person can do in a particular length of time, and add additional help when additional work is added.

Title: "Good experience."
Pros: Nice work environment, good tips if you work in week ends. Flexible schedule, hours that work for you!Overall a positive experience if you like this type of job.
Cons: Long hours where you have to stand all the time during your shift, rude customers. They expect you to work really hard, no breaks.
Advice to Management: Set more reasonable goals and allow breaks for more than 4 hours shift.

Title: "Work Lifestyle"
Pros: Chilis was always nice about allowing the ability pick up shifts to make extra cash. People are always friendly.
Cons: Being new at chilis can be a con since you would have to start off with cruddy sections.
Advice to Management: Keep up the good work and keep the training program going.

Title: "Chili's overall is a great place to work after you earn your spot"
Pros: Great Atmosphere when everything is going the manager way
Cons: Attitudes and they keep you at a stand still for a long time before promotion

Title: "Great Concept, poorly executed."
Pros: Great money if you're great at turning and burning tables, the culture and overall concept is fun and exciting, every chili's has its strong regulars. sales competitions quarterly top seller wins prizes. great team service policies for more efficient work environment.
Cons: No bussers, so you're expected to do it you're self. it's ok at slow location but if it's busy you're weeded. Ticket times are long and by the time they finish the order the first item is dead. during competitions no real recognition for everyone else busting butt to sell. management has no care for the guests till there is a problem. management doesn't enforce team service policies which in turn leads to crappy service then cheap guests who know if they complain enough they'll get free food.

Title: "Great Brand, Great Culture, Plenty of room for improvement."
Pros: Great people, very innovative re-imaging, great food and established brand. Well-oiled machine when Team Service is truly implemented. Great culture and concept which creates a fun work environment, which in turn translates to great customer experience. Decent pay (tips) and plenty of opportunities to move forward within the company. Food discounts and fun promotions.
Cons: If one part of the team fails, the machine falls apart. Management seems pressured to run bare-bones, and team members usually have to pick up the slack, which creates a disconnect in trust between management and staff. Difficulties prioritizing staff needs versus business needs, and poor utilization of staff strengths and weaknesses at times. Difficulties in consistent scheduling and a lot of inconvenient last-minute schedule changes.
Advice to Management: Chili's has a great concept in place, and people who really believe in the long-standing culture. As long as management sincerely shares this with the team members, things work great. When they fall apart though, it's bad, really bad.

Title: "Love Chili's!"
Pros: Chilis truly is a family. Flexible scheduling. Plenty of time to request days off. I ended up leaving chilis for another job at a golf course and didn't even make it a month before I went back. Management at my first store changed fairly quickly but slowed down at one point. The job is demanding but I was never ridiculed for making mistakes.
Cons: Long nights at work. Like any other restaurant job. If you don't like fast paced then you shouldn't pick this job or any other restaurant. Tips in Togo suck. But hourly wage isn't bad!
Advice to Management: Keep it up! We are all a family

Title: "Decent place to work if you are good at serving tables."
Pros: If you are likable and management can trust you, you will be favored with better sections and more flexibility on scheduling.
Cons: People in Utah Valley don't tip well typically. Lot's of internal drama that you will see with every restaurant. Sleeping around, favoritism, table floating etc....
Advice to Management: Come down hard on the sneaky stuff some employees do with bribing hostesses, giving away free stuff in order for a higher tip etc...

Title: "Eh experience"
Pros:
Decent hours
50% off shift meals (though it's only from an approved list of foods)
Not too hard at all
Cons:
Low pay
Lazy servers
Management overlooked a lot of major things about their employees
Silly managers who don't believe in a wait time (??!!!)
Management was way too relaxed
Advice to Management: If an employee isn't living up to the company expectations, get rid of them. They hurt everyone!

Title: "Great management, flexible schedule, decent tips"
Pros: Great management, flexible schedule with good support from managers. Not responsible for walk outs so there's a big plus.
Cons: Tips are ok but steady. Clientele are sometimes not great but that's to be expected.

Title: "Love it!"
Pros: Great people and good money! Typical shift is around six to seven hours! Management works with your schedule! Good food and it gets busy every day!
Cons: The costumers sometimes all show up at once and it can get a little crazy! The food can sometimes take a while and service can start to lack because of the rush!
Advice to Management: Maybe hire a lunch shift and night shift busser to cut down on it time for costumers during the rush!

Title: "good"
Pros: nice managers friendly personable understanding funny
Cons: unorganized lack of communication awkward inconsistant
Advice to Management: organize

Title: "Great Place to Work during college or part-time"
Pros: Flexible schedule, numerous locations make it easy to transfer
Cons: low chance for promotion, dead-end career, low end of restaurant industry.
Advice to Management: too many changes back to back, not enough incentive to meet goals.

Title: "Good job to have until the next one"
Pros: Overall, a fun place to work. Decent money for the area and flexibility with scheduling. Management comes from within so most situations are dealt with by experienced leadership.
Cons: Clientele are pushy, rude, and have a tremendous sense of entitlement. Business is ALWAYS busy and customers are generally irritable and are extremely difficult to please

Title: "Amazing"
Pros: Hours and staff are great
Cons: currently we are short staffed but otherwise no complaints.

Title: "Ok team service, and HORRIBLE management!"
Pros: The food is good, where I worked was very clean. I wasn' t qualified for benefits till a year of working there. The team service was good if you were a server. As far as a bartender or QA no help what so ever in running food or cleaning THEIR tables.
Cons: It was very disturbing what went on at this Chili's location. Two of the managers were having affairs with employees and it even went to corporate and they still stayed there and swept it under the rug leaving the team members to be treated like crap for letting corporate know what was going on in this restaraunt. Running so low on staff putting new people on bar that were not even trained for the position. The hours are crap to make a living.
Advice to Management: Listen to employees and put more professional people in the management jobs! Having affairs with cooks and servers while being a manager?

Title: "It's all alright"
Pros: It's nice to be able to walk out with a chunk of cash at the end of every shift, and if you get along with your team members it's fun to work there. At coors i40 you can walk out on a weekday with at least $100, and on the weekends even more. Scheduling is semi-flexible, and most managers are super cool.
Cons: G.M.'s are mostly full of bull. Corporate is about the bottom line, not the people, they don't care what you do or how you do it, just keep your comps down and sales up. There are super stupid contests they have quarterly, even if you win you won't win anything. You could come in at 3:00 to open dinner and end up closing on the map, meaning you won't get out until midnight or later. Be prepared, a lot of customers are jerks too.
Advice to Management: Help the servers out. Quit hiding in the office, or talking to your buddies at the bar, help us do our job by doing yours. To upper management: we are humans, not mules or robots, remember that when pushing us on our bottom lines.

Title: "Management"
Pros: Fun upbeat place to work. Company that's innovated that fosters a win together atmosphere. Promotes from with in.
Cons:
Labor rules are tough to beat.
Have had great experiences and some not so good it all depends on your market.
Advice to Management: Get your hands dirty.

Title: "Serving position at Chili's grill and bar"
Pros: Opportunity to manage your own income based on your how hard/efficiently you are willing to work, flexible scheduling, good for college students.
Cons: Long hours, no base pay, employee will often have to deal with picky or difficult customers. GEM surveys.

Title: "Wait table and clean restaurant"
Pros: Pay based on my work ethic and workable hours.
Cons: The shifts can be late hours.

Title: "Good company to work for."
Pros: Flexible schedule. Good bonus.
Cons: Not really open to feedback. Want yes men .
Advice to Management: Upper management should do N undercover boss episode. Maybe 2

Title: "Great people, hit or miss customers"
Pros: Flexible hours are always great. The job is fairly simple. The money is decent. The location is wonderful.
Cons: You never know what to expect as far as customers, tips, etc. Sometimes you get 10%, sometimes you get 20%, but in the end I guess it all evens out. Sometimes management's mood is taken into the workplace.
Advice to Management: Leave your bad mood at the door. Keep being flexible with the schedule and allowing other servers to pick up shifts as needed. Maybe allow a little overtime.

Title: "Good Money for a college student or recent college grad looking for a career."
Pros: Flexble hours, fun atmosphere, get paid cash every shift you work, company offers insurance plans (not good though) Company promotes within. If you aspire to become a manager or bartender then prove your abilities to management and let your aspirations and goals be known. Great for a 2nd job or weekend job, 1/2 off your check when visiting other Brinker Restaurants, Constant feedback from guests survey's so you know what works and what needs improvment. Great charity work especially for St. Jude's Children's Research Hospital, and give back nights. Large sections to maxamize your income and incentives to sell promotional items. I was lucky enough to work with mostly amazing managers
Cons: Long hours with no breaks (if working a double straight through) Some stores have excellent managers but I have worked with terrible managers which makes the shift a nightmare. Having to follow franchise rules "perfect 10" to every table in fear of being secret shopped. Gem should not determine how well a store is doing. I understand the importance but it should not be the be all end all. Employees have a very limited menu to choose from if they want to pay 1/2 off their meal for break. Horrible insurance plans for part-time, full-time, and managers. Every store is different but if you have a terrible manager you know the shift is not going to be fun/organized.
Advice to Management: Keep doing the great charity work, especially for St. Jude's. The Brinker Family Fund is an amazing program and should always remain part of Brinker. Lighten up a little bit when it comes to GEM, sometimes it's hard to get people to go home and fill out surveys. Management crew should be consistent when it comes to policy, I've seen conflicting policies for closing duties and other policies between diffrent managers. One manager would get upset because you did something that the previous manager instructed you to do. Overall I think Chili's is a great job w/ potential to make it a career if you want to however, the insurance plans are just awful.

Title: "made good money"
Pros: hours money and freedom paid vacations insurance
Cons: corporate restaurant b.s., bad guests = bad days at work
Advice to Management: Stop appeasing every guest that walks through the door. sometimes the customer is not always right and are just trying to get free meals. Quit being scared of the threat of race based lawsuits.

Title: "Not a pleasant experience"
Pros: In the 2 years that I was there, I learned the entire kitchen and there were no benefits of doing so.
Cons: The pay wasn't really that great, the scheduling was horrible. The management lacked communication. Other cooks were lazy. Everything was different for every employee.

Title: "very good company"
Pros: flex schedule and pretty decent training
Cons: pay should be higher than it is
Advice to Management: treat employees at least as well customers

Title: "Review"
Pros: Great company to work for.
Cons: I don't have any cons.

Title: "Horrible customers, near impossible expectations & long hours"
Pros: Money was decent- anywhere from $10/hr to $20+. Depends on night + section scheduled. Great coworkers. My store was a cohesive unit (for the most part) that took teamwork seriously. We all threw job titles aside to get the job done. Servers helped wash dishes, line cooks would help bus tables, etc.
Cons:
The clientele is hideous. Expect to be cursed at, threatened and basically treated like crap. The police department was called so many times to handle irrational guests that they basically refused to answer our calls and we hired a private security firm.

You will be expected to run a 5-9 table section without proper supplies. Essentials like having clean silverware are a rarity. Normally I'd arrive for my shift and have to immediately wash, sort, re-wash and roll silverware. That's while you're getting quadruple sat, have no clean cups, plates, ice or tea brewed fresh. Absolute nightmare. At the end of your shift, you had to roll an additional 100 pieces of silver on top of your 1-2 hours sidework.

Keep in mind Chilis runs LOW labor. There's one dishwasher at MOST. Usually Mon-Fri Lunch you wash dishes yourself. Servers do ALL of the cleaning besides the line. This means all front of house (clean tables, booths, floors, etc.) plus a majority of the line including kitchen floors, all beverage stations, etc. As a closer on a Saturday night, expect to arrive at 3:30 and leave at 2:30 AM with about $120 in tips if you're lucky.
Advice to Management: Give the employees the supplies they need and stop punishing servers for bad GEM scores. It's not the server's fault if a guest complains about the noise volume of the dining room or how under cooked their Ribeye is, or that their Country Fried Steak is fried!

Title: "If it sounds to good to be true ..."
Pros: competitive enviroment and room for upward mobilty
Cons: inconsistant culture, selective policies, and inconsistant guest experience

Title: "Easy Job"
Pros: It's easy and fun. All my coworkers were great.
Cons: Fast paced. Some coworkers tried to get tables in your section to make more money.

Title: "Fun place and fast cash! BUT....."
Pros: Great staff, consistent strong sales while in season, 50% off all Brinker locations on your days off, minimal micro management (managers really just let you run your own section), very easy menu, next to nothing tip out, fun environment, non profit account set up so you can donate money for co workers in time of need, online training, very very very good at scheduling, plenty of stores to transfer to, extremely easy job in case you're ever hungover.
Cons: Basing your company on dirt cheap prices does not always make a business thrive and neither does the motto "the customer is always right." Chili's brand has certainly gone down in recent years and has even been realized as a joke place in movies. As a company that used to compete well in the casual dining market, to date, they seem to rely on price points, round numbers, as well as cutting the fat to save every cent possible. You almost feel embarrassed saying you work here and you can thank the 2 for $20 for the run down decor and equipment of the restaurant. I doubt Chili's will be in business by the time inflation hits food prices hard. It's a shame they look so broke but they have to save every cent to make any money at all off their flagship product. The 2 for $20 will be the number one thing you sell by the way, and it will make your blood boil serving it to people who don't understand proper restaurant etiquette. Your clientele will consist of people who are extreme cheapskates and will be so rude because they don't get to go out often and take the opportunity to demand what they want. Customers also know that managers will do whatever the customer wants. I had a lady once ask for a discount, so when I asked if there was a problem she simply replied "because the customer is always right" so my manager discounted her 10 percent off. Your tips average 8-10% due to the higher end clientele going to better establishments. Your kitchen is also extremely incompetent and they base scheduling in the slow season off of your GEM score. (Basically a guest review of their experience) so if they had a problem with their food out of your control and admit that, you in turn will be blamed because it came up as a problem under your name, which isn't fair because it may not be your problem in the first place i.e kitchen mistake or food tasted bad.
Advice to Management: I have no advice to senior management at all, I just have hope. It's already a sinking ship and I just pray that you keep this vessel afloat long enough before the 2 for $20 goes bye bye.

Title: "Easy money and casual work atmosphere."
Pros: They offer really flexible work hours.
Cons: Male driven type of management
Advice to Management: Take leadership courses

Title: "Frustrating"
Pros: Good pay, learn new ways of doing things.
Cons: Horrible Health Ins. No balance of work and home

Title: "Crazy but fun!"
Pros: Nice coworkers, willing to help one another, friendly atmosphere
Cons: Gets really crazy at times, pay could be better, not enough hours
Advice to Management: Tip sharing with hostess

Title: "Went from good to terrible."
Pros: The best reasons to work at Chili's Too is honestly the coworkers. Funny, upbeat, optimistic, even when times weren't so good.
Cons: Management was terrible. Supplies constantly not stocked or ordered. Poor scheduling.

Title: "HORRIBLE"
Pros: Very nice co-workers thats is all.
Cons: Horrible management terrible pay the restaurant is covered in grease and filth the tables and booths are always covered in food from the table before and they treat the young employees like crap lying to them and giving them the worst shifts and making them do numerous jobs at once (which is always the managers extra work they dont feel like doing)
Advice to Management: Advice to corporate clean up and get management that actually cares about the good of the restaurant not managers who act certain ways to guests depending on their mood at the time.

Title: "Ok place to work"
Pros: The restaurant was always busy, so could make decent money.
Cons: Management very unorganized and customers very rude.

Title: "downhill..."
Pros: Not many pros by the time I left. It was a lot of fun to work there before they were franchised. Afterwards, the quality of food went down as did the clientele.
Cons: Company started caring more about the bottom line than the staff and work environment. They kept hiring more people and it became nearly impossible to get full time which made it cost more for benefits.
Advice to Management: Take the time to make your staff happy. Higher moral means a happier staff and happier customers.

Title: "Good environment, bad management."
Pros: Its an easy and casual job with potential to make some decent money serving. Its a job with money you can live off of while going to school or during a transition period.
Cons: There are no benefits to working here except for tips, which of course the company does not provide. They have a maximum amount of health insurance they provide to employees so most can't get insurance from here. I asked for health insurance coverage after working at least 30 hours a week for over a year and was told I would get my hours cut to 2 shifts a week so I wouldn't be eligible anymore.
Advice to Management: Take some consideration to your employees. You can't keep cutting what little perks there are to this job and expect your company to thrive through hardwork provided by your employees.

Title: "So much work, not enough money."
Pros: Cash in pocket daily. Make alot of life long friends. Tips arent too bad.
Cons: It has become nothing but saving as much money as possible. After the server is cut from the floor, expect to be there for atleast 2-3 more hours doing a ton of side work and on the clock for only 2.63 an hr. Management is a joke.
Advice to Management: Quality before money.

Title: "Not professional"
Pros: Making a lot in tips on busy days/nights.
Cons: Management, cheap customers and rolling silverware when you didn't make any money.

Title: "Bus Boy"
Pros: Great atmosphere and nice people really worked we'll with every one
Cons: The pay was kind of weak. I was expecting a little. It more but still worth jt
Advice to Management: Pay workers more

Title: "High pressure sales...heavy server work load"
Pros: I work at a high volume store so money is good! Easy to get time off or pick ups shifts when needed!
Cons: Bus your own tables, run your own food, running dish non stop, quarterly contest, constant coupons lowering check average, labor intensive for a server position compared to other restaurants!
Advice to Management: Servers can only do so much, so if you want amazing guest experience stop adding to the the work load of the server so they can have time with their guest!

Title: "Best Company Ever!!!!!"
Pros: Absolutely a wonderful company to work for!!!!
Cons: Dealing with no understanding customers

Title: "Good money"
Pros: Good money, and you will meet great people
Cons: Managers were childish, and annoying.
Advice to Management: hire a better management team

Title: "Franchise is not the way to go."
Pros: Relatively loose, fun fast atmosphere.
Cons: Pepper Dining restaurants are very different from Brinker (corporate) stores. Olympus Partners are only concerned with the bottom line, not the quality of the guest experience.
Advice to Management: Get a better understanding of quality. Quality of product, quality of life.

Title: "Work hard, get promoted."
Pros: Great discounts after you get your employee card, very flexible, and with hard work, you can move up quickly. You may transfer between stores very easily at almost any time.
Cons: Management his highly variable between stores, and play favorites. Very reluctant to give you a raise as a server, even after great performance.
Advice to Management: Schedule and promote by performance, not favorites.

Title: "Food Server"
Pros: Fast paced fun job. You can make money as a server in a Chili's, you just have to move fast and give the customers a reason to love you.
Cons: Times are tough, so people are not going out as much. While you will make money, you will have to budget carefully so that the lean times will not break you. My store in upstate NY was a tough place to make money in January.
Advice to Management: Take some time to teach your store managers the skill of coaching. There seems to be great opportunity to coach employees rather than just disciplining them when something goes wrong.

Title: "Good way to make quick money, not good in the long run"
Pros: Brinker International (the company that owns Chili's) has an excellent corporate structure. The training is awesome, they really strive to have very well integrated teams, and they're huge on feedback from all levels of employees. They are also super flexible with your schedule and managers work closely with you to help you out. And you only have to tip out 1% of your sales to the bartender.
Cons: They are so picky with who they hire that they have a hard time staying fully staffed.The way that they do sections (you can have 10 tables at a time) makes it really difficult to provide awesome customer service, and they hold you responsible for it. Also you work with a partner in your section, so if you partner is struggling then that can get you behind. So overall you'll make money because you have so many tables, but people can really be jerks because you just don't have time to pay attention to them as soon as they decide they need water.
Advice to Management: Figure out ways to hire more quickly so that sections can be a more manageable size for servers. Also don't hold servers responsible for subpar service when servers are given half of the dining room between them and their partner.

Title: "Its ok for a part time job, Could be worse could be better"
Pros:
-they seem to be upgrading their food menu in the right diretion.
-times you can make descent money
-Very friendly staff.
-Flexible scheduling
Cons:
-Alot of sidework for the job
-Clientele can be annoying at times
Advice to Management: Stop micromanaging us.

Title: "Waitressing at Chili's"
Pros: It's quick cash, customers are mostly nice, made good friends there.
Cons: Management does not respect servers. Long hours. You have to sell a certain amount of specific items or liquors and you get in trouble if you don't. Customers don't like liquor pushed on them.
Advice to Management: Have more respect and understanding.

Title: "Fun atmosphere, good tips"
Pros:
Good tips if busy
Management helpful when needed
Cons:
some execution problems
relationship between cooks and servers is not friendly

Title: "Busy"
Pros: Good money, flexible schedule, easy uniform
Cons: Work long hours and on your feet
Advice to Management: Be more understanding of school schedules

Title: "Server for 3 years"
Pros: Good flexibility if you are in school, easy to get shifts
Cons: Micro management, it's a serving job.
Advice to Management: Stop constantly changing expectations and ruining culture in the restaraunt

Title: "Learn the difference between SERVER and SERVANT.."
Pros: Flexible hours, friendly co-workers, benefits are available but not really worth it if you're in a tipped position. Room for growth, team work is enforced through a "team service" system.
Cons: Way too lenient with guests. Guests are allowed to use expired coupons, multiple coupons for one visit, which brings the check average down resulting in less money for the servers.
Advice to Management: Management should be more vigilant about using their discretion on a case by case basis and learn how to identify guests who repeatedly take advantage of the system because it directly effects the bottom line profit of the overall business.

Title: "It's alright for the meantime"
Pros: I make good money, the managers are pretty cool, it works with my schedule (most of the time)
Cons: The same cons as any other serving job
Advice to Management: Having to keep up with the BS like "Gem comments," "sales per hour," and "margarita contest sales" does not determine whether you are a good employee or not

Title: "Good for a first time job."
Pros: Hosting at Chili's is a good first time job and to get experience without it being too stressful of a job. You can work your way up the latter pretty easily if you are a hard worker.
Cons: The pay is horrible. the employees act like they are in high school and are very unprofessional. A lot of drama happens between people at Chili's.

Title: "Fun Place to Work"
Pros: Meet and interact with lots of people.
Cons: High turnover rate of employees
Advice to Management: More team building activities.

Title: "Working towards becoming fast food"
Pros: decent pay, understanding considerate in store management staff
Cons: weak training program, by cutting back starting wages greatly lowered quality of employees applying, the attempt to treat every employee as equal goes a bit too far, talking to a 2 week and a 10 year employee the same way is a bit ridiculous
Advice to Management: don't talk down to long term quality employees, up starting wages to stop getting fast food rejects, quit accepting and even encouraging mediocrity.

Title: "Decent"
Pros: friends, food is half off, i get movie passes for the local theater through them because of a deal they have.
Cons: other servers not doing their job, managers not listening to you, favoritism.
Advice to Management: i have school. you need to understand that, and don't.

Title: "Hostess"
Pros: Fun environment, great people to work with.
Cons: Pay based on tips and satisfaction of customers was based largely on server's performance not hostess.
Advice to Management: none

Title: "Nothing to special"
Employee Title: EVERYTHING BECAUSE WE WERE SO SHORT ON STAFF
Pros: The free food and pretty good pay
Cons: Managers were MEAN. co workers were rude...we all work at the same place nobody is better than anyone
Advice to Management: LISTEN TO YOUR EMPLOYEES!!!! WE ARE ON THE FRONT LINES

Title: "Working at Chili's is a typical restaurant management experience."
Pros: Experienced management and hourly staff. Stable company that will likely be around for a long time. Good job security.
Cons: Difficult to get promoted. not open to new ways of doing things.

Title: "Chilis server"
Pros:
fun enviornment
team work
organized
good money
good sections
work with you on schedule
Cons:
alternating management
run out of stock
Slow in the summer
negative employment
need more employees
Advice to Management: avoid stockouts

Title: "You definitely earn the money you make"
Pros: Quick Table Turnovers, Fast Paced environment (helps workday go by faster), high volume- always busy so your guaranteed to make at least 90-130 a night.
Cons: High employee turnover, low checks= low tips, a lot of extra side work, I seem to work so hard every night and leave with not enough for my efforts.
Advice to Management: schedule more servers and cooks on obvious busy nights instead of throwing us under the bus and we all end up suffering

Title: "Jack of all trades"
Pros: great atmosphere, decent pay (depending on what you position you are in)
Cons: ZERO quality of life for managers and key hourly

Title: "Chiliheads Rule!"
Pros: Fun Place to place to work! Great concept. Rapid store expansions planned, so lots of promotions..
Cons: Restaurant work is always hard but rewarding work.
Advice to Management: Its great to work for a restaurant that values the team members as much as the customers.

Title: "server"
Pros: great enviroment, family atmosphere and work with your schedule
Cons: at time incompetent management that has little experience, and wont fix the problem

Title: "Fun and flexible, as serving jobs go."
Pros: The always worked with my class schedules. It was an active job, so the time went by quickly (as long as we wer busy).
Cons: If you wanted the good money, you had to work the weekends. Lunch shifts weren't bad, but weekend nights were better.

Title: "Coworkers are great, but the customers can really bring you down."
Pros:
-Great coworkers
-Build friendships with coworkers
-Decent amount of money being made if you're a server
-Everyone that works here makes it feel like a family
-50% discount on days you work and 25% on days you don't
Cons:
-Customers can be very rude
-You start to feel like a punching bag for everyone
-Sometimes you feel like you give way more than you receive
-Old manager only ever told us what we were doing wrong, and never acknowledged what we did right
-Lunch shifts you may walk out with $8 dollars for two hours. (Varies)
Advice to Management: Don't just acknowledge what we do wrong, but show that we are doing things right and well also. This would definitely make me want to work harder.

Title: "Great company to work for."
Pros: the people, the company, 401-k
Cons: lots of work but great money, horrible customers
Advice to Management: make your employees happy and they will want to do well for you

Title: "Relaxed environment but always short on employees in all areas"
Pros:
Chill Management
super flexible
easy uniform (Jeans and black polo)
If you express interest in moving up and work hard you are likely to be moved into management in less than 2 years
Cons:
No food runners and bussers
2 for 20 and other deals make for a lot of work for low check averages which equals small tip averages
Advice to Management: Please staff more kitchen personnel so that guest complaints and high ticket times go down

Title: "Team service good, management iffy"
Pros:
Team service when taking care of your guests
Option to pool but not necessary because not a pool house
Good money
Management tries to work with your schedule
Cons:
Management staff not always supportive
Not everyone is held to the same standard within the same positions
Holidays and weekends are a must (any service position is the same)
Advice to Management: Hold your employees accountable even if you're their "friend" because it looks bad to other employees

Title: "Liked the people, not the pay"
Pros: I loved my fellow employees. We were all college students together, which made work more fun.
Cons: The pay was terrible and people don't understand tipping. It was not the company's fault, though.
Advice to Management: Take longer to train your employees, as some were much worse than others, and don't take just anyone who applies.

Title: "good and bad"
Pros: money was pretty good and co workers
Cons: managers stressed out way too muck
Advice to Management: don't stress out

Title: "Totally depends on the location"
Pros:
-You always get your money at the end of the night
-Camaraderie of the staff
-Flexible schedule
-People will come here no matter now terrible/unhealthy the food
Cons:
-Had a horrible manager that made the experience bad
-Customers can be really terrible
-Chili's always has large parties. It's terrible when they're a large party of kids that don't tip or try to stiff the bill
-due to taxes taken out of your paycheck, you'll never actually see a paycheck
Advice to Management: -the DM's should listen to the staff for a real account of how each location is doing

Title: "Good learning experience"
Pros: I learned so much and respect the quality and value this chain offers.
Cons: Tips were lower than expected

Title: "Dishwashing Sucks"
Pros: Nice people, chance for advancement, decent food.
Cons: Strenuous, annoying, tiring, boring work.

Title: "For a server job, it was pretty ok."
Pros: Flexible scheduling, decent tips (depending on location), and fun atmosphere
Cons: Long working hours and somewhat unrealistic shift goals
Advice to Management: Keep doing what you are doing, but be a bit more understanding of students' scheduling. Also, the surveys are a waste of time and are only pointed out to customers that the server feels will give a good review.

Title: "Proud to be a "Chilihead"."
Pros: This job can make your "weekend fun money" or pay bills while putting a kid through college before receiving a GED.
Cons: immature server staff;bad economy causing less business low tips

Title: "Luv"
Pros: Food is great perk yummy
Cons: Lazy employees, hired lazy people

Title: "Great Job, Great Team, and Lots of Flexibility!"
Pros:
-Lots of great team members... they become like family
-Great management-- most have moved up through the ranks
-Flexible scheduling for students
-Servers can make money on the fly
Cons:
-Like any job based on tips/commission, you aren't guaranteed a set amount
-Depending on your location, it can be hard to make decent money during lunch, unless you are a closer. Closers are typically staffed based on seniority, though newbies can switch shifts at times
-This isn't really a con, but to some it may be. Brinker concepts (like Chili's) went away from charging Gratuity to large parties years ago. Customers can take advantage of this... but servers did to, hence the change in policy.
Advice to Management: Remember your roots! ...and keep doing what you're doing.

Title: "Is there a place to mark less than 1 star (Chili's of Pace)?"
Pros: Sadly, there were no pros whatsoever.
Cons: Worst job that I ever worked at for a restaurant! Management was nonexistent, all the employees there hated each other because management pitted them against each other, hours were low, pay rate stunk, managers were liars, & did not care about their employees.
Advice to Management: Find a different line of work. You don't know how to manage a restaurant. Advice to someone thinking about working here: "Run" don't walk, to a different employer!

Title: "Horrible Quality of Life"
Pros: Salary, co workers, fun work environment. Lots of opportunity for advancement if willing to relocate. Industry leading kitchen equipment. Lots of great ideas, but lacking in the implementation
Cons:
Absolutely horrendous work/life balance. They expect you to live there 24/7.
Bonus structure has changed and it's almost impossible to bonus well anymore, even though your restaurant is making the company money.
Restaurant managers get the short end of the stick. Company is all about the hourly team members quality of life and work experience but doesn't seem to care about the managers.
Constant changes with many if them contradicting themselves over and over
Absolutely terrible benefits. Almost not even worth having the health insurance with the unbelievable deductibles
Too much emphasis on the MEE (My Employee Engagement) surveys. Even high po managers are in danger of losing their jobs over them even though there is no way to even control wether or not there is not cheating done on them
My Area Director was crazy. He showed favoritism. Went psycho crazy when our Regional Director would do his random announced visits which ended up being total dog and pony shows
Crazy budgets and goals to hit which are made by pencil pushers sitting at a desk only worried about pleasing the investors
As in any job, sometimes there is crazy back stabbing just to get ahead
Advice to Management: Quit screwing over your Restaurant Managers. If you are going to terminate managers over MEE Surveys, then put more security in place so they are more accurate. There is cheating both ways on these surveys. Disgruntled team members filling out multiples and unethical managers filling out multiple positive ones. Try to not contradict yourselves with the massive amounts of changes. Offer better health insurance and benefits. Change the bonus structure. Take it easy on the budgets and goals that are needed to succeed. Many goals are close to impossible to hit which is requiring the managers to be labor savers and not properly lead and also the restaurants not being staffed properly which is leading to poor guest service and restaurants not being cleaned properly. Many of your restaurants are profiting and making the company money, yet the managers are still not bonusing.

Title: "long hours"
Pros: good food - some great people
Cons: some of your days off you were required to come in for meetings or inventory.
Advice to Management: Think twice, they care more about the employees than you or the guest

Title: "Hours were terrible"
Pros: Great serving staff made it fun to work, and the other hosts were fun when on duty at the same time. No one can ever say they didn't give me enough hours...
Cons: I had requested a few days off, so they decided that the days I worked, I was going to work from 9 in the morning until 12 at night. The doors closed at 11, so I never really understood the point of keeping me until 12 when I had already done my cleaning during the slow, later hours. Also, on two of those 9 am-12 am days, they took my two hour lunch break away for various reasons. I'm pretty sure that's not even legal. Management turned over faster than the waitstaff.
Advice to Management: Don't insist on hiring only 3 hosts when there always had to be 1 in the restaraunt on normal hours and 2 on Friday and Saturday nights. It just doesn't make sense and we were horribly overworked. I signed up for a part-time job, not 40 hours/week plus overtime. Also, I actually made more at Chick-fil-a. They paid $.25 over minimum wage.

Title: "Challenging, frustrating, not easy."
Pros: Set in stone preparation procedures and recipes, never short on equipment, great people. The training materials are great and thorough, you will never be bored working for this company, and you can work any station you want and transfer to any store you want if approved by management.
Cons: Hours aren't always great unless you like working nights, labor management is intense, volume of select stores can get insane often without enough employees to handle it. The company was on a wage freeze while I was employed, so as one of the better employees I didn't have much incentive to stay or keep performing at my best because I made the same as everyone else regardless of how they performed.
Advice to Management: Loosen labor restrictions placed on kitchen managers to allow adequate scheduling. And reward good employees with a raise.

Title: "Horrible."
Pros: Better pay than fast food, great servers and people.
Cons: Management is horrible. Worst people to work with.
Advice to Management: Quit.

Title: "Good for students"
Pros:
Same day cash in your pocket as a server or bartender
Flexible schedule, will always try to work with you.
Fun atmosphere with managers and staff
Cons: Guests can be rude and inappropriate tips for hard work
Advice to Management: Don't try to win over everyone as soon as you start , servers will respect you if we know you're helpful and understand them

Title: "Poor"
Pros: Flexible hours, good online communication
Cons: Terrible management from regional managers to area directors to general managers. Constantly change management and each general manager they promote is worse then the previous one
Advice to Management: Hold area directors accountable for the terrible job they do with promoting managers.

Title: "Great Place to work"
Pros: Lots of opportunity, stable income, consistent work place, good benefit plans and fun atmosphere. Chili's is known to have a positive culture where staff tends to stay with the company long term.
Cons: Customer service isn't always pleasant.

Title: "Manager"
Pros: Fun environment and great team work
Cons: structure is a little lacking.
Advice to Management: create more structure throughout the brand.

Title: "Typical Restaurant Experience"
Pros: Decent money when it was busy. Good managers at the time. Friendly Employees
Cons: Can get quite slow, clientele can be iffy, get ready to work

Title: "Position met my expectations."
Pros: As a part-timer, the hours were generally flexible if there was a scheduling conflict (depending on the manager on duty). The restaurant has an overall great atmosphere.
Cons: Going home smelling like a restaurant! And the slip proof ugly shoes (safety before fashion). Also, it's very easy to get hooked on those delicious desserts.

Title: "Fun, fast paced work environment, with late hours."
Pros: Chili's does an excelent job training managers. They give you all the tools you need for success.
Cons: As a new manager to a very tenured management team, the hours I recieved were always late night hours.
Advice to Management: Place new managers in a team that will be open to haveing someone new, not with long time team members that have no desire to help teach or guide new managers.

Title: "Very corporate and organized."
Pros: There is an answer for everything and any situation you might encounter, so you don't have to worry about disappointing a customer in that regard. It is also nice that they run a "partner system" within the sections, so ideally at least one person is always there to help you. I was also fortunate to have managers that seemed to care about their employees and doing whatever they could in their power to make sure that everyone felt comfortable.
Cons: Because the company is so large, it doesn't give the server much room to be their own person. At times it felt very scripted and unnatural. The amount of selling you have to do with the customers can also be a bit uncomfortable. At times it felt like the servers were pushing options that were not wanted on the people who were dining.

Title: "Great company with great benefits"
Pros: flexible hours, great benefits, great culture
Cons: having to declare all tips
Advice to Management: make upward mobility more obtainable

Title: "Only Part-time, but enjoy the work experience"
Pros: Management is awesome, food is great, co-workers are friendly
Cons: Attitudes when restaurant gets busy from co-workers occasionally
Advice to Management: More productivity from front house/back house managers

Title: "Great place to work if you're fit for it."
Pros: Easy dress code. Super flexible hours. You tip out the bartender and maybe the busser but you keep all tips after that. Get paid in cash every single shift.
Cons:
When Chili's isn't busy you don't make money. Some people don't know how to tip.

You're doing a lot of things at once; greeting tables, taking orders, possibly taking togo orders, busing tables, running food, helping your partner.

Title: "poorly managed. Striving for mediocrity. Places corporate efficiency over customer service."
Pros: It was a very simple job to get. Although I left, almost immediately.
Cons: Poor pay, poor upper management. Corporate seems to have little understanding of how industry works on the ground level. Managers who contradict each other and lose their cool in public.
Advice to Management: Be better.

Title: "One of the best brands with the best leadership in the industry."
Pros: Open to feedback. A big company that still acts like a small one. Great food quality and manager training programs. Stays current with food trends.
Cons: Growth is coming at a slow pace. Which can be a good thing as well.

Title: "Management does not take care of employees like they should."
Pros: It is one of the only restaurants in the city
Cons: Poor salary, Will not give the hours that are promised when hired

Title: "Great Company!"
Pros: Awesome food discounts, reasonable schedule times if you had something going on, decent pay.
Cons: Management can step on toes, other servers not pulling their weight, you have to run their food

Title: "Hourly team members would like to work here"
Pros: great food, great margaritas, great guests
Cons: long hours, loosing too many of company's biggest fans over the last few years
Advice to Management: Hourly team members are important and valuable but so are the salaried team members

Title: "Disapointing"
Pros: Co-workers were fun and hard working. Lots of free time on shift.
Cons: Senior management is dissapointing and has a hard time finding positives for employees. Terrilbe shift schedules if you were "in trouble". Junior management is very inexperienced. No buisness.
Advice to Management: Treat your employees better. Team unity and happy workers= a better experience for customers.

Title: "It's a decent job for beginners in the restaurant industry"
Pros:
Flexible hours
Relaxed dress code
Very busy
Giving with food
Cons:
Low pay for many
Understaffed
Disorganization
Unprofessional
Horrible sanitation
Constant push for higher performance with no accomadtion
Advice to Management: Many of you need to take responsibility for your actions and stop putting all the work and blame on the employees. Stop cutting hours and lying about reasons why the restaurants are understaffed to add to your bonuses and lastly, learn to appreciate the hard workers, by logic, not favoritism. Otherwise, Chili's while profitable, will never be capable of maintaining employees, and in the end, will be forced to pick their game up or suffer an abysmal, economical fail...

Title: "easy hire - bad mgmt and scheduling - selfish co-workers"
Pros: easy entry level job with different options, fast to learn, moderate to good food, flexible work schedules, semi friendly co-workers,
Cons:
management is unapproachable and avoids you, conflicting and contradicting information on how to get your concerns and requests for help heard.
Let go without actually being told!!!!

I was hired with little history of working in the restaurant industry. As it was my first job with a chain restaurant they said I will be trained and start off with the To-Go phone in and take out conunter to learn the register and menu items.

The interview contained a lot about how working there is like family but it turns out that this family is using and cheating on one another.
My trainers I worked alongside for the entire shifts did either not share the tip jar with me or only gave me less then a 1/4 of what we both accumulated. So much about equal sharing for equal work.

After training period was over the different on duty managers as well as franchise owner and scheduling manager told me different ways on how to communicate my availability in order to be scheduled for regular shifts.
I ended up not being scheduled for literally weeks as I followed anyones rules on how to make that clear when I could work but it seemed that none was the right way.
When I stopped by in the almost empty restuarants during the day here and there I was just shoved out of the way by management on duty - had no time to talk.

I finally got the whole run down by scheduling manager and called her as requested before a deadline just to be not scheduled again.

The final straw was that I was NOT told that I was let go - but rather when I signed in to the online scheduling request website my profile was gone When I tried using their corp. website to look up my previous paystubs my user ID was no longer recognized period.
Guess that's their way to tell people you're out???
Advice to Management: don't tell staff you have open door policy but then ignore them when they need you

Title: "They don't appreciate their servers."
Pros: Great money, fast paced and a lot of fun.
Cons: Very little room for advancement. Unrealistic expectations.

Title: "its a ok place to work"
Pros: they are flexible to work around your schedule hours
Cons: not work appreciation at wherever you do and their pay rate is low and they do not worry about you eating a meal for your entire shift
Advice to Management: they need to be able to encourage people to be their best at their work

Title: "dissapointing"
Pros: easy if you don't care about fairness or values
Cons: culture is BS, no accountability for your workers, or boss, total accountability from you for everything, even when you aren't there!
Advice to Management: walk the talk

Title: "Great place to work while in college"
Pros: If you are a student this company is a good one to work for. Flexible schedule, night, and weekend shifts available
Cons: Very little room for advancement. high turnover, late nights, the per person average is low so you really need to be able to turn tables in order to make money

Title: "Love Chili's"
Pros: Great place to work..nice pay...flexible schedule
Cons: Too much drama between employees

Title: "A great place to work if you like to be micromanaged."
Pros: With being such a large company, they have nice benefits. Another benefit of having numerous locations would be the ease of transferring if need be. They do a great deal of promoting from within, which is great.
Cons: Lack of culture and work/life balance. Micromanaging to an extreme.
Advice to Management: In my 4 years there as a manager. we had 3 different Area Directors. There is always a reason for turnover, if you want to see it. I always felt that suggestions for improvement fell on deaf ears. Though promoting managers from within is great, it really limits any possible positive ideas from other concepts due to them not having any. Maybe, instead of hiring or promoting managers that need to be micromanaged Brinker should spend some energy hiring managers that can think and act for themselves.

Title: "Fun"
Pros: Tips , fun atmosphere, good hours
Cons: Poor mgmt. , weekend nights, poor tips
Advice to Management: Less micro mgmt

Title: "Good money, lots of drama and bad management"
Pros: Good money for no education
Cons: Bad hours, over worked, can be conned by management easily
Advice to Management: Train your management team better, and promote based on performance, not experience.

Title: "Great Company. Good Reputation. Training Program is good."
Pros: Fast paced. Free Meals. Great Customer Base.
Cons: Some Managers do not know how to manage.
Advice to Management: Teach Managers to be more hands on when managing.

Title: "Not a bad company to work for. Management is really good, and customers are friendly (with exceptions)."
Pros: Nice personnel, good starting pay
Cons: Takes too long to advance

Title: "Great job for college students"
Pros: Great job and people who will be there to help.
Cons: During football season it can get busy, but you make lots of money.
Advice to Management: No advice. There is well rounded management staff that has a balance of personalities for any type of worker.

Title: "Loved it!"
Pros: Energetic, fun atmosphere, great employees.
Cons: Sales drop in summer (college town)
Advice to Management: Have Town Hall meeting with non-management employees

Title: "Server"
Pros: Flexible, you'll make lifelong friends, you can make awesome money if you work in the right area
Cons: Annoying customers, long hours, annoying customers......... annoying customers.

Title: "Chance to make some good money, depending on management"
Pros: Good, good money to make, you just have to take to the time to learn the menu and get used to the computer system, and taking 5-8 tables at a time.
Cons: Can be hard at first, and customers will not always be understanding. You just have to give your best and make sure they see that. Can be lots of drama with staff, stressfull shituations and whatnot.
Advice to Management: Dont give up on a drama-less employees

Title: "chilis"
Pros: good pay,nice people abd good food.
Cons: no advancement,bad benefits upper management has no clue.
Advice to Management: look more into your operations

Title: "Good experience"
Pros: Best way to make money while working your way through college
Cons: Busy store - must be willing to work hard

Title: "Not a bad place to work"
Pros: A lot of benefits, even for part time employees
Cons: Under staffing has become the goal in saving money
Advice to Management: maintain more cooks on the line

Title: "Great company to work for"
Pros: Great teamwork, awesome managers, very positive and upbeat atmosphere.
Cons: not enough money, no opportunity to advance in workplace
Advice to Management: Be able to advance in work place

Title: "Extrapolating Chili's"
Pros: Well Run, professional, respectable starting wage, easy room for advancement.
Cons: Inherent heirarchy, many workers (station trainers included) speak next to no english. No lienecy given even in training (particularly for cooks). Speed is favored over efficiency. Continuous pressure to prepare meals ASAP.
Advice to Management: Overall Chili's is run efficiently. However in terms of training in other more technical positions more specificity is needed. Managements perspective was that repetition with trainers would correct all errors. But if making a dozen different dishes nightly knowing the exact portions would be key.

Title: "Rewarding and Fun"
Pros: Room to grow professionally if you show interest, good core values and culture. Wonderful training program if you are willing to learn and apply yourself. Pretty consistent shifts. Loved the recent remodel and transition to ALOHA POS. A lot of employee outings every year, like the "Chili's Trainer Olympics" and the rafting trip. Loved being able to work with St. Jude every year. Constantly have margarita contests and it's nice to have a little friendly competition between co-workers and all of the other restaurants in the brand.
Cons: A LOT of coupons and money-saving deals. Although it brings in guests who would not normally come in, it hurts the income for servers and bartenders. Worry too much about labor costs. No bussers and hosts aren't always available, especially during the lunch shifts. Servers and bartenders are responsible for greeting guests at the door during the daytime and can sometimes get overwhelming if it's busy.

Title: "Hard Work, small pay off"
Pros:
room for growth
part-time benefits offered
good food discount
Cons:
poor management
high stress
harsh on erros
Advice to Management: If you want to stop the high turnover rate, pay employees what they deserve for the work they do!

Title: "Managers are Labor Savers NOT managers"
Pros: compensation, extra day off for birthday an anniversary
Cons:
Managers are used to prep, do dishes, cook, QA...not coach or lead others
60-70 hour work weeks with little-no weekend days off
Non-existent Quality of Life
Blurry future as upper management is not clear on rollouts or communications
Constant last-minute changes to budget plans, making it hard to hit your bonus
Advice to Management:
You can keep changing plans, you can keep coming at us with new goals like BRGs (which DON'T pay the bills), but someone is still going to have to prep and it is always the manager. During my 60 hour work weeks, I spend 90% of that cooking or prepping and I'm not the only manager in my area that deals with this frustration. You brag about hiring talented leaders...use them to LEAD and coach. We are stuck in function ALL day.

There are also some locations that are still making lots of money for the company (mine) and we are still getting yelled at for BRGs and guest satisfaction scores. If a location is up double digits and beating their labor percentage...realize that THESE factors affect the bottom line...and thank me for your inflated bonuses.

Our culture used to be what stood us apart...that is no longer true. We haven't heard anything/preached anything in 2 years.

Start promoting the managers you say you will, follow through on promises, get the prep tool fixed (always a bug) and realize that MenuLink is not a cure-all.

Title: "Grill"
Pros: Fast paced, unorganized, lacking preparation for busy night.
Cons: management quick to cut staff, always leaving you short handed.

Title: "Ahead of the pack"
Pros: Making changes to become the best in their segment of the industry
Cons: Lots of micro management on business plans and rules
Advice to Management: Become a partner with your GMP's

Title: "Strong established company, restaurants are always busy"
Pros: potential for great tips, benefits In some locations
Cons: Hard to get days off. Can't call in sick
Advice to Management: Let employees know about growth and promotion potential

Title: "I enjoyed working at Chili's."
Pros: Managers were very flexible with my school schedule and transferring. I never had a problem getting my needs met, and always enjoyed the people I worked with.
Cons: Some of the guests are very difficult to work with. $6 lunch combos make it difficult to earn money, and the focus on speed over service was sometimes frustrating.
Advice to Management: Focus on quality over speed.

Title: "restaurant business"
Pros: This restaurant provided a fun atmosphere and was very good about working with my schedule. The management team was approachable and understanding.
Cons: Compensation in my opinion is poor. Mandatory "tip outs" to bartenders and busers was unfair, especially when it was calculated from percentage of sales.

Title: "Manager"
Pros: Great Training Process for managers
Cons: Benefits - need some improvement to be competitive in the market

Title: "fun environment to place to work"
Pros: you can choose hrs you work
Cons: management is not always consistant

Title: "It was fun"
Pros: Great people, good food, nice discount
Cons: upper management can be a pain
Advice to Management: When you have good, reliable employees who tell you something about the store or guests and another employee take them seriously.

Title: "Servers = servants of the restaurant"
Pros: Good money on weekends. Generally all of the food is good. The fellow TMs are usually fun and when MGT allows, can have a great time.
Cons: Too much back work, MGT takes advantage of servers low hourly rate. Unreachable goals such as sales/hr, guests/hr, and earnings/hr. Unreachable because of the amount of extra hours that is spent doing back work and rolling silverware is sometimes just as long (or longer) than the time spent actually serving tables. MGT plays favorites and gives better shifts to favorites. MGT stresses GEM comments and good numbers to obtain good shifts, but does not follow through. Dirty plates/cups/silverware. MGT not helpful in fixing problems.
Advice to Management: Servers are the face of the restaurant, don't overwork them where they don't enjoy working there.

Title: "Chili's is more than just a job, you get to make a difference with St. Jude's: truely phenomenal!""
Pros: The training is great! Corporate really cares and helps provide servers/bartenders with extraordinary training.
Cons: Management sometimes sounds scripted. Corporate trains them to answer each scenario with a script.
Advice to Management: Remember that the employees are PEOPLE. Keep it real, knock of the "corporate says to answer this question this-a-way" bs- we can see right through that. Remember to be compassionate.

Title: "It was ok."
Pros: Learn a little bartending and how to work in a team
Cons: Too much gossip, bad trainers.
Advice to Management: Need better trainers.

Title: "Not bad"
Pros: Depends on management, had some terrible managers and some great ones
Cons: Pretty cheap company. MAke servers make sacrifices to fix management's mistakes.

Title: "Easy Money"
Pros: Easy money, some days I've walked out with over 200 in a 4 hr. shift. Never a day where I left with less than minimum wage.
Cons: Inconsistent, might have one day making 200 then the next you only make 30. Shifts are not guaranteed, and there is a lot of drama between staff. They do not pay attention to employees availability or requested days off.
Advice to Management: Listen to staff more

Title: "Great business environment"
Pros: fun culture, frequent menu updates
Cons: busy on the weekends, not a lot of growth opportunities

Title: "This company is one of the best to work for"
Pros: Management is really understanding, and you learn a lot about the real world and society
Cons: The pay as a server sometimes is hard to live with

Title: "Good company"
Pros: Work conditions, product, flexibility in schedule
Cons: Development potential, lots of unnecessary change

Title: "hey Ya'll"
Pros: this is a really great place to work. I have a friend who works here too and she loves it too.
Cons: I wish we could get paid more! but then again that is what everyone wishes for.
Advice to Management: I really appreciate working here.

Title: "Great 3 year experience with Chilis"
Pros:
-Good Money
-Good Training Program
-Fun, fast-paced environment
Cons:
-Long nights
-A lot of extra side work beyond serving

Title: "excellent"
Pros: for fun awesome fun and drinks
Cons: some employee do work hard to better the company
Advice to Management: need to appreciate the good employees you have

Title: "Overall very happy"
Pros: You work long hours so the people you work with turn into family, it was fun, fast paced and upbeat environment. Love working with customers and people one on one and training. Money is pretty good too!
Cons: Long hours with minimal breaks no time to eat, rude customers , GEM comments being the only form of recognition or not, non appreciative managers and management playing favoritism.
Advice to Management: Listen to your employees and have an actual open door policy, if you're going to enforce a rule enforce it to everyone.

Title: "Loyalty not rewarded... must read before working for Chili's"
Pros: Brinker family fund helps out when a tragedy happens.
Cons: WorkWorked for the company almost 10 years. 5 as a server and 4 as a manager. When I got married I decided that I wanted to be a better husband and father. I asked to be demoted and turned in my demotion letter. After my time was up I was terminated for not producing well as a manager. I was singled out by the CEO, RD and AD multiple times
Advice to Management: I have no words..... just completely disappointed that my 10 years was so easily forgotten.

Title: "An interesting expeirence.. good way to earn quick money"
Pros: Working at Chili's was a quick way to earn money. Your salary even though low covers your taxes so you get to walk out with cash every night and keep exactly what you earn. Hours are flexible around your schedule.
Cons: Management can be annoying. Very short-sighted and often do not really care about your needs.
Advice to Management: Managers need to be more concerned with the well-being of their workers.

Title: "Great training structure, room for advancement, etc"
Pros: Great training structure, room for advancement, awesome customers
Cons: Late hours, tipped position may not make very much at times, ups and downs.
Advice to Management: good work

Title: "Former dishwasher West Valley Utah 3403 decker lake drive the management are rude behind a face of a smile."
Pros: loved the team members very nice waitresses
Cons: The Management Talks crap behind your back they expect you to improve quickly when it takes time to improve they push and expect to learn quickly they fire people who try. plus the sprayer messes up your wrist .
Advice to Management: you guys need to realize it takes time to improve on a job task and understand theres some people that have learning disabilities so quit pushing people to do crap and help a team member to develop and quit being panzees trying to call people to fire em. learn to do confrontation and quit putting your lives to get your egos drunk. cause thats all the managers care about.

Title: "FOH Team Member"
Pros: Flexible with schedule. Always busy. Fun, young crew.
Cons: Customers can be low-lifes. Management either likes you or they don't.
Advice to Management: Stop with the 5 dollar combos. Good for guests...bad for tips

Title: "Fast easy money!"
Pros:
Team environments
Half off food for you and your friends (4)
Easy money
Pays the bills
Cons:
Dealing with rude guests
Can get busy but if you are on your game it's easy to handle
Advice to Management: Great place, great environment

Title: "A fun place to work with opportunity to advance if you work hard."
Pros: Management was always willing to work with my schedule, especially if school was involved.
Cons: The high turnover rate made it difficult to have coworkers that were dedicated to their jobs.

Title: "Good Company with Solid Track Record"
Pros: Good pay. Great coworkers. Can be fun environment and most shifts offer a different challenge.
Cons: Can encounter some rude people.

Title: "Good for the most part"
Pros: Good management, Pretty good staff
Cons: Low pay, Restaurant job, no advancement opportunities
Advice to Management: create advancement opportunities

Title: "bartender"
Pros: good job for between jobs
Cons: poor quality food. Poor mgnt. healthcare a huge joke. working with up to 12 tables at a time and being yelled at for making a single mistake. Immature G.M.
Advice to Management: hire someone who does not just kiss upper mgr. ass.

Title: "Great Job"
Pros: Free schedule, meet chicks, and drink beer
Cons: Not a lot of money at the job
Advice to Management: Keep on keeping on baby

Title: "I loved the people I worked with and the company was great."
Pros: Great company with benefits. I loved that they supported St. Jude's Children's hospital. I also loved the contest we had for nightly sales, up-selling, margaritas, etc. It made the evening more fun.
Cons: As with any waitressing, the tips could be bad. We tended to be slightly overstaffed most of the time. I also wish they had a food runner or two.

Title: "good but not great"
Pros: I get full time hours as a kid, which beats the 15 hour weeks at Braums.
Cons: Very boring if you are under 18, There isn't much variety in job choices.

Title: "Great Customer Service"
Pros: Team service is absolutely wonderful, managers treat employees well. Team work is very good.
Cons: Restaurant can loose control when it gets very busy and food is out late to tables.
Advice to Management: Keep up the good work.

Title: "Working at Chili's was so much fun!"
Pros: Great staff, full of energy.
Cons: Rude customers and having them complain to you.
Advice to Management: Be nicer to your staff!

Title: "Great place to work!!"
Pros: flexible schedule, good money, fun work environment
Cons: never guaranteed money, working nights & weekends

Title: "Constant CHanges"
Pros: It's Burgers and Fajitas not too difficult, Great benefit packages, 50 percent dining for hourly tteam as often as you like nice perk
Cons: Constantly making policy, training or management style changes. Very hard to keep up with all the changes. GM not very strong no backbone

Title: "Fun environment and great management"
Pros:
Flexible schedule
Great management
Good hours
Co workers are like family
Cons: Because of tips never know how much cash your walking out with
Advice to Management: Keep positive attitudes up

Title: "Very Fun"
Pros: There is a great variety of people that come in. When training as a server, you are given full meals to eat to experience the food. Management does an awesome job with selecting workers. Everyone is very fun and sociable as well as helpful.
Cons: Managers play favorites so they give better table sections to the people they like. The hosts also play favorites and seat more customers in certain people's sections more than others. The mangers are also very unprofessional. Chili's doesn't drug test s often the cooks would come in high.
Advice to Management: Hire better managers.

Title: "Headed the wrong direction"
Pros: Working at Chili's you'll meet great people (both your coworkers and the guests), have a flexible work schedule, there's consistent food and drink quality, high table turnover with large sections, a focus on team work, a fast paced work day that's never boring and there's always a contest going on you can win extra bonuses in.
Cons:
If you're full time, the health benefits are dismal- whether you are hourly or in management. $6000 deductible on your health insurance for single folks, $12,000 for a family. $750 emergency room copay that doesn't even cover all the ER bills. Full time hourly team members had their vacation time taken away in lieu of an annual bonus, that is significantly less than vacation time adds up to.
¬†The company is always looking to do more with less- cutting labor hours often at the expense of the team running smoothly. Final straw for me was when the decision was made to make the bar area into a "sports bar like atmosphere"- with only attractive young people behind the bar. When at a meeting the girls were told to wear more makeup and tighter shirts, I knew it was time to move on.
Advice to Management: To upper management, actually, as usually when a in store manager makes a poor decision it's because he or she is trying to make numbers or keep their job- go back to putting the guests first. A meat market bar isn't going to win you the casual dining segment- great service, great food and customer experiences is. If you invest a little more in your team, you'll find they've got your back and will again be proud of the company they work for.

Title: "Run, run far away"
Pros: - There really are none. You can get the same experience with better pay elsewhere.
Cons:
- Management shows no respect for people working there.
- When people fail to show each other respect in the restaurant, our customers sense this and think that they can treat the waitstaff like garbage, as well.
- Food quality can be substandard at times making it difficult to serve to customers.
Advice to Management: - Your best people are walking out the door because you can't judge potential. Work on it.

Title: "I worked here while I was completing my degree."
Pros: Free food is always a plus at any restaurant job.
Cons: Everything else is below average.

Title: "Great place to work"
Pros: Great money , flexible schedule , discount is awesome.
Cons: not much full time. not the best benifits. late nights. don't ever have a set time to get off work.
Advice to Management: management is awesome!

Title: "Very easy, fun job"
Pros: Easy to make money, customers are usually easy going and relaxed.
Cons: Sometimes coworkers don't do their jobs and other employees are required to pick up their slack.
Advice to Management: Keep everyone in line.

Title: "Fun coworkers, but extremely corporate and lacking in respect for employees"
Pros:
-fun coworkers
-50% off at all Brinker-owned restaurants
-facilitates an annual fundraiser for St. Jude Children's Research Hospital
-decent tips
-fairly flexible (Though this depends on the manager. Some respect our lives outside of work more than others.)
Cons:
-Corporate is more concerned about the bottom line than about its employees. They got rid of our bussers, cut our hours, and make cooks pull double duty as cook and dishwasher simultaneously, all for the sake of "helping us make more money" (which thus far has been questionable).
-Extremely corporate! We have no freedom to be ourselves, though the higher management will do everything in their power to make us believe otherwise. (We are constantly secret shopped, written up if we do not meet unreasonable guidelines, etc.)
-We have had problems with managers who seem to be incompetent. Several of the managers I have worked with do not have even basic cooking skills and are very unfamiliar with our menu and our computer system.
-The company is always more concerned with keeping customers than with having any respect for the employees or the company itself. Problems are always remedied with free food and coupons, even if the customer is obviously at fault.
-The health insurance offered is so bad that even my general manager advised me to purchase outside insurance.
Advice to Management: Respect the opinions of your staff- we are the face of the restaurant and are more aware of customer desires than the corporate staff who have never encountered a customer.

Title: "Good place for the experience. 1-2 years then get out"
Pros: Friendly people, good development opportunities
Cons: company is grasping at straws trying to get a piece of every little part of the market. Ever expanding menu does not allow for focus on quality.
Advice to Management: Pick one thing to be good at and stay there. Tacos, pizza, flat bread. Stop. You're a bar and grill, stick with that.

Title: "Yuck"
Pros: It's a Job, There is really nothing positive to say about this train wreck
Cons: Experienced Workplace Violence, brought it to management, they laughed, brought it to upper management, they said tell lower management, Homophobia, Racism and Sexism are rampant in this place. Just about everyone is rude and lazy and expects everyone else to pick up their slack. Food is horrible, drinks are horrible, no beer selection, everything comes out of a bag, just a sit down mcdonalds thats hella overpriced.
Advice to Management: Just Quit so this blight of a company goes under already

Title: "Loved working at Chili's Alamosa"
Pros: Great managers that cared about you! Not bad money for a serving job.
Cons: Having a teammate and the kitchen of the future... gross!!!

Title: "bartender"
Pros: great staff to work with. fast paced environment. good tips
Cons: sketchy management. 4 different managers to report to. high management turnover. no promotions within

Title: "Don't work here unless you are desperate"
Pros:
-Get to know people
-Learn the restaurant business
Cons: The management was never on the same page. I would always ask them what goes in what, and would get 4 different answers. Also, I did WAY too much running around, dealing with wrong orders etc. for the minimum wage salary I received. Also had to deal with lazy servers, and I did to go so I ended up tending to a lot of the tables' needs. The servers would be over in a corner talking! To go was a very fast paced environment and since you're on your own you REALLY have to know what side items go with what dish, etc.

Title: "For the most part Chili's was a great place to work, I dedicated 7 years to them"
Pros: Fast and easy money, great co-workers, and its fun interacting with the different guests that come in, a good way to attain regulars and make friends.
Cons: Management is seriously lacking, I feel like they will put anyone into management just to have a body in the position, and they hold no one accountable.
Advice to Management: You really should listen more to your employees, in all honestly the establishment couldn't run without them!

Title: "Run!"
Pros:
Allow me to dig deep to find some sort of positive feedback on such a negative facility. .
*Good Pay
Host: 8.75$
ToGo: 8.00$ +tips

*Fun Environment
It is fun purely because of your coworkers!! Laid back, calm and cool people.

*Free Food:
It Works like this: On a average shift, you must pay for your food. It will be half off, granted you're selecting from the TM Shift Meal Menu.
To obtain free food, you MUST be working a double. Even then, your food options are limited to the TM Shift Meal Menu.

*Tattoo and Piercings
Just don't over do it.
Cons:
-rubs hands together- Let's Do This.

*Favoritism:
Managers calculate your hours based off of if they like you or not.
Managers give you days off based off of if they like you or not.
Managers cut (allow you to go home) based off of if they like you or not.

*Senior Workers:
Let's say you have your To Goschedule and you know you are due to be cut at 9:00pm and therefore made plans. Let's say a Host who picked up a shift (meaning they took that specific work hours by choice) but decided she wanted to go home at 9.
