Quick as lightning you're suddenly hosting and stuck until closing (12 midnight) and that Senior worker is going home at 9. But those tables can't turn, you'd better not ask to switch shifts last second!!

It's Just WRONG
* Let's say a nice Host retrieved a lost cellphone and returned it to the male who lost it. Let's say they tip you a dollar. The manager will tear it in half, pocket it and walk away.

Second Job?
*Let's say you get a second job. Chilis will immediately terminate your hours. If they can't have 100% of you, they don't want you.
Just don't work here.

Chilis
off of 59
Directly across from Deerbrook Mall
Advice to Management: You Don't Have The Right To Talk Badly To Us "because you're a manager"

Title: "Miserable, Not a good experience."
Pros: Met some new friends, nothing else.
Cons: Horrible management. Too much work hours/responsibilities for a host, for the poor pay. Get blamed for things that happen that have nothing to do with you. Customers getting in your face and complaining, and even blaming you for things they don't like 98% of each shift. Would not recommend. Not a happy environment for myself and customers always seemed upset. Left after 3 weeks.
Advice to Management: Get your priorities together. Stop losing schedules of when people can and cannot work.

Title: "Long hours, bad pay, unprofessional employers"
Pros: You meet some of the greatest people and good tips.
Cons: Some of the most incompetent people you will ever work with. Very unprofessional with the employees.
Advice to Management: Know who you hire and change your attitude. Smart remarks are uncalled for.

Title: "An unaldultrated trip through hell"
Pros: None that I can think of
Cons: No bussers, constant menu change, you will do the work of three or four people while getting paid for one.
Advice to Management: Quit and retire with all the money weve broken our backs to earn for you.

Title: "Changed over the years, they care more about hitting their numbers than the employees and customers."
Pros: Great employees, good food, not much else
Cons: Not enough good managers, no benefits, to much favoritism, promises broken, not very professional, training isn't consistent, no paid vacation. Managers not available when needed, they act like you're bothering them when you need them, can't ask off on weekends.
Advice to Management: It's the cooks and hostesses and servers that bring in the customers and make the company money, treat them better and with respect.

Title: "Interview Process"
Pros: Very Quick.Friendly Staff. Easy Questions
Cons: Misleading on whether you got the job or not.

Title: "Unprofessional"
Pros: Enjoyed the other people I worked with
Cons: Management was horrible and unprofessional
Advice to Management: Find new jobs

Title: "Great place to work if you want zero responsibility."
Pros:
-Schedules tend to be extremely flexible.
-The company holds an annual monthly donation drive for St. Jude's Children's Hospital, and 100% of the donations go directly to those in need.
-Friendly Staff and Management
Cons:
-There's absolutely no accountability at any level.
-Lack of communication between management leads to inadequate staffing and food orders
-Gratuity for large parties is only suggested and not required.
-In an effort to reduce the cost of labor, stores operate on the bare minimum. Servers are expected to bus, run, qa, host, dish wash, clean, and assist with Togo orders all while they serve their tables.

Title: "Chili's was a great place to work for many years, they started losing their culture before I left"
Pros: Fun environment and great staff. Working with high energy people made the job well worth the time. Food was always good for sure.
Cons: Company really struggled with direction after Norman Brinker left the helm.
Advice to Management: Keep it fresh as you are doing with recent retrofit but go back to the original culture and stop bowing down to wallstreet.

Title: "Fair"
Pros:
Meet interesting people
Challenging work environment
Cons: Not allowed to have enough staff. Will work unnecessarily hard as a manager doing employee functions.
Advice to Management: Be more committed to making money. Staff the stores.

Title: "The most horrendously, nightmare-fueled restaurant to ever work for."
Pros: Money is the only pro, when you get to Chilis you'll understand that this isn't a positive work environment. Its a 'try to survive every day environment'.
Cons:
-Management completely changing their attitudes about topics from one hour to the next
-Constant bickering and fighting between the Back of the House and Front of the House
-Unreasonable expectations from crew, little customer service.
Advice to Management: Start showing some employee loyalty.

Title: "Good For Teens !!!"
Pros: Fun environment, Laid back at times, Very busy at others, Flexible work schedule, Okay pay for teens who are looking for pocket change.
Cons: It can get hectic, Standing for long hours, Can be dysfunctional at times, Managers can be unprofessional at times.
Advice to Management: Maybe managers should take classes on how to run a business and then things will run a little more smoothly.

Title: "corporate typical"
Pros: caring company willing to help its employees
Cons: corporate guidelines stifle employees ability to excel as customer service reps

Title: "it was a high pace job well thats if you weren't ready."
Pros: Good managers, if you asked with time about your schedule they tried to work something out with you.
Cons: You sometimes have to work long shifts

Title: "I liked working here but the store had low volume of guest"
Pros: I love the managers and staff
Cons: not very busy and the tips aren't great either.

Title: "pretty good"
Pros: corporate will back you up in a pinch, our store was esp great during the hurricane..met wonderful people. 50% discount at sister restaurants
Cons: its really hard to give great service, via 'team service' or otherwise when our bussers are taken away..we have 8-12 tables between 2 servers we have to bus EVERYTHING ourselves, run food all while getting double sat (God forbid someone needs an allergy menu, or takes forever to order, then we're really backed up) and the menu is all over the place

Title: "Worst restaurant I've ever worked at"
Pros: I can' think of one positive thing that came out of working at Chili's.
Cons: Lazy cooks, No Teamwork, Managers didn't even know how to cook or make meals, Work week started on Thursdays and the schedule would come out early Thursday Morning (4am). After working there I will no longer eat at a Chili's restaurant nor a Brinker owned restaurant.
Advice to Management: Ugh be a real manager? We must have had 7 different managers and when I quit I was still unsure who was at what level. Work on Teamwork, when you only have 2 or 3 cooks working on a Wednesday or Thursday night and you have 2 of the cooks running one station and the other cook is running 3 its quite unfair.

Title: "A great place to work."
Pros: Bonus structure is rewarding. Opportunity for advancement.
Cons: Healthcare benefits are not that great.
Advice to Management: Offer better healthcare benefits. Deductibles are way too high.

Title: "good tips"
Pros: make good money on weekends
Cons: work every weekend usually doubles
Advice to Management: appreciate staff more

Title: "A fun place for a part time job."
Pros: Flexible with your needs and fun coworkers help you out.
Cons: A little disorganized at times.
Advice to Management: Be more clear and specific about how you want things done.

Title: "Corporate System Restaurant"
Pros: The company does its best to keep up with growing trends and needs of its customers. Brinker International is supportive of its employees and values feedback from them.
Cons: There are times when it feels like the employees are just a number in the grand scheme of Brinker's corporate plan.
Advice to Management: Value the staff's input as they see more of the day-to-day issues firsthand.

Title: "What a waste of time....and money"
Pros: 50% discount on food (not including alchohol)
Cons:
-Get treated unfairly
- Got food poisoning twice after eating there
- Unorganized management
- Have to pay for all your uniforms
- Have to pay for an Application on the phone that is the way they schedule you, etc.
- Food takes over 45 minutes to come out on average, so you deal with a lot a lot a lot of angry guests.
Advice to Management:
-Fire the managers that dont know how to interact with servers. You need people to support you at your job not fight you on it.
-Hire new cooks that dont disappear during a lunch rush
-Follow through with discipline on people instead of trying to be everyone's favorite manager

Title: "Fell in love with the Culture!"
Pros:
Great Co-workers and dedicated staff.
Promote from with-in
I love serving our guests and the community
Cons:
SLOW to promote beyond the Asst. Manager level
Pay is just barely enough to be competitive with industry, but anyone with ambition would not likely stay
Work/ life balance is horrible, but that comes with the territory in restaurants
Advice to Management: Great corporate culture, very talented mangers in your Maryland Market. Please stop pushing the Productivity and Labor goals so hard down everyone's throat. We understand profits are important in a business, but this Brand is very profitable as it is. At some point we need to stop worrying about the share holders best interest and start concentrating on the well being of our work force and their moral. Not to mention in the constant effort to always save on labor costs the guests are the #1 victim! They and we deserve better.

Title: "Great place to work with easy hours"
Pros: They always work with your schedule and you can make quick money. Easy online scheduling program makes it easy to change your shifts with coworkers
Cons: Lazy coworkers, new managers that are still enthusiastic and annoying
Advice to Management: Don't test all your new management on one store! Employees don't want a daily pep talk. We came here to make money, not get a life coaching session.

Title: "Bad Management crappy place to be"
Pros: discount meals, hours are good
Cons: not able to move up

Title: "Good Place to work to get by"
Pros: Great staff to work with. Morning Staff is usually the older crowd that have families so usually the morning crew are great with team work. But you tend to make more money at night. If you are a food server or bar tender you bring home your tips the same day. They offer 401k and match a certain percent after 1 year of working at Chili's . When you become a a trainer you get 50 percent off the meals at all of the Chili's on the island except the Waikiki location.
Cons: If you want to attain health care from this company it's hard to attain. You have to sacrifice, be flexible, and work harder than the rest to get health care. Food servers make a quarter less than minimum wage.

Title: "my work"
Pros: Great place to work for short times
Cons: Can be vast paced at times

Title: "Serving at Chili's"
Pros: Very flexible scheduling, great opportunities for growth, good benefits, great coworkers.
Cons: Lazy managers lead to late schedules being released, no bussers, no food runners, stupid contests.
Advice to Management: Stop pushing us to tell guests about gem and trying to change the way people wait tables.

Title: "good starter restaurant"
Pros:
good pay when busy but during slow times they are quick to cut and save labor
flexible work schedule
laid back environment
Cons: the clientele can be iffy at times since it is a fairly affordable restaurant and a lot of clients don't know how to tip so at times you can make nothing despite working really hard

Title: "Managing Partner"
Pros: Compensation is great if you hit your aggressive sales and profit budgets.
Cons: This company sold it's soul to the shareholders when the current leadership team took the reins. 50% of home office was eliminated, leaving store management level to deal with outsourced incompetency. Sales and profit budgets are overly aggressive, with little regard to the human beings that work and sole focus on the top line and bottom line.

Title: "Managing Partner"
Pros: Developing people. Working with a varied employment base. The salary is pretty good as well, including stock grants, annual merit increase, and decent health insurance.
Cons: Not a ton, mainly just dealing with your typical restaurant chain procedures at times.

Title: "very good"
Pros: flexibility good environment helpful management understanding
Cons: not enough raises, not fair 100% of the time
Advice to Management: knowledge when your cooks do a good job, or go above and beyond.

Title: "Chilis is the worst to work for"
Pros: Free Heart Clogging Fattening food
Cons: Worst work environment I have ever worked in ever
Advice to Management: Stop being so oppressive to the workers

Title: "Great part time job for college students, busiest restaurant in town."
Pros: Very busy, excellent GM with great AM's. Flexible scheduling due to high volume of employees. BOH does a nice job.
Cons: Not a great crowd who comes in late to eat, long hours with little breaks on doubles, picky managers about little things, and many employees have had personal items stolen from the BOH. (sunglasses, wallets, cash out of books, ect.)
Advice to Management: Implement surveillance cameras for reported theft, hire quicker more experienced bartenders, close earlier on Friday/Saturday nights. Waste of labor hours when less than 200 dollars in sales is generated in the last hour and a half.

Title: "Basically a disaster and a half."
Pros: Having some nice customers who don't make you want to tear your hair out.
Cons: Badly trained because apparently the managers don't know what they're doing.
Advice to Management: Learn to train your hostesses better. Each manager told me something different about how to seat sections, and when one would tell me one thing, the other would say I was doing it all wrong. This cause drama between servers and I because I apparently wasn't "doing my job right" according to them. Most likely considering 3 different managers told me 3 different things on a daily basis. Get your "stuff" (I'll be friendly there) together.

Title: "Okay work while you're in college, but don't get stuck here!"
Pros: The social atmosphere--if you're single and/or don't have any children. Working with the same people day in and day out can foster some great friendships. Depending your area, good tips. Also, good opportunity to travel around, as you can transfer from one Chilis to another. I started in Tampa, FL, moved to Houston, TX, went to Pensacola, FL, then to Colorado Springs, CO.
Cons: Management is ridiculous. Instead of firing people, they will just hire more people on and cut hours so that people are forced to go elsewhere. Also, they wait until the last minute to post the schedule. New schedules start Thursday; you can expect to know what you're working on Wednesday, usually. They do NOT promote from within, so don't believe that BS.
Advice to Management: Promote from within and post schedules further in advance--people have kids and have to arrange childcare!

Title: "Horrible Management"
Pros: fun staff, great customers, easy work,
Cons: horrible management, not easy to advance, not many hours available, favoritism
Advice to Management: Please hire store managers that actually care aboutt he customers and don't make comments about them in the back or mumble under their breath about the customer while they are visiting their table

Title: "Very training based, salary/compensation based on effort."
Pros: Flexible hours, opportunity to make very decent money.
Cons: Late nights and weekends. Fuzzy schedule.
Advice to Management: Help with scheduling.

Title: "Five Years of Fun"
Pros: The best part of the company is the atmosphere. I worked at a Utah location all the way through college - it was a great way to make extra money and get the social interaction that double-majoring didn't allow. Chili's makes a community of its employees. Right before I started, a host/bus staff member (a friend of a friend of mine and a brother of two other employees) passed away, and Chili's paid for his funeral and offered emotional support to all of the mourning employees. Great company.
Cons: Because it is casual dining, occasionally you have to work with people who don't take any pride in their work and that can be frustrating. Also a little cult-y, but not terribly so. As a trainer, I indoctrinated new employees in a way that sometimes felt cheesy, but it really was like a family.
Advice to Management: Keep on keepin' on.

Title: "Not a long term place"
Pros: Larger table sections than any other restaurant, committed to making everyone money, greater starter place for restaurant business, ability to move around with in store.
Cons: Constant flow of people including managers, everyone is disposable, ticket times are long and thus stress is high,

Title: "Chili Heads"
Pros: Best placed I've ever worked, they make you feel like a family at work!
Cons: Weekends are crazy to work but always worth it and good experience!

Title: "review of chili's Miami fl"
Pros: regulars and the staff , I at least moved up enough for self learning purposes but it took way too long, closes around 10, safe area
Cons: worst area to work, people regularly dip out on the tab, it was a franchise before but then was bought by corporate....we didn't know if we would even have a job for a year since they werent sure about buying the store
Advice to Management: Pay attention to the servers themselves not the surveys. You have amazing employees there that dont get moved up to the positions they deserve and you get stuck with terrible employees that steal from you , too few employees due to this I almost passed out on fourth of july one year because we didnt have enough servers so i didnt get a day off for 2 months every day i had off i was called in -_-, i quit because i found a better job, but honestly even when corporate took over I was done with the place, tho I have heard good things about every other restaurant

Title: "it was horrible"
Pros: nothing, poor staff and work ethic
Cons: favoritism, terrible managers, low tips
Advice to Management: listen to employees concerns

Title: "Great people and benefits for team members"
Pros: Great people and culture. Very organized company with updated systems in place. Good home office support. Great place for a new manager to learn the ropes of restaurant managment. Great training program.
Cons: Bonus plan changed and became not very obtainable. Took individuality out of manager decision making to do what is right for individual restaurant.
Advice to Management: Give power back to MP and GM of restaurant to do what is best for individual restaurant. Stop hiring upper levels from outside of company to keep the culture alive.

Title: "Not somewhere you want to work as a manager"
Pros: Has name recognition due to popularity and success in other markets.
Cons: Take it from the spouse of a former manager at this location, there is no teamwork or development mentality. It's all about catching you doing something wrong but not telling you how to properly handle that scenario in the future. The management team is so busy trying to throw each other under the bus and make themselves look good individually that there is no room for teamwork nor is there any encouragement to develop team work. Managers at the GM and RM level do not practice what they preach by following the Chilis standard but will certainly reprimand anyone umder them not following the standards.
Advice to Management: Someone from Chilis Corp needs to plant a manager spy to witness the lack of leadership and development that is occuring in the Nebraska Chilis Management team.

Title: "An ok job"
Pros: People are nice, and management can be ok. Hours are pretty good if you can convince them to let you work certain hours.
Cons: Servers treat people terribly. Not just other co-workers in the restaurant but also people they are serving. People come in to work and leave within 3 months. Even when I was there for 4 months, 10 people had come and gone. Hostess are real jerks, only care about themselves.
Advice to Management: Do better interview process to get a sense of the real person.

Title: "just a number"
Pros:
tends to be a high volume restaurant, so quantity of customers should help make for high sales
affordable food
well-known
Cons:
like staff, management is a revolving door. Extremely high turn-over rate
customers tend to flood in for the 2-20 deal... higher volume... lower check averages
Advice to Management: realize your hardworking employees hold significant value to your success

Title: "Long term employee that has been in many different positions"
Pros: It is a fun company to work for and they always have contests and stuff to give away. I have never had a problem with any managers and I always have great flexbility with my schedule. They also have a Brinker family fund in case you have a family emergency and they will help pay bills and rent.
Cons: The company has recently taken away vacation pay for hourly team members though they do give money for how many years you have worked for them. Also the insurance is horrible for part time and full time.
Advice to Management: Remember that alot of employees are working there while going to school so when they need to change their schedules they are not doing it to be difficult.

Title: "Great Time! Fast easy money"
Pros: Easy Money, People, Traffic, Hours, Flexibility, Lack of Responsibility, Distance to home
Cons: Communication, Management plays with you, tease you with shifts and schedules, Side work
Advice to Management: stop squeezing so hard on the stores

Title: "Chili's is one of my absolute favorite jobs!"
Pros: Great co-workers, fast paced environment, fast money, get to meet all types of people!, great food and management.
Cons: can get stressful when it's busy, but the money makes it worth it!
Advice to Management: Give the managers at the Chili's in Stowe a raise, we have the most incredible management any employee could ask for. I have absolutely no complaints, and would highly recommend employment at our location.

Title: "Great company to work for room for advancement."
Pros: good hours for going to school
Cons: late hours due to the location in an outdoor mall.

Title: "Great Company to grow in the Hospitality Industry"
Pros: If you have the drive you can work your way from waiter to GM. Every restaurant is different, so how much you like it will depend on the GM and managers.
Cons:
Waiters:Train on how be better at up selling and other sales tricks.
Managers:Make sure you hire the right ones, to often they are in the back and not helping out during the busy time.

Title: "Overwhelming, not quality of life. All the responsibility is yours, GM is never in the building."
Pros: Good Benefits + bonus + 401k after 1 year. Free food and 50% off in other restaurant with the same company.
Cons: Gm's and Area directors are very unprofessional. They show Favoritism for some other people even they are very bad employes.
Advice to Management: Managers hast to do everything, cook, clean, food running, dish washing to keep labor in track.

Title: "A busy very fast paced environment"
Pros: you get to interact with customers and learn to multitask efficiently
Cons: You can often get slammed with orders and can negatively affect your performance/income.

Title: "One of the best jobs I have ever had."
Pros: Great Benefits, quality of life balance +
Cons: Some late nights. Long shifts. Lots of stress in high volume restaurants.
Advice to Management: I was treated very well by all...

Title: "Fun, fast paced, stressful"
Pros:
Great people to work with
Manager's were mostly professional
Promote from within
Cons:
Like any restaurant job, the customers
Stressing overtime but then asking you to do it another point
Some really bad seeds become managers

Title: "Its a paycheck"
Pros: Great staff, and friendly management
Cons: They place so many guidelines and policy (up-sell, Saint Judes, GEM, food cost, Promotions, Margarita Madness, Coupons, Kids eat free) just a few off the top of my head, that the customer interaction gets lost, or becomes fake and impersonal

Title: "Worst place I've ever worked"
Pros: free food, discounted food when coming in
Cons:
The managers where horrible, the store manager is a joke. she shouldn't even have a job, let alone over a store. Girls there where so petty. All I ever did was get yelled at.
They don't train you very well, and yet expect you to know everything about the menu. even if they never schedule you.
Advice to Management: listen to your workers when they complain about their store manager 24/7

Title: "Great if you fit in their box!"
Pros: Food, more food, and even more food. Pay is competitive to start with. They solicit feedback. Very diverse workforce.
Cons: Don't ever assume that your confidential feedback is actually confidential, it's not, even when it says that it is. Pay structure can change without notice at anytime. No one is currently leading the brand, they say that there is a direction, but that direction changes all the time; making it no direction at all. Pursuit of diversity comes at a cost, sometimes you get the worst fit for the job but they like it because diversity goals are made.
Advice to Management: Go back to the basics, stop chasing other concepts, Chili's is not cutting edge, never will be. That's OK, know who you are and be the best at who that is... and for crying out loud, 2 for 20 didn't save you from anything, it just makes the margins thinner.

Title: "Boring job and questionable management"
Pros: Great discounts on food as long as you're a member of the meal plan. Worked with friendly, happy people. It was right down the street from my house, so I was never late.
Cons: Management was rude and frustrating to work with. The incentives for good work were a joke. No reason to go above and beyond the call of service. The food is all terrible for you, as well as being frozen and prepackaged. Not a restaurant but more so fast food with soft-seating and excessive decorations.

Title: "it was joa job exprience,great customers and great co-workers"
Pros: good food!, great hours, managment very flexible , and great atmosphere
Cons: needed better managment,managers had to much favoritism,
Advice to Management: never have favoritism because its never turns out good

Title: "An amazing place to work. You become a giant family."
Pros: They are amazing at working with outside schedules. I had two jobs for the longest time and they did their best to work with me around that schedule all the time. I've been there a total of 5 years and still love my job (most days).
Cons: They switch management around ALOT. We constantly have new management from different stores due to transfers. Chili's is like a family, and people get used to how the work with each other. Each time they introduce a new manager to the team, we have to re-learn what they want, how they want things done and how they want us to work. It's hard and frustrating. Eventually you just stop trying to get along with everyone because they're most likely going to end up gone anyway.
Advice to Management: Stop choosing favorites. Everyone can tell who's on your "lists" of people you do and don't like. It shows and it makes it hard to work sometimes. I have personally never had a problem in this area, but some of my coworkers get so frustrated they end up quitting or crying because of the amount of favoritism shown at times. Treat everyone as equals.

Title: "Incredible Company to work for!!"
Pros: Everything from the family benefits to their contributions to St. Jude-they really take care of their own!
Cons: Honestly,I cant think of any cons!
Advice to Management: Keep up the good work-you guys are super fantastic!!

Title: "A good place to work if you don't plan to stay long"
Pros: Laid-back atmosphere. HotSchedules implementation allows more flexibility and ease in scheduling/trading shifts. You can make a decent earning if you're put into a good section. The managers work closely with the employees and its conducive to good teamwork.
Cons: The biggest con was that the new servers are placed in the smallest and least profitable section. Most lunch shifts, which were about 2-3 hours, I brought home $15-25 in tips which made it hardly worth it to go to work there. It was impossible to support myself. Another con was the fact I had to watch management handle cooked food without gloves or even washing their hands. Absolutely disgusting. I also witnessed the male managers putting their hands on and fondling some of the female servers; they seemed to not be bothered by it but the principle of it disturbed me. Lastly, the favorites game is played **a lot.** The employees who had not befriended or otherwise gained the managers' favor were treated like outsiders and written up for the most trivial offenses.
Advice to Management: I would suggest a more thorough selection process for your store managers.

Title: "not what it use to be"
Pros: still can make decent money in tips for the time you put into it. like any serving job, the hours are flexable so going to school is easily coordinated around work.
Cons: since the economy took the dive down a couple years ago, personalism and being a stand out employee is no longer an asset. too much focus on the bottom line.
Advice to Management: your stretching the store managers way too thin. as I see it, they have too much on their plate, and alot of it is stupid micro managing bean counting that doesn't amount to well,"a hill of beans". they aren't able to effectively manage the shifts and people working said shifts. enough already... show a little trust in the ones you have in place to run the stores.

Title: "Wrong Direction"
Pros: easy money with little hours worked.
Cons:
working with people and having to be nice
ridiculous goals for selling.
Advice to Management: Learn to speak to employees

Title: "Good place to make a quick buck"
Pros: Good place to make a quick buck
Cons: Level of money you make is up to you.
Advice to Management: Stay straight

Title: "easy steady money, a lot of rules"
Pros: good prices, so heavy flow of customers
Cons: cheap food- cheap tips, some guests are rude. management caters to guests, not employees
Advice to Management: management takes everything too seriously and is uptight. focus on having more fun and your staff will enjoy their job more

Title: "Good people, good college job."
Pros: Fun environment, most managers have an open door policy, fair scheduling, decent money if you put in the hours.
Cons: Many of the employees can be a little too immature and blow off work, leaving you to fill in. Occasional drama, long days.
Advice to Management: Try not to over staff on slower nights. If you schedule strong staff they can carry the shift and make money for all involved.

Title: "Fun at time, stressful at others"
Pros: Work with some nice people and you get a 50% discount on food, but you can only get it on weekdays
Cons: management staff can be pushy at times and odd with their scheduling. you dont know when youre going to go home.. even when its slow they will keep everyone on for no reason
Advice to Management: we are getting paid 5 dollars an hour, i am not going to put my all into selling alcohol and cleaning the restaurant when its dead

Title: "Like falling down the rabbit hole."
Pros:
50% discount on meals for you and a few guests, the more guests you bring in the lower your discount.
Exceptionally well at working with your schedule allowing you the flexibility to do other things.
Cons:
They prefer to hire management from outside of the organization rather than from within. Not to say they don't promote from within, it's just not as common.
You never know what to expect when coming to work. HQ is always changing things! Half of the time the changes are pretty good but then there is that other half where you scratch your head wondering what they were thinking.
I think they brought in someone from Wal-Mart to run the marketing because they are always "rolling back the prices". The Con to this is that it brings in the bargain shoppers who for some reason or another don't understand the concept of tipping. It is their version of fine dining when they are used to a drive-thru budget.
Advice to Management: Build your team up! Promote from within. Don't hide in your office for long periods of time. Lead by example. If you say your going to do something, do it.

Title: "Flexible, but all employees are stretched too thin"
Pros: Flexible schedule for school, always a plus. It's a very easy job and I've made some great friends.
Cons: Employees are asked to do so much that when we get packed no one can keep up including the managers, cooks, QA, togo, servers and sometimes hosts when we are short staffed (to "save labor costs"). We have no bussers so the servers are required to do most of the work for the FOH and they rarely can accomplish keeping a clean restaurant while providing great service to their tables
Advice to Management: The idea that Chili's is a "teamwork" environment sounds really fuzzy and warm, but in reality it is just a way to cut labor by making everyone responsible for a little more. This works well on predictable slow days, but when it gets busy, theres a reason why bussers exist. Our GEM scores have significantly decreased due to customers complaining about cleanliness. Also, the host stand is very old school, and because of the paper list system, we hosts lose valuable time. It would be so great to have a hospitality computer management system like at (a similar chain corporate restaurant) Olive Garden so that we could time manage more effectively.

Title: "a decent place to work"
Pros: a lot of customers go to chili's specifically because they love the food
Cons: managers/management is kind of thrown together and unorganized
Advice to Management: take better care when selecting managers

Title: "Chili's Bar and Grill"
Pros: GMs are driven and work hard to make the company money
Cons: Servers often have to comply with standards set by the corporate office, whether or not it actually helps the particular restaurant increase productivity.
Advice to Management: Treat employees like human beings.

Title: "It was so fun! I would have been a food server forever if it paid more!"
Pros: Flexible schedule, half off food even from other Brinker brands, go home with cash every day, friendly work environment while being competitive, casual uniform
Cons: They close late, somtimes past midnight and closing can take extra hour. Scheduled by sales/customer service. Running out of inventory can make customers very angry
Advice to Management: Create a program for employees to work their way up so there is incentive for longevity

Title: "Work Environ"
Pros: The money is easy and great
Cons: Disorganized management and poor teamwork
Advice to Management: Stop being lazy and get on the same page

Title: "Great work environment that accommodates life's busy schedule."
Pros: Flexible Schedule, Good Pay, Friendly Atmosphere, 50% Food Discount up to 4 people when dining at any Brinker restaurant, Opportunities for Advancement
Cons: Difficult to maintain hours during slow seasons, Company has no sustainability program and does not appear to want one
Advice to Management: Listen to employee concerns and voice them to higher levels of management. Also, take every opportunity to cross train as many employees as you can. This strengthens the restaurant as a whole, means less empty shifts during illness or emergencies and allows employees to maximize their salaries by switching roles as needed.

Title: "Alot of work a little dough"
Pros: Fun upbeat work environment with great people. You have the ability to hire and create your own team. You are given the freedom to train and retain each individual using your own style of rewards. For the most part, you are your own boss with little to no direct supervision from your boss. You are entitled to eat with your friends for free in any Chilis from coast to coast and receive a discount at the other sister locations. You will receive reviews at 6, 12, and 18 months. After that your review will be done annually. Expect great money in your first year of reviews.
Cons: Profit is king> don't be suprised if you are working hourly positions to save a buck. You will notice tons of Chili's advertising pushing their to-go food or Hostess propping open the door and saying "Welcome to Chili's". It looks great on TV but don't expect to have those people in your restaurant because that would require paying them. We are often required to run our stores with a bare bones crew and the slightest amount of business can seem like the busiest shift. Promotions are not based on merit but the "good ole boy" system. If your boss likes you and you are someone he can share a beer with, then you may get a promotion.
Advice to Management: Get a clue! Times have changed. It is not 1995 anymore and your budgets and bonus plans should reflect that.

Title: "Decent money that pays the bills, but plenty of poor decision making and negligent authority to deal with."
Pros: You will make decent money waiting tables as a server, while working with a generally friendly staff of many different people of different ages.
Cons: Poor management, unfair scheduling, and low-income clientele. Management can be very rude and does not value any of the waiter staff's time and effort.
Advice to Management: Give back to your employees, learn to work with the staff in a professional manner, and do not threaten to fire people. It is a waiting job afterall, and they only pay the base minimum of $4/hour.

Title: "Patience"
Pros: Receive tips and meeting new wonderful people. I was able to get requested time off with not much of a problem. Builds character. I learned hpw to work with many different types of personalities and attitudes.
Cons: Managers that acted inhumane sometimes. Not being able to have a mutual respect for manager & regular employee. Racism & favoritism.
Advice to Management: Listen to your employees. It shouldnt be always about business. We are people & there is such thing as a life outside of Chili‚Äôs.

Title: "Server, Bartender, Manager"
Pros: Very flexible with scheduling, fantastic group of people to work with.
Cons: Worked too much, not a lot of time off around special holidays

Title: "Not bad!"
Pros: Team are fun, 50% discount for food
Cons: Food is poor quality. Discount should be greater

Title: "professional"
Pros:
professional
flexible
good hours
long term managers
good work/life balance
Cons:
dress code
large tip out
head office is scattered

Title: "Working with chilis"
Pros: Good food, great teaching opportunities in customer service, networking with neat people.
Cons: Could have better communication, more positive teamwork together, as well as restaurant could recycle more
Advice to Management: More team building activities, more involved with team members, better communication

Title: "waiter"
Pros: Tips can be really good
Cons: Pay and overtime pay could be better

Title: "Kitchens Supervisor"
Pros: Good Brand to work and always innovative recipes coming in an interval.
Cons: Worst management lot of partiality with the staff and franchise owner.
Advice to Management: Please take care off staff who really doing their job well .

Title: "Chili's Grill & Bar - Server"
Pros: Good team work and server experience. Good tips.
Cons: Salary was $2.13 in Puerto Rico.

Title: "Hostess"
Pros: Pretty casual atmosphere and good food
Cons: Have to stand a lot, do not get breaks if you only do one shift

Title: "Worst experience ever. Wouldn't recommend to anyone!!!! It was very disappointing."
Pros: None really. No wonder they cannot beat plan or make bonus and grow sales. What a sad management team.
Cons: Long hours. Breaks not allowed. Micromanaging from above. Managers don't know how to take feedback. Lots of drama...it's like back in high school again!
Advice to Management: Be open minded and take feedback openly. You judge too fast and believe everything you hear before you get both sides of the story.

Title: "Not a career"
Pros: Flexible hours for students and people who have other jobs. The workplace is very dynamic.
Cons:
Place and time affect whether you'll have a good shift of not.

Though tips are good, they're never guaranteed therefor

THE SALARY IS NOT ENOUGH
Advice to Management: I believe the company has the lowest payment in the industry towards servers. A little raise would be nice.

Title: "Cook/QA"
Pros: Management works hard to cope with the different challenges and changes in within employess lives.
Cons: The smell of Chili's is kinda of hard to get rid of...
Advice to Management: Keep the ideas coming!

Title: "Ehh"
Pros: Friendly coworkers, not too much effort put in job because it's a restaurant
Cons: Disorganized management and shifts, some sexual harassment.
Advice to Management: Treat employees with respect and respect people to do their jobs.

Title: "Minimum wage"
Pros:
Staff I worked with was ok.. Management was ok too.
Meeting new people.
Cons:
No overtime pay
No flexible schedules
Same meal everyday (still had to pay for it at half price)
No employee discount
No room to grow
Pay was barely over national minimum wage and I worked my butt off
I believe some of the weekly tips were stolen by managers

Title: "Working at chilis was a fun experience"
Pros: Fun work environment and a great customer service base. Great base pay and most people tip well.
Cons: Business began slowing down. Management had some difficulties communicating. Kitchen was slow.
Advice to Management: Get better at communicating with eachother. Everyone should have the same rules and restrictions

Title: "Chili's"
Employee Title: Waiter, Quality Assurance/Expo, Key Team Member
Pros: It's a perfectly decent place to work.
Cons: Money can be an issue. Promotions can be used as a carrot.

Title: "Corporate expects a lot and gives nothing back in return"
Pros: Management are real good people, I honestly love my management team.....for corporate management they are pretty good,
Cons: it's the corporation itself that is the problem, we are under the umbrella of Pepper Dining...so I don't know what to to say about Brinker but I hear it is a lot better to be under Brinker...Pepper Dining has a high risk credit score.....meaning they don't pay their bills on time.....they are still controlled by the investment group Olympus....after more than 5 years......
Advice to Management: GO BACK TO BRINKER

Title: "commissary manager"
Pros: Before casting off your real-estate albatross, carefully weigh the pros and cons.
Cons: Each technology has its pros and cons, and each must be a part of any conversation about literacy and learning.
Advice to Management: Set clear standards for your team

Title: "Management"
Pros: Great Company to work for, always looking for good managers
Cons: 1 weekend off a month
Advice to Management: agree to be transferred will help you in your career.

Title: "busting your ass off for $2"
Pros: Great co-workers, and schedule was flexible so it works if you are a student and want to work part-time
Cons: Working at a family restaurant means working really hard but earning a few dollars at a time (if any). It can get frustrating cleaning up after children's' messes with parents rushing out the door and not leaving any tips, so you end up having to pay for serving your guests rather than getting paid.
Advice to Management: Mandatory 15-18% tipout on a party over 6.

Title: "5 years in t g i fridays kingdom"
Pros:
work in chills
Working as a supervisor with a salary of at least 4000sr
Cons:
To lead the team on each shift and ensure the company service standards are upheld.
‚Ä¢ Escort customers to their tables.
‚Ä¢ Explain how various menu items are prepared, describing ingredients and cooking methods.
‚Ä¢ Present menus to customers and answer questions about dishes and make recommendations.
‚Ä¢ Remove dishes and glasses from tables or counters, and take them to kitchen for cleaning.

Advice to Management:
Leadership-Communication-Budgeting
Shift leaders are often be charged with monitoring stock levels and placing orders with suppliers for the replenishment of ingredients and drinks. They must be able to source quality ingredients at low prices and ensure they don't over-order. Any ingredients that have to be trashed at the end of the day can seriously eat into a restaurant's margins.

Title: "i can not tell you"
Pros: made great tips on weekends
Cons: the customer wanted everything for free

Title: "I dont want to enter a title"
Pros: good money, good co-workers / managers
Cons: customers can be needy and annoying

Title: "It's a burger joint"
Pros: You get to wear jeans.
Cons: it's a burger joint. Self-explanatory.

Title: "This is not a job for the lazys..."
Pros: there is money to be made (4 bonus' year), lots of support available from other managers and the ability to learn and gain experience
Cons: You will work hard, be challenged and learn every aspect of the restaurant...only for the lazys is this a con
Advice to Management: You have to have pride and passion for what you do. The best thing you can do for your guest is MAKE THEM FEEL SPECIAL. OH, and it's cool to be a "Chilihead". :)

Title: "Casual atmosphere with heavy emphasis on upselling and sales contests"
Pros: A relaxed atmosphere and friendly coworkers make it a generally pleasant place to work at the restaurant level. There is usually an attempt to work with your schedule.
Cons: Constant pressure to sell, and upsell, and pressure customers to fill out (long) surveys. Chilis is a casual restaurant, and some of the ambitions of management such as the average amount they expect each customer to spend is simply unrealistic. The constant contests and different-themed sales start to wear on the employees after a while.
Advice to Management: Upper management should spend more time at the restaurant level so that they can learn how to form more helpful and realistic policies.

Title: "Bartender"
Pros: It was fun to be a ChiliHead. The restaurant industry is fast paced, but you learn to work as a team to get things done. You will get an occasionally rude guest but if you enjoy making someone's day better, you will definitely enjoy working at Chili's. Longer than server shifts.
Cons: Minimum wage. Rude guests. It is a lot of work to clean a bar. There is a lot of cleaning involved. You will also get sticky.
Advice to Management: Have more manager in training opportunities and look for in house talent.

Title: "Fine, but too corporate"
Pros: Fair tips sometimes, room for small advancement in time (bar tending, trainer, etc.), lots of fun people
Cons: Horrible guests, too much pressure from company, too "formatted" and not relaxed enough, management could stand to chill a little (although I'm sure they're just being pressured from a higher power), overall the customers made me hate my job and so I had to quit. White trash and rude, would much rather work at a steakhouse somewhere and make real money.
Advice to Management: Chill.

Title: "A good one"
Pros: Meet great people, there are always opportunities for growth
Cons: Customer is always right, can be frustrating at times
Advice to Management: NA

Title: "Need To Rethink Their Strategy"
Pros: Competetive Pay for Managers. It is also easy to relocate if you need to. Excellent commitment to St. Judes
Cons: The need to take better care of their front line employees and quit changing their concept. Nobody knows what's on the menu anymore because it changes every month!
